description:
I highly recommend going to the Botanical Gardens if you are looking for a low-cost high-quality day! (It's free for SF residents, too!)

There is so much to see in the Botanical Gardens and a huge lawn to lay a blanket down and spend a few hours. There's even an area to get married! I never find the Gardens overly crowded so it's a peaceful place to read a book or bring out of towners.

What I like about the Botanical Gardens is that the vibe is completely different than you will find at Dolores Park or Golden Gate Park--there are no screaming birthday parties or people cheersing champagne glasses! Only peace and self-reflection. 

Don't forget to buy yourself a plant when you leave ;)
author: Sydney G.

description:
This place is basically a Disneyworld of plants. We had no idea where we were wandering - until a sign would come up and say "Chile" or "temperate Asia". The whole time it felt like we were in some kind of amusement park, everywhere we looked there was something incredible to see, touch, or smell. 

Probably one of my favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Travis B.

description:
Beautiful place. I visited here a few months ago and loved it. I am a nature lover and no better place than a garden or park to be around all the wonders of nature. 

I love how the habitat is distinguished based on the countries and regions. I particularly loved the bamboo area, it is small but I have an innate penchant towards the canopied bamboo trees from my childhood. 

So I absolutely loved the garden. I will be visiting here more and soon.
author: Anu W.

description: Had the most amazing time here! Entry was $9 for non-sf residents but well worth it. It was almost like traveling from continent to continent as you get lost in the immersive environments. There were many different paths to choose from and you could spend several hours looking at all the species of plants they have to offer. Free parking if you can find it.
author: Zach H.

description:
A.MA.ZING. We spent 3 hours in here and I still don't think we covered every pathway! We walked about 7,000 steps and were completely in awe of all the different trails and plants. We loved how they are broken up into continents and we felt like we were entering each one as we would walk into the middle and surround ourselves in their native plants. I felt that the $9 entry was SO worth the experience we had. I would absolutely come back to take a friend who is in town or something along those lines. 

I also loved the children's garden!
author: Melissa B.

description: Most beautiful garden I have ever been to. Try the "aroma garden" there is a mint plant that smells just like a pineapple. How about visit the "cloud forest" garden to view tropical plants. It is beautiful year round. The place is well kept and very cleaned. It is free for San Francisco reasoner so bring your ID or letters they show your address. You can park in the neighborhood for free on Sunday and walk to the park.
author: Desiree N.

description: SF Residents with ID gets in for FREE! Score! I love coming here especially during the spring for the flower blooms. Summer is also very nice with several events happening such as the Flower Piano which is happening right now! 12 pianos placed all around the park with performances by very talented  pianists. Even if you aren't into classical music you will find something you would like. Anyways, the park is quite large. Plenty of room to explore and just enjoy the outdoors. I love the fragrance garden, smelling them all and the redwoods area, which feels like you are at Muir Woods. I encourage you to picnic here, it's peaceful and beautiful with many different plant species all around. Bring a friend, a date or family, everyone will enjoy. I guarantee it!
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description: This city never ceases to amaze me. Twelve grand pianos scattered through the Botanical Gardens. Anyone can stop and play.
author: Joe M.

description:
If you go here before 9 am, it's free. My family and I drive to SF once a month to visit the Botanical Garden because we love to see the plants grow and flowers bloom, especially seasonally.

The garden is huge. Since we go early in the mornings, its nice and quiet and finding parking at Golden Gate Park is very easy. This place is great for dates and family outings. You can take snacks inside, so it's great for a little mini picnic.

You can see everything in about two hours.
author: Ami S.

description: This garden is a nice stroll for all. It is fairly quiet and protected from the noisy city, and it also has an amazing selection of flora, it actually has a redwood forest that very well mimics the tallest trees in the northern part of the state. Also, a small Asian garden waits for you if you want to find some real peace and solitude. But above all, a really nice morning walk.
author: Julio H.

description:
We all have to agree to disagree! The city of SF is world class but this garden certainly is not. 

I came here on Christmas Day b/c it was a free day. Glad I came, checked this place out, and finally crossed it off my list. 

This botanical garden is mediocre at best. I'm kind of a botanical garden snob and have been to quite a few much more impressive gardens around the country including the Huntington. I had high expectations because of the stellar ratings and SF. But it was a very underwhelming experience. 

The garden wasn't particularly well maintained and there really wasn't much to see. It only took about an hour to finish. It felt to me like it should just be a part of the Golden Gate Park which was the case before. 

Overall, I was disappointed. I'm glad I didn't pay admission b/c it's totally not worth the price. It's safe to say I'll not be back nor bring my family here when they visit.
author: Angela F. W.

description: It was beautiful here! And it was free every 2nd Tuesday of the month. Lots of different trees from different regions and a plethora of flowers; exotic and native flowers. Also has lots of grass area to lay a blanket and have a picnic at! It was a sunny day when we visited and it was a nice relaxing time! I almost forgot that I was in the middle of the city.
author: Jade W.

description:
If there's one thing I regret not having done in the first six years that I have lived in the Bay Area, it's taking the time to visit the San Francisco Botanical Garden. I guess I never stopped by because it didn't seem worth it to pay for a garden when there's nature everywhere, and there was always something else to do in the city. But last weekend, I decided to surprise my girlfriend by taking her to the garden since it was one of the last few chances anyone had to see fall colors there. After a few hours of walking around, we both had the same thought in our minds: "San Francisco, you've surprised us with another gem!"

Two words described what we saw inside the garden: GORGEOUS and VIBRANT. Immediately when we walked in, we encountered the most massive and beautiful tree. Even with winter fast approaching, this beast stood tall and robust amongst a sea of nature. Venturing deep into the garden, we then found ourselves surrounded by a maze of life. Apparently there were tens of thousands of different plants here, and we found each one to be both stunning and magical. Unlike what some had said, there were PLENTY of fall colors to see! To me, the most scenic spot was the moon viewing garden. It was like we were in a mini Japanese garden.

If the scenery isn't enough to draw you here, let me convince you further. For those of y'all who enjoy spending hours in a garden, you will LOVE the San Francisco Botanical Garden. I mean this place was gigantic! It was almost the same size as a zoo - only instead of hundreds of critters we got an army of plants (although there were still animals here too like the duckies). We stayed for about 2 hours and it still wasn't enough. Don't worry about getting lost because there are maps and signs everywhere (as well as bathrooms!).

Think you'll be bored though? Trust me, you definitely won't be. It was SO relaxing and peaceful to just walk around here. The garden wasn't crowded, the diverse paths kept us engaged, and if you're afraid of getting tired there are plenty of benches along the way. 

One of the most underrated aspects of the San Francisco Botanical Garden had to be the location. Since it was directly inside Golden Gate Park (aka San Francisco's version of Central Park), there was SO much to see and do here in addition to the garden. Whether this is your first time visiting or your 100th, you can easily make a day trip out here. The only thing that sucked was parking but if you're patient you can definitely find a spot (most are free for 4 hours!).

When coming here, note that general admission is $8 for adults ($6 for youth/seniors, $2 for children 5-11, and free for those under 5). If you're an SF resident or a member, you don't have to pay! It's also free before 9am each day, during the second Tuesday of every month, and on certain holidays (Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's).

Of all the attractions I've paid around $8 for in my short life (e.g. museums, shows, etc), the San Francisco Botanical Garden definitely had one of the best bang for the buck. This garden was so visually pleasing, spacious, and quite serene. Thanks dear San Francisco, for you've once again provided my girlfriend and me with a memorable adventure. I wholeheartedly give the San Francisco Botanical Garden an "Omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this" rating. If I were an SF resident, you BET I'll come here weekly.

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
I finally found some time to explore the botanical garden this morning! I've known about free entry for SF residents for a while now, but I just recently found out about free entry on Christmas, New Year's Day, and every Tuesday from 7:30-9am. 

I've always loved exploring botanical gardens in other cities, it's a shame I didn't give this one a chance until today. The inside of this garden is HUGE! There's a wonderful garden of fragrances near the entrance, and from there you can explore plants from different time periods and different parts of the world. I really enjoyed the succulents and redwoods, and I'm excited about seeing more the next time I go! 

On the way out, I spotted some people headed in with pizza and a blanket. Sounds like a pretty good afternoon plan to me! :)
author: Christine L.

description:
I adored this place! I love walking around, especially in nature. The garden is huge, so my friends and I spent hours walking around and enjoying the sceneries. There are plenty of trees, plants and flowers to look at and learn about. If you get tired, you can sit and relax. 
Overall, it's a beautiful garden!
author: Ngoc Tran D.

description: Best bargain in SFO!  $8 for non-residents (free for residents).  Wonderful walks thru the different botanical regions-my favorite was the Redwoods!
author: Molly M.

description: Really pretty ! Ideal to go for a walk to disconnect and relax ! I loved it! If you like nature this is a must go!
author: María G.

description:
Lovely even on a cold winter day. The magnolias and camellias were awesome.

Free entry to SF residents. I don't live in SF all of the time so my license does not say SF. However if I had shown a utility bill I would have visited for free. Admission is around $10 so it's still very reasonable--less than seeing a movie.
author: Joanna S.

description: This park was one of the best highlights of my stay in San Francisco! It is peaceful, beautiful, and pristine. I was lucky to be here while a special event was going on called Flower Piano, in which they place full-size pianos throughout the park, and people can play them and share their beautiful songs with others! It is a very special place.
author: Lon G.

description: Affordable, clean and great gardens. Staff is knowledgeable and friendly. Great location and lots a great plants/flowers.
author: Juan M.

description: $8 for an adult entry. Absolutely lovely and worth it if you are in love with nature like i am. Lots of different trees and plants from native Cali and other parts of the world.
author: Victoria M.

description:
A wonderful site to see while traveling.

It was very relaxing and peaceful here, and I was impressed with how clean the place was!

Lots of shady and sunny places to sit down and relax for either a picnic or just to enjoy the smell of the gardens around. It was fascinating seeing the sections divided by parts of the world to explore.

I wasn't able to find any place inside that sold drinks or food, but luckily there are plenty of options near the park, and as long as you save your ticket you can show it to come back in the same day.
author: Amy R.

description:
I have never walked through this part of the park. It was beautiful, well designed and taken care of. We walked part of it before our tickets for deYoung exhibit and the rest afterward. Free if you live in the city, $8 if you don't, but good for re-entry too.

Really enjoyed the walk, seeing different parts of the botanical world represented, and seeing how each part was arranged. Worth the time and walk.
author: Susan K.

description:
I have lived in the bay area 98% of my life and this was my FIRST time visiting the SF Botanicals. The sprawling grass looks like an ideal place to set-up an easel, a blank canvas and paint the lush landscape that surrounds you. It's the PERFECT PLACE to sit and set up a quiet afternoon picnic. It was absolutely peaceful! 

Actually, the best word to describe this place -- ROMANTIC. 

One of the reasons why I avoid trips to the city is because, when I think of the city, all I envision is the traffic, the overpopulation of tourists on Embarcadero. But here, you can enjoy being in the city but away from the chaos. This (to me) is the heart of the city. This is my idea of an escape. 

I would gladly come back to experience the tranquility of the gardens.
author: Shiela T.

description: My favorite place to go for a relaxing walk. The fragrant garden is awesome to go through and smell every herb. Flower piano is an awesome event here every year!
author: Ly P.

description: I love visiting this botanical garden. It's peaceful, absolutely beautiful. Has great variety of plants!
author: Alma C.

description:
What a piece (or peace) of tranquility smack dab in the middle of San Francisco. For just  a small fee, unless you're a local, you can enter the garden to lose yourself along the endless trails viewing the beautifully maintained flowers and such.

Plenty of places to escape the hustle and bustle of The Fran.
author: Kevin F.

description:
This place reminds me of Central Park, but on steroids. It is quite big and has areas where you can completely isolate yourself from the rest of the busy city. Central Park rarely can boast about that.

There are lots of amazing flowers, unique plants and scents. Every area is carefully manicured and is well-maintained. My favorite part was the front entrance: open field with groups of people just enjoying outdoors on the grass - peaceful and somehow trendy simultaneously.
author: Christy W.

description: This is a great place to come with family and get away from the rush of the city for a while. There is an entrance fee, but it is well worth it.
author: J. C.

description:
It's another world out here!

You should hike a bit to the cloud forest and other dense forest  areas to really feel it. 

And there are quite a few surprises like the ponds, hide Piono and a beautiful Japanese garden with a deck & a green pond!

It's worth a whole day trip.
author: Deebs M.

description:
I've been a fan of San Francisco Botanical Gardens since back in the early 2000's, when it was free to the public. Times have changed and they now charge admission (more on that in a bit) but the gardens have stayed spectacular and have only gotten better over the years. I try to make a point to visit once a year and vary my trips by season. Each season brings different blooms, lighting and a unique overall experience to the garden goer. This is the kind of place where you can spend a few hours or all day. Despite being strategically placed near so many other attractions in Golden Gate Park, the gardens are never overly crowded. The atmosphere of tranquility is apparent from the moment you start meandering down their paths. The city fades away and you're transported to a variety of ecosystems and geo specific garden areas.

It can often be a bit chillier and foggier here, so plan accordingly. Many times the sun will also break through-layers are in order. There is quite a bit of walking involved if you want to see all of the gardens and many paths are wheelchair accessible. Because of the zig-zagging paths you can take a different route each time and enjoy the displays from different points of view. On my most recent visit, I took the guided map which highlights their "Magnificent Magnolias" in bloom. The route was easy to follow and it was a fun little floral treasure hunt to be sure to see each magnolia tree in bloom (typically January-March.)

Other highlights of the garden and my faves include the Redwood Grove, Central American Cloud Forest and the rhododendron garden. There is so much more so I highly recommend any botanical garden fans to plan a few hours-bring a picnic and book and take time to relax on the many lawn areas and benches to truly soak in the surroundings.

Admission for non San Francisco residents is $8 but if you are a member of either this garden or the UC Berkeley Botanical garden, admission is reduced or free. My UC Berkeley garden membership got me and a friend in at no charge to the SF gardens-that annual membership has honestly been one of my favorite gifts of all times. Parking can be found in the museum garage, some limited spaces along the park streets (closed to through traffic on Sundays) or in the nearby Inner Sunset area. You can also take the Judah muni and get off at 9th & Irving with a short walk over to the park. Highly recommend you visit any way you can get here. Every season offers botanical wonders and happiness!
author: Jennifer N.

description: The flowers were beautiful, they were kept nice, it was raining lol but we still tried visiting everything. The only thing that i didn't like was that it was kind of boring. I'm all for looking and reading but everything was so small, little bushes of flowers and herbs no spazazz
author: Erika M.

description: Skip the conservatory and come here for 2 hours. This is one of the largest and most beautiful botanical gardens I have been to. I got lost many times smelling the magnolia flowers that were in bloom. Then there's the cactus, the various regions (Asia, Africa), and redwoods. If you've been to Descanso Gardens in SoCal, this is similar.
author: Julie L.

description:
Come early in the morning or on a weekday and the parking is a little easier otherwise it is a lot of heart ache looking for a spot.

This garden has a lot of hidden gems. This time I was delightfully surprised by the magnificent tulip magnolias. A very tall magnolia from the himalayas and the blooms were huge. Another pleasant surprised were the crab apple blooms that look similar to hawthorn blooms. You can't experience every thing in one visit. Plants display their blossoms at different times throughout the year.
author: Keo N.

description: Had a nice stroll through the gardens. Got some great photos. $8 entrance fee per person. What a beautiful adventure. Makes a romantic date. Invite a loved one!
author: Elle K.

description:
Walked by with a friend and since we'd both never been to the gardens, we took our first visit. Very beautiful! Lots of flowers were still in bloom, though we're making it a point to come again next spring for sure! 

SF residents get in free!

It was uncrowded on a Sunday, spacious, lovely, and overall just a relaxing place to walk, talk, and explore.
author: Thalia F.

description:
A great Park in the city .. with acres to explore .. flowers and plants you've never heard or seen .. from other countries are well represented here..

The Tranquility of this place and the smell of the surrounding is like your in a forest ..

Well guided path with lots of information.. plants and from where...

Plus this too .. if your a San Francisco resident? Free entrance!!!
author: Donovan L.

description: This is our first time visiting this botanical garden.  Entrance fee is mandatory  $8/adult.  It is a lovely garden with lots of plants and ponds.  We really appreciate the experience of seeing their redwood forest.  It was majestic and beautiful.  We really enjoy exploring this garden.  It was a nice get away from the busy city scenery.  We used public transportation to avoid parking hassel.
author: Sydney T.

description: One of my favorite places in SF! The gardens are always so beautiful and well maintained at all seasons, although the spring is my personal favorite time to visit. The staff who work at the entrance are always super polite and friendly. It's a lovely landscape, especially if you're out for a casual walk or a family picnic.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Free admission every second Tuesday on the month, just walk right in! Also free daily to SF residents (with proof), and free daily admission from 7:30-9 AM.

Free street parking in the SF Golden Gate Park, usually 4 hour maximum time limit.

 Map available upon entrance.

My favorites: moon viewing garden/lake and the succulent garden.

Benches available throughout the gardens for sitting down to relax and enjoy the scenery, pop open a book, have a little picnic.

People are very respectful of the signs "Stay on path".

Amazing experience!  We went to go see the American bison afterwards.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Our family had a great time strolling around the gardens. Spent at least 2hrs here, and we didn't get to see everything! Would definite return. Very peaceful with lots of beautiful trees and flowers. 

Free every second Tuesday of the month, Free everyday from 7:30am-9am, always free for SF residents, and free with any arboretum pass. We have a LA arboretum pass that also gets you free admission to 300 other gardens in the US, which included SG botanic gardens & conservatory of flowers.
author: Victoria S.

description: What a beautiful garden. It is well cared for, nice staff and intriguing. I loved the bamboo pond and fragrance garden. In the fragrance garden you can touch and smell a large variety of herbs and plants. And the ancient plant section is excellent. I didn't spend enough time here. I'll be back
author: Julian C.

description: As an SF resident (which includes people on fee month leases! Get in there interns!) , You get in free, definitely worth checking out.
author: Daniel G.

description:
The San Francisco Botanical Garden is awesome!  It's huge and there is so much ground to cover.  The funny part is that I never knew it existed until just a couple years ago.  It's very surprising to see such a massive garden close to the city.

This is a great place to exercise your photography skills and give your camera a workout.  There are so many subjects and views to take photos of.

My favorite areas are the California Redwood forest (http://bit.ly/2eunQAd), the bamboo garden that makes you feel like you've transported to Japan (http://bit.ly/2euoPAf), and the Moon Viewing Garden which has a small pond with a deck that overlooks it (http://bit.ly/2eunIQU).

In regards to that last picture from the Moon Viewing garden, during the summertime, they place pianos throughout the garden for anyone to play on (http://bit.ly/2euqbLq).  It was really cool because there were some really talented piano players at the garden that day I went (http://bit.ly/2euq6HF).  Great nature views with beautiful piano music in the background made for a very tranquil experience.

I honestly could spend a whole day at the Botanical Garden and just meditate and relax especially on sunny days.  In my opinion, I like it better than it's more popular neighbor, the Japanese Tea Garden.  It's almost quadruple in size, many paths to explore, and an overall better value for the general admission price you pay to get in.  Definitely check it out if you've never been before and want to see a part of San Francisco you probably never expected to see.
author: Rodney H.

description:
As someone that has lots of plants in my home, I'm biased about loving the San Francisco Botanical Garden. I came here for a quick after lunch tour with a friend.

-- LOCATION --
The garden is located in the southern eastern part of Golden Gate Park. The garden is large and the entrance is on the east side of it, along 9th Avenue. The entrance cost is free for San Francisco county residents, and $8 for adult visitors. You are provided a map to help navigate your way around. I suggest Googling "San Francisco Botanical Garden map" beforehand if you want to take a specific path.

-- MAINTENANCE --
This place is gorgeous and well-maintained. Sprinklers are at locations where humid plants get the moisture in the air they need. Old or dead leaves can be seen composted for reuse into the Earth. You can tell that the people that help maintain the garden care for it.

-- COLLECTIONS --
You could have a nice peaceful stroll through here alone, or walk around on a date. My friend and I decided to walk in a counter-clockwise path. Along the way, we went through some bamboo mini-forests of Temperate Asia, saw some cacti growing along the walls in the Succulent Garden, explored the Ancient Plant Garden, and saw some very large trees from New Zealand. There is a great Meadow which reminds me a little of Central Park where you can just sit down and absorb the calming scenery.

-- PLANT STORE --
I had hoped to see some carnivorous plants and maybe I missed it, but, I did see some in the plant arbor/bookstore. After you are done and get back to the entrance/exit, you can buy plants to take home! There are a variety of plants to buy here which you could easily carry in one hand, or in a car if you wanted something bigger. Since I have enough plants at home I was ok but my friend was able to get a Venus Fly Trap. Take a look and bring some nature back in your home.

-- SUMMARY --
I wish I had more time to spend here and I will be sure I have that time on the next visit. Bring a friend, go yourself, or take your family for a fun explorative day. Recommended.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
If you are a resident of SF (just show your driver's license or ID), then here is a wonderful place to kill a couple of hours to see various plants from different countries.  We came today (11/25) so there weren't really that many flowers in bloom, but we still saw a lot of different things.  Make sure to wear comfortable shoes that you aren't afraid to get dirty since there are many dirt or bark covered paths throughout the garden where you can see lots of other plants that are not along the cement covered paths.

Would I come back? Definitely, since it's free and I would love to see the garden when there are more flowers in bloom.

Rating: 4 stars overall for the variety of things you can see and for the exercise you get in walking around such a large area.
author: Gilda W.

description:
Build communities of support for the Garden and cultivates the bond between people and plants. Botanical Garden Society Mission Statement.

In 1926 Helene Strybing in her will, left money for the construction of the Arboretum in Golden Gate Park San Francisco. The donation was in 1939 about $ 200,000. Additional money was left for her siblings and other organizations that work for the welfare of sick, children and animals. The arboretum officially opened in May 1940.

She had a tree named after her; Leptospermum scoparium 'Helene Strybing' (New Zealand Tea Tree)

This botanical garden encompasses 55 acres and is sectioned off depicting many different climates. Such as; Temperate Asia, Meso American Cloud forest, South Africa, Mediterranean garden, California Native, New Zealand, Australia, Gondwana Circle, Chili, Andean Cloud Forest, Redwood Grove and many more.

Spent the whole day taking pictures (estimate about 500) so much to see, smell and experience here!

8,000 kinds of different plants from around the world! It's easy to get a bit overwhelmed at first due to the large size and sheer acreage. Just follow the maps, take one section at a time, hydrate and soak in the wonderful presence of the trees and the foliage while sitting on one of many bench's throughout the park.

My favorite spot by far, the Redwood forest! The strong aroma of the trees hits you with the fist step in. Secondly the stunning silence surrounds you.

Beautiful, serene park, nice place to spend a day.

Sadly we missed the Flower/Piano days as our time ran out! Next time!
author: Margaret A.

description:
One of my favorite parts of the park! Never too crowded, nice areas of grass and benches to read or picnic. Free admission for SF residents (they check ID or ask for zip codes). I love the annual flower pianos-- 12 pianos places around the park for formal performances and also for the public to play. I do wish they were open a bit later in the summertime. They close at 5 which is a bummer (at least until 6/7 would be nice on weekends). The magnolia blooms are also beautiful to check out in the spring.

The entrance is close to 9th/Irving making it a great place for a post-meal stroll.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
So beautiful to spend time here whether you're siitting or walking around enjoying nature. There are different gardens featuring plants/trees indicative of the climates in each region:  Australia, Chile, New Zealand, Asia, Redwood Grove, and more. 

We happened to be here for the second Tuesday of the month, which is free, all day. It's worth the money to stroll around or sit and relax. They had people playing pianos in the flowers!  We absolutely loved music with nature.  It's a great oasis to escape the city.  There are restrooms and no cafes; bring a picnic lunch with you and enjoy.
author: Tammy B.

description: My husband and I really enjoyed this place. It's really beautiful and a great place to spend a peaceful afternoon. Cheap admission for non San Fran residents. If you're looking for more flowering plants, I'd come in Spring. We went yesterday in the middle of winter and didn't see too many flowering plants since they're out of season. Other than that, there's a lot to see and it's super nice.
author: Riley M.

description:
What a delight. In all my years of living in the bay area I have to wonder why I never made it here before. So much to see and smell. Even got some great suggestions for plants that would do well in our garden.

Admission is free on the second Tuesday of each month. We went relatively early and actually found street parking.

Also, I didn't learn until after our visit they have an app you can use to navigate the gardens and identify the plants and trees. Check their website.
author: Thomas B.

description:
The event is simply called Flower/Piano and it runs from July 7-18, 2016.
SF residents get in for free with photo ID.

The twelve days, twelve pianos and one giant garden are an invitation you shouldn't miss.
Once again the city becomes an outdoor concert hall and everyone is invited to play or listen.
There are a few professional pianists thrown in the mix too but, today it was mostly everyday folk who shared everything from "Bennie and the Jets" to "Bohemian Rhapsody".

The event had a really nice vibe and included receptive audiences all throughout the 12 different places set up with pianos.

It's a creative idea and another example of when SF does something right.

Clap! Clap! Clap!
author: Thomas D.

description: Grab tickets to the night garden piano concert.  Pack a picnic, you'll love it.  Great for visitors, show off our beautiful gardens.
author: SF T.

description:
We decided to enter based on the 4.5 stars rating on Yelp. Admission is $8 for adults (ages 18+) and they do not offer student discounts unfortunately. They do have lower rates for other demographics though.

It's not a bad place to check out if you're already in the Golden Gate Park area. The Botanical Garden has different themed sections and is quite spacious. It was nice to walk around the area and see all sorts of colorful flowers and plants. In total, we spent around 45 minutes at the Botanical Garden and walked around a mile and a half. However, unless you are an avid lover of flowers and plants, I don't recommend this place. I love nature, but don't think I'll be returning here anytime soon since I just didn't find anything that memorable; all I remember is seeing pretty flowers here and there. Perhaps you can look at some photos first to decide if it's worth the trip and entrance fee.

I would recommend visiting the other areas that Golden Gate Park has to offer such as the Japanese Tea Garden and the California Academy of Sciences, especially if you have time to spare 1-2 hours.
author: George L.

description: This is a great place to go birding. Went birding here today and got some great pics. There are some varieties here too. Just wanted to share that with all the people who are a birder like me. Check out me photos below.
author: Ford W.

description: Free if you have an SF address on your ID.  But make sure to donate if you can!! Always a very lovely walk with lots of plants to look at from around the world.
author: Trinh T.

description: Came here for the first time on my first trip to San Fran, and I have to say it was so beautiful and they layout was so huge and so many hidden trails i don't think I viewed the whole park. Saw a few people having Picnic there which seemed cool definitely a place to bring the family or relax!
author: Linda C.

description:
A Garden to treasure and continue to visit time and time again! The garden is sectioned off into different areas with plenty of space and scenic trails which provide blissful hours of exploration. The Bamboo forest was one of my favorites. There is plenty of areas to picnic, read, meditate and simply enjoy quiet time among the beautiful gardens. There are beautiful trees galore and gorgeous colors surrounding you every where you look. 
The fee is just $8 and for San Francisco residents there are no cost fees. Next time I come here I will surely prepare picnic treats.
author: Yoh M.

description:
San Francisco Botanical Gardens is magical
It is so big and there are so many things to see. The different gardens transport you to different countries and even back in time!
Our favorite gardens are the succulent garden, the Garden of Fragrance, and the Ancient Garden. 
The Garden of Fragrance is full of beautiful lavenders, mints, and tons of fragrant flowers to smell and admire. I often walk through with a notebook to write down any plants I would like to look for for my garden.
The California Succulent Garden is so well done. Many different levels to walk through. Aloes, aeoniums, agaves, and many different cacti. Many of them very old plants and so huge! The bushes of aloes look like something from an Alien movie. We love it! Although we do find some species are not labeled, which makes succulent lovers like us sad LOL
The Ancient Garden transports you to the time of dinosaurs. Huge ancient ferns, palms, and species of plants that are just so neat. 
These are just a few of the many gardens and things to explore at SFBG
Make sure to stop in the plant store, where they sell clippings of plants from the gardens. They also sell books, seeds, and many more items. The proceeds go to help fund SFBG
Parking can take a minute since it is all street parking inside Golden Gate Park, but we have never had a problem finding a spot well within walking distance of the entrance
Perfect for families, dates, meet-ups, or just a quiet walk by yourself
They have docent led tours as well. I have not taken one but I have heard they are wonderful. One day soon we will definitely to a proper tour.
This is a beautiful spot not to be missed when you are in San Francisco!
author: Kat R.

description: Stunning and relaxing. Free for SF Residents. See the plants and flowers of the world! The annual 'Flower/Hidden Piano' event every year is lovely as well.
author: Callie C.

description:
Almost a 5-star average? Do people feel obligated to give a high rating just because it's a botanical garden, which has cachet enough, & it's in their beloved SF? Or do they actually think it's all that? This place isn't Bouchard Gardens, the Huntington, or any fancy destination garden. The SFBG is just a local, regional, ho-hum nature area. People from outside don't come here for a reason, & it's not just because they started charging admission for non-residents a while ago. 

It's like Yosemite, Apple, & everything else - overrated. Any random limestone cliffs in China, from what I've seen in pics, is 5000x prettier & more stunning than your beloved Yosemite. Except they don't boast it's practically heaven, the way people think of Yosemite & anything else worshipped in the SF hipster outdoorsy crowd. Americana really rules in SF, much more than you can imagine. Except here, it takes the form of hipster racism, unbridled love for Trader Joe's, showing off your Arc'teryx jacket - & anything else that might be dated by the time you read this, because SF's hipster Millenials move on to new trends very quickly. 

The SFBG can be enjoyed for what it is - a pleasant, if underwhelming, little local garden, just another little-known part of GG Park, which is overrated already. If you really think about it, the SFBG is purely a 3-star, mediocre, regional, non-destination garden. And actually, this place isn't that much of a "garden," per se - more like a nondescript nature area, w/wind-y dirt paths, like the rest of GG Park. It's not a fancy, obsessively-maintained place like the Japanese Tea Garden, or filled to the brim w/bright exotic flowers, like Bouchard Gardens. In fact, there's almost no color at the SFBG, other than grass green & the brown of barks, in any season. 

A major SF events site recently claimed that for 2 weeks, you can see fall colors in the garden. And then that day, I saw tons of people there, a younger & hipper crowd - the ones that follow that events site. The site provides very good advertising for everything. There was barely any fall colors that day, & in my many visits, I never noticed fall colors, ever. There are bits of fall colors all over SF, but they're not very visible, & no one ever talks about it. 

The outer reaches of the garden, like the children's area, is poorly maintained. It looks sad, like something that was abandoned long ago. It's like they thought of a great idea to add a children's area, & then the idea fell through, & you're left w/weird little chairs, basil plant labels, & strange odds & ends. Other outer areas of the garden look like they haven't payed much attention to it, & visitors rarely get there. The way the SFBG is, you're just mainly in the primary area, around the pond, & you just don't get much farther than that. For some reason, where ever you go, you just naturally circle back to the main area. 

There's a little horticulture library that seems rarely visited. And it's for a reason - the staff is always stuffy, & they ignore you, at least if you're non-white. The selection seems very dated. Supposedly they have children's book readings there, but I can see certain parents w/kids being a little less welcomed there, too. 

Once I saw an older employee/volunteer near the admissions kiosk warmly greeting & helping a man on his own. And that visitor wasn't just any man; he was white & had a slim, elegant Obama sort of build. The volunteer, like everyone else, just automatically liked & respected that guy, based on his appearance, so he gave him special treatment, though he didn't deserve it. That guy w/the Obama build surely gets everything in life, constantly, unfairly. Being greeted/helped warmly while other visitors are IGNORED is just one example; people with a look you like get advantages, unfairly, in all contexts/settings. I've been to SFBG many times, & no one ever cared to say anything to me, except a coarse and rude "HEY! GET OFF THAT LAWN" - when they would've let anyone else go, or said it in a nicer way, & chat them up, too. 

SFers are Trump at heart. We love to bash Trump, the way we did w/his predecessor, George W. - but people here really aren't that far from the racism, lookism, xenophobia, & provinciality of Trump. Bay Areans are just less forward about their very innate prejudices than Trump is. Trump's stupidity/stigmas are expressed everyday, by almost everyone, in SF, just in a more understated manner. If SFers took a test of subconscious bias, they'd fail it as badly as Trump.

UPDATE: Went there again, & a lady at the Front Gate rudely LAUGHED at me when I showed my ID. When I politely asked what was going on, she dismissively said I looked "robotic"! And when I emailed about it, & followed up, they FAILED to respond. And then I called a manager, & she was extremely rude/unhelpful. Docking off 2 stars--1 for terrible treatment multiple times, & another for failure to respond to my emails & painfully rude call with a manager.
author: Valle H.

description: Beautiful,  educational, kid-friendly and free to SF Residents. I regret not visiting sooner.
author: Katie W.

description:
A great park within the larger park that is Golden Gate Park.  What?  I've used up my allotment of the word park?  Ok then...

This...place has many different flowers including a prehistoric themed area and a redwood forest.  You need to stop in here.
author: Tom T.

description:
OMG!!! I've been going here my...entire...life! It was free for so long (nice) but over the decades, due to the natural regressive pathetic lethargy of the Park/Rec Dept, the Garden descended into a mess. So much became so ugly, so broken down. But now that people pay entrance and people like me become members, the signage is great, newsletters are out, advertising is out there, volunteers are clipping away and restoring and maintaining....it's AMAZING. On any given day, one can see families of all (un-Trumpish) shapes and sizes and creeds and colors and capacities. I love it. It's everything one wants in a public botanical garden. I can't really pinpoint any one thing because it's completely educational and restorative!

Go. Run. Enjoy. Restore and Learn.Love
author: Kevin F.

description: Great place to go if you love plants. It's located right across from the Japanese tea garden in the golden gate park. There are so many unique flowers and plants from around the world. We came during a weekday and parking was easy to find since there weren't many people there. It was very tranquil and a great place to enjoy nature Entrance is $8 for adults and free if you're a sf resident. We spent probably 2-3 hours here just exploring the different themed paths and looking at the different types of plants. There's also a small redwood grove and trail that gives you a taste of Muir Woods. We also saw lots of geese, squirrels, and even a raccoon near the small lake. Ask for a map when you get your tickets if it's your first time.
author: Helen J.

description:
Slide into a pair of sandals and kick them off to enjoy the luxuriously soft grass around the conservatory!

Beautiful displays, especially the lily pond inside the building. Be enchanted with the carnivorous alien-like plants. 

Lovely spot to get away from the hustle and bustle of the city. 

Don't forget a blanket/throw to lie down on and soak up the rays and fragrant blooms.
author: Leica G.

description:
Unfortunately, they are now charging an atrocious $8 to get in.

The gates behind the Hall of Flowers are frequently open, and you can enter for free this way.

Locals can get in by showing an ID, but they still have to pay for guests.

It is time to return these 55 acres to taxpayers!
author: George B.

description: Love the botanical garden and even more after attending the Night Piano during the annual Flower Piano this year.  Seeing the garden at night, it was magical and mystical.  The music was amazing and I hope they will bring the Luminescent Grand back (LED piano) - more importantly, memorizing music....electronic, tango, classical, Brazilian and more....I so look forward to next year.  This must continue.
author: Perry H.

description: New England Master Gardener thoroughly enjoyed seeing these gardens that are about two months ahead of our zone 5 gardens. Amazingly designed and so thorough!
author: Amy H.

description:
One of the most restful getaways in the city! 55.5 acres of lush plants from around the world all doing great in San Francisco's  micro climates. Quiet and beautiful, (with lots of oxygen) it's the best place to rest and revive. Free to S.F. residents!
Concerning Angel's review, she must not have been looking to hard. This garden is rated 3rd in the world for the variety of plants and is 3rd to China (which is 1& 2)  with Magnolias. No  one could appreciate it in an  hour. You do have to take the time to look!
author: Nona B.

description:
I have visited San Francisco several times since I moved to San Diego but always confined myself to areas within the city I am familiar with.  I had the obligatory visit to Golden Gate Bridge (no I didn't walk the whole length).  But I have never visited Golden Gate Park.  

On this visit after a family event in San Jose, I decided to kill time before my flight to visit GG Park.  Luckily, post Labor Day weekday, parking was available in the area.  Of course I parked closed to the San Francisco Botanical Garden and had to check it out.  Once I paid my entrance fee ($8) free for San Francisco residents, the lady in the ticket booth informed me that the Conservatory of Flowers was free for the day so I hightailed it over there, warning, its not a block away, it's on the other side of the park..lol.  bring water.

Well back to the Garden.  I appreciate small quiet parks within the confines of an urban city like San Francisco. I understand why this is free for residents, its actually a lovely park with sections designed for various countries or for California native plants.  The best part for me to explore is the Redwood Grove.  I have been lax in going further north of San Francisco to go see the Redwoods but this was a small taste of it.  I love old tall trees because they have been here for centuries, when I visited Europe a while ago, the best visits were to ancient spots.

Overall, the Garden provides nice little areas with benches to be able to medidate, read a book or explore.  It was worth the entrance fee.  I am sure seasonal flowers/plants would enhance the experience.

Note:  For some reason I was able to FaceTime on my phone with Brian while here (I always thought you needed wifi to do this), so I am assuming there is a wifi connection near the library.
author: Melanio F.

description:
One word: MAGICAL!! 

Stumbled upon this place after wandering through Golden Gate Park with some friends one Saturday afternoon. We were lucky enough to come on a day where they were having the flower pianos (12 pianos scattered throughout the park) and it was amazing! Crowds formed around each piano and visitors were able to go up and play a few pieces on the piano whenever they wanted. Music and nature are just so beautiful together!! Unfortunately, having the pianos also meant that I mostly focused on the music and didn't pay much attention to the diverse array of flowers at the garden. 

Nevertheless, it's a beautiful place to go with friends or family. You can easily spend a few hours here just admiring the views. There are so many food shops nearby too if you get hungry. I'll definitely be back to see the garden in its entirety. Bonus: SF residents get free admission!
author: Kris C.

description:
I have been living in SF for many years and this is my first time to visit the gardens. Spring time is the ideal time to come out and view the wonderful plants and flowers that are blooming, The garden hosts all types of plant life from indigenous to different parts of the world like New Zealand, Australia, and Africa. The gardens are clean and well kept. My favorite plants were the magnolias (Garden of flagrant flower area) and the rhododendrium flowering plants. 
Residents of SF are free admission, just present the staff your California DL or ID Card. Otherwise admission is $8.00- Summer times have extended to closing at 6:00pm.
Highly recommended from a native San Franciscan.
.
author: jack d.

description:
This is a fantastic garden. So many different regions of plants all in one place, but segregated in a way that you can begin to recognize which plants are native to which regions. We went on a Saturday morning, when a plant sale for California natives and succulents was occurring. Thankfully there was a separate line for cash vs credit, because the line for people paying with credit cards was at least 75 feet long, and the cash only line was nonexistent. Needless to say, we went with the latter option since we had the means to do so. On our way out, we saw that there was a path to get in to the park and the sale without going through the main gate, which is good knowledge for interns visiting the Bay or anybody else that might have forgotten their San Francisco ID (free admission if you live in SF) and didn't want to pay. 

Additionally, we saw a super cute groundhog/woodchuck/varmint burrowing holes on our walk to the plant sale. It looked super active, with many freshly dug holes nearby. I wonder how long it will take groundskeepers to take care of the mangled grass, but even with that said I enjoyed the brief glimpse of untamed nature. Speaking of that, the squirrels that live in the garden have no fear at all. I was able to stick my camera in their faces without issue and I swear that one even posed for me before scurrying off.

All in all, it was a great experience, and I can't wait to go back on a sunny day!
author: John B.

description: I've walked down many San Francisco streets but this was my first visit to the San Francisco Botanical Garden.  It's the first botanical garden I've been to with redwood trees.  I like how parts of the bark are soft and a bit furry.  It took hours to walk through the garden and many parts of the world are represented.  I liked the calm of the bamboo forest.  I loved the quiet stillness of this place in the midst of a big city.  Some of these trees have been here since the beginning in 1926.
author: Soo H.

description:
*Late post, during Magnolia season (mid-January through March)

Came here with my best friend to see the beautiful Magnolias in bloom and the immense variety of Magnolias all around the garden were breathtaking. There is so much to see and really is a great place to bring your kids or a date and just stroll around. Also bring along some food and drinks and have a picnic on the big grass area inside. Beautiful place to be :)

PARKING: street, free 
PRICE: FREE for all SF residents (with proof of residency), but for non-residents: 
Adults: $8
Youth (12-17) & Seniors (65+): $6
Children (5-11): $2
Under 4: FREE 

There are also free days on major holidays like Thanksgiving and Christmas, and a free time period every day from 7:30-9am.
author: Vivian S.

description: Loved this place. Visiting from dry Colorado it's amazing to see the plants that grow in this climate. Visited in late January and still plenty to see even though most plants aren't in bloom. Magnolias, camellias, and succulents were great. Had the place almost to ourselves too on a Thursday morning.
author: Paul H.

description: Love this place, conveniently located not to far from SFSU and also located in the middle of a lot of places around in SF, it's a go-to place for adventuring and admiring the view :)
author: Brian S.

description: Loved the flowers. Enjoyed my visit. Variety of flowers from different part of world to see.
author: Jyoti K.

description:
This place is so beautiful, clean, and spacious!

Came with cousins after our dimsum lunch, and a walk was certainly what we needed. We came for the Flower piano event, and having live piano music really enhanced the gorgeous atmosphere of the garden. There are so many different areas of the garden, so many different plants and flowers, and the staff was so friendly! Wear lots of sunscreen and even carry a parasol if you're a sun-hater, like me. ;)

Tip: Go to the bathroom before you come here. The bathroom isn't the cleanest (as it usually is with parks), and if you do need to go, then the lines take forever.
author: Jo W.

description:
I go here every time I'm in town and it's a new season! There are so many different areas to explore, I get lost in all the natural beauty. My favorite places are the Rhododendrons, the redwood grove, and the perfume (scented area I forget the name). 

I just went in February and the magnolias are in bloom!
author: Nikki T.

description: We are fortunate to have such an amazing place away from place.  Great signage to tell which country or continent you are in.  Need some quiet space, definitely.  This place should be free for all to enjoy and i wish sf doesn't have to be so money hungry all the time.  It's free for sf residents with ID only.  If you forget you ID, you got to pay.  I know the money goes towards keeping this place clean and beautiful, but i just wish this place can be free for all.  Love the one area concentrating on fragrant plants.  This year they had an event where there were 14 pianos placed at different places for people to play.  That was a really special event.  Piano under the gazabo.
author: Helen L.

description: Free Admission today!  We enjoy the San Francisco Botanical Garden especially more on free days!  I walked with a friend on our first visit and took our time and lots of photos.
author: Agnes C.

description: Nice little European getaway if you can get over the unfortunate city noise surrounding the garden.
author: Inigo M.

description:
What's not to like? It's quite large (nearly twice as big as Berkeley's Botanical Garden), stunningly beautiful, peaceful, and free (for SF residents - if you don't have a SF driver's license, they'll accept a screen shot of a utility bill).

Get lost in the redwoods - enjoy the cool air as the sun sneaks through the trees and you slowly walk around the spongy ground blanketed in leaves.

Wake up your olfaction meandering through the Fragrance Garden.

Or check out the crazy Monkey Puzzle tree and pick up some trivia facts such as it's the national tree of Chile.

Or just bring a blanket in bask in the sun on the lawn, knowing that a trip around the world is only steps away.

And keep coming back as a new season creates an entirely new experience.
author: Cristina S.

description:
I highly suggest going here especially if you're a resident of San Francisco - admission is free! You just have to show proof of residency. Since my ID wasn't updated, I showed a bill from an e-mail and was able to get in.

Since spring was just up and coming, there weren't a lot of flowers that were fully bloomed yet. However, there were a lot of paths to go to with different themes.

I was only able to go to about 1/4 and had to leave because I had an appointment, but I'd love to come back here again and experience the garden fully!
author: Aj C.

description: I came here a week a half week ago and I have to say this place is so beautiful that you can see the names for each flower from their region. Each section has a spot for you to look around. Good thing about coming here too is coming back without paying another fee, your receipt will expire at the end of the day. the coolest part i like coming here is the fountain. I took so many pictures for a hour that then the rain came in really rain hard. It rain like someone took a long shower. Luckily when I was taking pictures I have an  umbrella and a selfie stick to save the day. You'll love it if your really into nature and beauty.
author: Emily L.

description: The place is pretty much filled with a bunch of flowers/plants from different countries, small live music performances, and animals. Admission is $7 but free for San Francisco residents. They also have periodic plants sales where you can purchase certain plants that you can't find anywhere else. Perfect place for plant enthusiasts!
author: Tuyen H.

description: What a beautiful summer day to visit the SF Botanical Garden! Tuesdays are free for non-residents. The garden is spacious and was not overcrowded for a free admission day. The gardens look natural and not highly pampered. An amazing vast array of flowers and plants represented from different continents. An observant visitor will notice unique vibrant flowers that pop out. I enjoyed the massive pond that has turtles and coy fish.
author: Julie S.

description: This place makes me want to cry it's so beautiful and magical and foresty and oh oh so much more!! If you love nature or not this place will make you fall in love! The charm and gorgeous smells are enough to win you over in one breath. Highly recommended!! Bonus is that you feel like you have enough privacy and solitude here if you want or need it. So lovely *happy sigh*!
author: Sarah M.

description:
Very affordable ($8 for visitors, free for residents). Beautiful gardens. Came here for the redwoods and they didn't disappoint. Lots of different areas with a huge variety. 

Would definitely come back.
author: Sunia C.

description: Get your cardio in while smelling  and seeing the pretty flowers that bloom here. FREE for SF residents, $8 for everyone else. The flowers and plants here originate from all parts of the world, and there's even a garden of scents. Definitely worth a visit.
author: Corinna T.

description:
This botanical garden is so big! I came here for the Flower Piano event, and it was a unique experience. There were twelve pianos (a mixture of upright and grand) scattered around the garden for people to play on, and the settings for each of them were in the trees and very relaxing. It was really fun! I don't think I would otherwise come to this botanical garden, as I've been to bigger ones with more variety of plants. There's also a $7 entrance fee but it's free for San Francisco residents (bring an ID or water bill that has a SF zip code on it). It's a good place to take a stroll and there are different sections with plants from around the world, but I don't think I would come all the way to San Francisco just to visit this place.
4 stars for the Flower Piano event because of its uniqueness, 3 stars for the actual garden.
author: Andrea W.

description:
Having been a resident of San Francisco for the bulk of my life, I'm surprised that it took me so many years to finally make it out to the Botanical Gardens. Thankfully, last Saturday before heading into the downtown, the boy and I finally made a trip to visit.


THE HIGHLIGHTS:
+ Free admission for all SF residents
+ Affordable cost of admission for all others (~$10)
+ Different sections of the garden are dedicated to different environments/regions, with thriving indigenous plants and helpful name placards
+ Meticulously manicured lands and gardens
+ Beautiful place for a stroll (or engagement photo shoot, as we saw)

Being in Golden Gate Park, the 'golden hour' here may be more fog than you'd want for your photos, but it's still a lovely place to visit.
author: Claire S.

description:
One thing I miss about living in California is flowers, grass and trees. I definitely got my fill during my short visit to the San Francisco Botanical Gardens. Beautiful nature surrounds you as you walk through the gorgeous gardens and just enjoy your surroundings. 

It's a quiet sanctuary away from the hustle and bustle of the city, I recommend it to anyone.
author: Emily R.

description:
This is one of the most beautiful gardens in Northern California and is well worth the visit, especially during the 12 days of Piano in the Garden.  A dozen pianos are strategically placed throughout the vast gardens and citizens as well as professional musicians are invited to play on the open pianos.  No formal program, just beautiful music in some really special settings.  If you are lucky, you might even get to hear some original compositions by some of the Bay Areas most noted composers!
There is an admission charge to get into the Botanical Garden if you are not a San Francisco resident but there is no additional charge for the music.
The Garden feels relatively safe and secure, is well kept and is divided into many thoughtful spaces.  Even if you are not a gardener, there is a lot to love about the San Francisco Botanical Garden, just make sure you give it enough time to work its magic!
author: Linda T.

description:
Beautiful and expansive property!  You don't feel like you're in the city anymore.  I couldn't believe all the flowers that were in bloom in February!

Free for San Francisco residents.  You really can't beat this place for a nice relaxing walk.  Parking was fairly easy (I went on a weekday).  They even have free docent led tours, which I highly recommend.
author: Jaching H.

description: One of my favorite guided tours, thanks Savanna, I have ever been on. Learned so much and Spring is the perfect time to see some amazing flowers in bloom.
author: Timothy G.

description:
I visited San Francisco for the first time and had to come here. I was pleased to find out that my LA Arboretum pass got me access into the garden. It was all very beautiful and the staff were so helpful and kind. 
I love that the garden is surrounded by a handful of other beautiful destinations as well. 
The highlights were the redwoods and most of all the fragrance garden. I definitely will have to come back here every time I visit San Francisco.
author: Rose H.

description: We spent around an hour in the garden and enjoyed strolling around the narrow pathways. Although the place is very beautiful and located amongst the much bigger green area is known as Golden Gate Park, the entrance fee is quite expensive (8$ per person). If you are going with a couple of family members it can cost you especially if you want to see the rest of the park as the entrance fee is valid only for one area (we ended up paying around 70$ for Japanese Tea Garden and Botanical Garden next door). The Tea garden is relatively small so you will be able to see the entire space in matter of 20 min so I recommend that you actually sit down at the small restaurant on the premises and enjoy the nature (you payed for it).
author: WarmCoffeeHub ..

description:
It's a garden, inside a park! Maybe you're not an outdoorsy person, but the Botanical Gardens inside Golden Gate Park are amazing and have a wide variety of plants to view, and paths to meander. Like most of the attractions inside GGP, there's a fee to enter unless it's early in the morning or a specific day of the month. Check their website if you're interested in discounted or free admission, otherwise prepare to spend a few hours here and get the most of your $8 admission. 

There's different sections laid out by region, with plant life specific to that area. The paths are sometimes clearly marked, and other times are simple dirt paths that veer off in a different direction, and they all take you through, around, and amid some of the most beautiful and fragrant plants I've ever seen. I took tons of photos, and the different sections are unique and beautiful. You'll wish you had the budget to landscape your yard like the gardens here! 

Spent about 3 hours wondering around the 55-acre garden, and that felt like the right amount of time. It would be easy to spend longer in the gardens, but don't try to rush your way through or you'll just be upset with youself.
author: Melinda R.

description:
Very beautiful garden! It's very large and has a variety of beautiful trees and plants! It was not too crowded when I went on Sunday.
I recommend a visit to anyone!
author: Stephanie R.

description:
So pretty! So many plants and trees... and squirrels!

I came here this past Wednesday as part of a spontaneous trip to Golden Gate Park. My friend and I had never been to the Botanical Garden so we thought it'd be a nice stop. 

$8 adult. Free for SF residents. 

The garden is huge! I don't think we saw it all. But we tried, we really did. I never really expected it to be this big We came in half an hour before the gates closed at 4pm. We had a nice, tranquil visit. There were plenty of areas to explore and relax in. Great place to bring a sketchbook to sketch in!

Walking through the whole garden was a nice, easy 'hike'. I had a refreshing time here. :)
author: Shanise M.

description: Basically got lost bc it's very big but it's a good place to look at nature I suppose.
author: Cecilia H.

description:
I didn't expect it to be so massive! 

It was such a lovely trail, words can't describe how beautiful the greener was. I came here on a Sunday afternoon and it was just lovely to see everyone gathering to the park to enjoy themselves. Please wear comfortable shoes or rent a bike. There's a lot of scenery. 

Free for San Franciscans (w/ valid ID) 
$7 for non-residents.
author: Luisa P.

description:
I really, really enjoyed this place!

With me having the day to spare and it being a lovely sunny day I thought I'd leave the Walt Disney Family museum to my next visit (gutted...) and would spend the vast majority of the day outside. 

Ok so maybe you wouldn't naturally think of me as someone who gets my kicks in a botanical gardens but I really wanted to feel connected to SF nature after being in the city for a while, hitting many bars every night and this was the place to do it. 

Loads of different districts with native species and plants from all around the world - for $7 entry (free for SF residents) I learned that Californian is one of only about 7-8 'Mediterranean' climates around the world meaning pretty much anything will grow in this state - wow!

Something else which blew my mind was learning that beetles used to (and do still in some cases) pollinate flowers back in the days when bees didn't exist - think about that chicken and the egg like scenario peeps...

Well worth the money and time - there's also some cool bars and shops just across the avenue from its entrance.
author: Jonny Q.

description:
I've been to botanical gardens around the US and other countries, and this one is truly world class. I can't believe I've lived here for years and had never gone -- it's even free for SF residents. 

I was worried that there might not be many things blooming since it's September, but there were so many amazing flowers packed together, that I can't even imagine what it's like in the spring. 

The ratio of plants-to-walking is really excellent. Every square foot of the garden seems carefully planned to pack in more wonderful things to see, all meticulously labeled and growing vigorously.
author: Bonnie M.

description: I love nature so for me this was a really good experience. However if you or the person you're with are not into flowers (whether it's smelling them, admiring their beauty or learning where they come from, things like that) then this will not be your cup of tea. Check their website for free days but bring cash so you can still donate because you will enjoy your time there. I did grab a paper brochure to use while I was there, but to be green I gave it back at the end so the next person can use it.
author: Saní R.

description:
The San Francisco Botanical Garden is one of San Francisco's best kept wedding secrets!  They have several different areas to choose from (we did ours in the Garden of Fragrance, which is absolutely perfect for a wedding), and the prices are SO reasonable!   We could not have dreamed of a better place to have our wedding.

We also reserved the Sunnyside Conservatory in the  event we needed a rain location (and used Sunnyside Conservatory as our first look location since it, predictably, did not rain), but you could also arrange for a tent if rain is a risk.  We had the reception at Twenty Five Lusk in SOMA and offered a shuttle for a guests to the reception.  

The whole wedding was gorgeous, easy, and a fraction of what it would have cost us to do the wedding at a more mainstream spot in the Bay Area!  And we got a paver engraved at the fountain to commemorate our special day!

The full list of the locations available in the garden, and prices, available here:  http://sfrecpark.org/permits-and-reservations/weddings/wedding-site-directory/
author: J B.

description:
The gardens were superb! 

I really liked my visit here at Botanical Gardens. Many people visit this in the weekends so I would totally recommend people to visit the weekday for there isn't as much foot traffic. This also guarantees better pictures without anyone popping up in the background

Entrance: $8 bucks

Theres a tea station in the middle of the whole garden.

We got:
1.) Jasmine Tea
2.) Ice Green Tea
3.) Green Tea Ice cream  

I think the ice cream and the green tea was okay. I wasn't blown away BUT it was the beset Jasmine Tea Ive ever had. Its not your typical tea like the ones you get at chinese restaurants. It's high quality tea!!!! Really high quality.

My only complaint was the amount of people.

and like i said thats easily avoided by going in the weekday.
author: Christopher G.

description:
Great relaxing place with beautiful plants.

One of many great parks in the SF area.

Not for people who don't like walking around and enjoying nature!
author: Michael Y.

description:
This botanical garden exceeded my expectations by far due to a variety of reasons: 

1) Great price - I took advantage of the daily free admission by arriving within the time frame of 7:30am-9am.  Definitely check the website beforehand (http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org/visit/index.html) if you are interested in visiting for free. 

2) Unique plants - The garden's plant collection was very extensive, from flowers to herbs to redwood trees.  There were special plants from all over the world, grouped by geographical area. If I wasn't on a time crunch, I could have spent all day wandering the grounds of the botanical garden.  

3) Scenery - In addition to the plants, the landscape was very scenic.  There were many paved paths, fountains, and other architecture to enjoy during your walk through the botanical gardens.  There was even wildlife to observe (eg. birds, squirrels, ducks, etc...).  

I definitely recommend this garden for every nature lover!
author: Vy N.

description:
The San Francisco Botanical Gardens were until recently known last the Strybing Arboretum named for the women who provided the seed money to start the gardens.  The garden opens daily from 7:30 am with last entry varying by time of year,  The garden now charges 7 dollars for adults dollars for families to enter the garden but is free for city residents and members of the garden,  the garden is also free the second Tuesday of the month, Thanksgiving, Christmas and New years and before 9am.

The garden is broken into individual areas most pertaining to a part of the world, or a specific kind of plant, though a few are based on a concept like the Fragrance Garden and the Ancient Plant garden,  A few of its more notable gardens are: it's a small redwood grove, three outdoor cloud forests (more then any other botanical gardens) the California Native garden is best in the spring and late summer when many plants are in bloom,  The garden is also noted for its large camellia  collection and its magnolias which are so popular they have their own special event "Magnolias by Moonlight" each March.

SFBG has a number of endangered plants,  One of them, the "Puya raimondii" made the news in 2006 when after 33 years it finally bloomed.

Two of my favorite things about the garden are:

1 The tiny gift shop featuring books, cards, Japanese bells and other garden themed items.  Out front are usually some tables with other merchandise behind the shop is a plant sale area,  I often find gifts here for garden lovers.

2 Docet tours- these are great because the Docets know what is in bloom and try and show them off.  When the gardens were free there would sometimes be several of these tours throughout the day,  Now they are daily at 1:30 starting just inside the main gate to the garden.  These volunteer
 led tours tell you the history of the gardens and take you on  a hour to hour and a half tour of the gardens.  The tours very greatly as different guides have different interests and they try and show areas that are at their best and that changes.  They always take request so if someone in the group is interested in a certain kind of plant they will do their best to show it.

I always make it to the gardens and take a tour when I am in town,  when the garden was free I would make the trip several times looking forward to the different guides and what they will cover,.  Some stay to the main paved paths, some early walk on the main trails mostly following the smaller gardener trails.
 
The gardens are located in the same area of Golden gate park as the Japanese Gardens, the Academy of Science and the DeYoung art museum.
In all the gardens are a great place to wander and explore or as many residents do when the weather is nice, find  a lawn and catch some sun or a bench to read.
author: Mark B.

description: The fountains were beautiful and so were the flowers. The grass was green because all of the recent rain. We went to celebrate Easter with our friends and had a super fun Easter egg hunt which concerned a certain 6-year-old who was the son of my mom's best friend hogging the candy. We went to the pond at the entrance and saw turtles and what I believe was Koi fish. I strongly recommend going to the Botanical Gardens and if you like it, you should also check out the conservatory of flowers.
author: April P.

description: Beautiful layout. Weaves many diverse landscapes together into one condensed park. Zellerbach during Flower Piano makes for the perfect picnic spot.
author: Yad L.

description: Stop what you are doing! Really! If you live in San Francisco you cannot claim you are a real resident unless you have been to the Botanical Garden. Flash your SF ID and get in free. This place is a real treat..and I am raving because I have lived here for 10 years and had never been until today. I like the redwoods and dinosaur age sections. There's all sorts of plants and unique plant smells. This place should be more popular! It's heavenly.
author: Denise C.

description:
Came here on hopes for a romantic stroll with the hubby and crossed our fingers for a few stunning shots of nature'a natural beauty.

$7/person entry fee. Try to come with smaller bills because they had a hard time breaking our 50. Parking is absolutely horrendous and you will be certain to hear a whole lot of honking and maybe even some yelling. There are a number of touristy places to visit in the vicinity so we are all pretty much battling for parking along the sides of the road. Be cautious, there are a bunch of bicyclists and joggers roaming around. 
During this time of the year, I didn't see too many flowers in bloom, which was slightly a let down. Fortunately, The beautiful weather made up for all of that. Sun was shining bright, blue skies, and just the right amount of breeze.

The park is quite big. Since there wasn't too many flowers to take pictures of, we assume we would be in and out of the garden quickly. Boy were we wrong, time was ticking away and before we knew it, we had spent over 3 hours roaming around. 

Squirrels run rampant and free. They even get pretty close to you at times.  There is a pond where plenty of people laid out blankets and enjoyed lunch. Do be aware: stay on the designated paths. We took a picture up close next to one of the plants and were scolded for "killing" greenery.

I'm not sure if we'd come back. Dealing with the traffic and angry drivers on a weekday was no fun. I couldn't imagine how much crazier it would get on a weekend.
author: Ter L.

description:
We took an uber ride from the rental home were we were staying,  and when we arrived we discovered it was free only to San Francisco, California  residents. 
We ran into a very nice lady name Joyce , she heard about our experience and she picked up the tap.
Thanks Joyce for the kindness you gave...
Because the Botanical Garden manager was very nasty and not understanding. ..
author: Veronica R.

description: I'm not normally a garden person but my mom was visiting and she wanted to see it and I was pleasantly surprised. They did a great job with the grounds and liked the Ancient plant section! Would love to go back and just have a picnic on the grass.
author: Ranee W.

description:
I usually end up going with my friends to the botanical gardens when we're hanging out but low on $$$$.  the people at the entrance are friendly and really there to help!  whenever i forget to bring a proof of residence or my student ID, whoevers there is nice enough to let me off the hook.  (sf residents get in for free, but i think regular admissions is $5.)  

the only bad thing is that at the pond, the sad little turtles get pushed around by these big (cat?)fish.  and theres goose poop everywhere in that area.  oh well! 

on my first visit last year, i saw a hummingbird in its nest!  amazing.  
& if youre lucky you'll spot this little red lobster? crayfish? looking thing in the Japanese area.
author: Amanda J.

description:
Beautiful!! 

Located in the Golden Gate Park, the SF Botanical Gardens are simply breathtaking and worth visiting at least once. Plan on being here at least 1-2 hours to truly admire all that you can here -- you really forget that you're in the city. It's $7 for adults to get in, free for SF locals (with ID proof). 

I like how there are different sections for plants (ie: CA Local, Australia, New Zealand, etc). Lots of places to take pictures, benches to just chill, pretty lakes, fountains and cute animals running around. There are also some open grass spaces that I saw people eating/lying down/sun bathing/reading/etc on. This is a great place to get lost in for a couple of hours. 

Side note, there are also a few clean restrooms inside the garden as well as some water fountains. Good to know for being in the city!

Cheers!
author: Michelle M.

description:
I think the concept for the film, the Night at the Museum, works for most people. It's based on the story that a night watchman at NYC's American Museum of Natural History discovers that the exhibits, animated by a magical Egyptian artifact, comes to life at night. The adventures that arise are hilarious, as you can physically see a real live museum in action.

After watching the movie, if you want to visit a real living museum, then head to the San Francisco Botanical Garden located at Golden Gate Park. It offers 55 acres of both landscaped gardens and open spaces, showcasing over 8000 different kinds of plants from around the world. (http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org)

The reason that the garden is able to house these living plants is due to the Bay Area's mild temperatures, wet winters and dry summers, coupled with the coastal fog. It provides a range of climatic conditions that exist only in a few botanical gardens in the world. These unique conditions allow it to grow and conserve plants from all over the globe, including plants that are no longer found in their native habitats.

2015 marks the 75th anniversary that the garden has been opened to the public.
