I'm not really a big fan of places like this, but I have to admit that it's really chill, where visitors can experience nature and learn about plants and its environment. Kinda like an outdoor classroom. You can relax, while the kids run amuck. Best thing, it's open 365 days a year. I highly recommend checking out their extensive Magnolia collection.

You must be a SF resident to enjoy this place for FREE. Bring your driver's license and you're set. Non residents pay $7 like I did, so it's sort of your call as to whether you'll get your money's worth. There are discounts for Seniors and Children. All in all, not a bad experience, if you make the best of it.
author: Chris C.

description:
The Botanical Garden is pretty for like the first visit or two. After awhile it gets boring. Or maybe I'm just bitter because the first time I came here, it was free for my friend who was a San Francisco resident (only according to his ID) but I had to pay the $7 admission fee. Anyways, this is a popular peaceful destination for tourists.

You can walk around for a good few hours. There are lots to see, and the variety of plants is actually quite impressive. I would imagine most people wander around for the bonding experience rather than the actual gardens. Even when there are lots of people around, it never seems crowded with 55 acres of land.

As a tip for non-locals, there are free admission days on the second Tuesday of every month, as well as daily from 7:30am to 9:00am... also on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's. Definitely a must-see if you are ever in this city!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Breath taking are the two words that come to mind when describing this place.

Truly a wonderful delight to see nature at it's finest.

Just don't forget your allergy medicine!

They recently redid the landscape in some of the areas here to bring in new attractions. Such a great update! More flowers and trees from other different regions of the world.

There are a lot of different types of Mongolian trees with all sorts of different colored flowers which I thought, "wow" they're huge flowers and some have a unique smell to them.

This is a terrific place to spend the weekend with family. A great place to explore with friends too!

Happy adventure time!

Toodles~
author: Mae M.

description:
Beautiful! Golden Gate Park is always worth a visit and this place is definitely a sight to see. Lots of interesting flowers and plants everywhere from various parts of the world. How is it that they can all survive this specific kind of climate in California? I have no idea, but I'm glad they're all here in this garden.

I came here with a friend when it was still in "Magnificent Magnolia" season. During this short period of time, the magnolia flowers are in bloom and it's really quite a spectacle. There's various kinds of magnolias spread out in the garden and they all have different qualities (colors, aromas). I totally recommend planning a visit while they're in season!

The garden is huge and I can't imagine this place ever being too crowded. There's some hilly parts that might make you breathe a bit harder, but I think it's overall good for families, kids, everyone. Would love to come back here another weekend!
author: Karen T.

description: Easy to get to via public trans. Large open spaces, tighter more private spaces, a variety of beautiful gardens, a lake, a Moon Viewing pond, birds, butterflies, caterpillars, plentiful benches to sit on and soak up the beauty. Everything you need for an enjoyable afternoon except food. No problem at all. Less than a block away you can find food to suit every taste. Re-entry to the gardens is easy with your ticket. What a treat!
author: Teri L.

description:
An awesome part of Golden Gate Park. Came here for the Flower Piano series over the weekend (happening through 7/18), in which 12 pianos are located throughout the gardens. If you go to their website they have a schedule of all the professional performances going on, which are concentrated on the weekends. When there are no scheduled performances, anyone can play the pianos. 

Would highly recommend coming for the Flower Piano! The fog was really rolling in the Saturday afternoon we went, which made the gardens even more pretty. Beautiful setting for live music, picnicking, and just strolling around. Definitely worth the $8.
author: Connie C.

description:
Came here a few days after the first day of spring. Super tranquil, people setting up picnics, and tossing around frisbees and footballs. Kind of view it as paying $7 admission to get a more private park within Golden Gate park/ any park in the city + super amazing array of flowers and space to wander to your heart's content.  

Lovely landscape, and fun to wander around. Would recommend to check out at least once if you're in the area!
author: Tiffany S.

description: What a wonderful walk! We were there for hours wandering and hit just a fraction of the garden. Their pond has turtles! I will definitely be back to walk through other sections.
author: Mikhail H.

description:
What a beautiful area of Golden Gate Park. 

Gardens representing parts of the world, all in one place. And what's more, they happen to be hosting a Flower Piano event, in which they put 12 pianos in random areas of the garden for anyone to play in. Can't get anymore relaxing than that! 

$7 admission for the out-of-towners, free for SF residents. 
Man, it's places like this that make me wish I was able to live in the city.
author: Viet N.

description:
I am the first to admit I don't appreciate our city's botanical garden enough probably because it's not a showy display of flowers like the Butchart Gardens up near Victoria, British Columbia. Of course, that costs $32 to enter, while this lovely, 55-acre attraction is completely free to city residents who can show a driver's license with a local address ($7 for non-residents). So who's complaining? Not me. It's a calming place that Jamie W. and I visit when we feel like taking an easy stroll from the entry point to Golden Gate Park at 9th and Lincoln. Besides, it doesn't smell of old lady like some other gardens do.

We usually have to work off some of the calories from a satisfying meal we got at either Park Gyros, Park Chow or Marnee Thai. As you walk toward the very retro-looking County Fair building, I like the vertical sign that tells you all the things you can't do in the space (see photo). Once you enter the main gate, you see the Great Meadow, a wide expanse of manicured green dotted by majestic trees. Side paths take you to any of the four main gardens organized by climate, geography and plant type. There are at least two restful Japanese gardens which offer ponds, benches, Japanese maples and water irises.

There's also a succulent garden, a fragrance garden and a fascinating garden devoted to ancient plants. The wildfowl pond features all sorts of fowl, and we ran into a parade of geese who seemed unperturbed by the humans in their path to the water. The camellia garden is a particularly nice place to sit a spell and enjoy the colorful glories of nature while resting your derriere. There's a tiny garden bookstore at the entrance that's worth perusing and a rack of seeds for the more horticulturally inclined. This is well worth a stop on the way to many of the other attractions in the park (see the photo gallery).
author: Ed U.

description:
Before you read any other reviews, remember that this is a botanical garden.  It should receive fair comparisons with other botanical gardens, not comparisons to a movie or a concert or a day at the beach.  

Every great city should have a beautiful park, and every great park should have a botanical garden.   A botanical garden represents careful planning and design, a blend of science and art.  This is the beauty of a botanical garden.  And the SF Botanical Gardens are no exception.  This majestic SF landmark was first begun in the 19th century, and its caretaker, John Mclaren from Scotland, spent literally his lifetime planning out how to incorporate plants from around the world into a park that also spawned many of its own native California species.  By the time he passed at the age of 96, he had established one of the most beautiful botanical gardens in the country.  

Set against the rest of the Golden Gate Park, its easy to overlook this garden as much more of the same flora, but close attention to detail reveals much more.  Mclaren was able to recreate different flora from around the world, like a botanist's dream version of Epcott center at Disney World.  Various sections of the park are dedicated specifically to growing plants from South East Asia, Chile, South Africa, even Australia and New Zealand.   Everywhere you look, you will literally find one unique species after another, one after another, beautiful plant imported from far away, with neighbors from its own country, now making its new home here in SF.  There's also quite a bit of land dedicated to Californian species, including a small Redwood forest.  The dark gray stones, which line the the terrace and can be found interspersed throughout the garden, are actually old remnants from a 12th century Spanish monastery.  

As you explore the garden, your senses will be inundated with wonderful and brilliant colors, and rich, vibrant smells.  The garden even encourages visitors to not only smell, but also touch the plants as well!  Find a comfortable spot, and take some time to rest and relax.  Very likely you will notice plenty of wildlife around you, even on a winter's day I noticed a Canadian goose and several hummingbirds perusing the garden's foliage.  Children will delight in the ancient plant arboretum, which boasts species from the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods, as well as replicas of dinosaur footprints and even a few hidden topiary dinosaurs themselves! 

Whether you're a naturalist or a nature lover or just a naturally loving person, you'll enjoy a stroll through the botanical gardens.   Happy travels my friend!
author: Gino I.

description: Nice botanical garden located in Golden Gate Park is both pretty and relaxing to come visit and they have a great variety of trees and flowers.  It's only $7 admission so you should check it out.
author: Anthony G.

description: This was really fun! I had never been here before but loved getting to walk through all the different countries.
author: Katrina S.

description: This is a beautiful Botanical Garden. Great for a quick visit or a long walk. If you came from the busy California Academy of Sciences, this is a nice way to unwind.
author: Oliver A.

description: Huge gardens, with too much to walk and foliage that was basically planted and left to itself. Mile markers are too far and in between to really figure out where you are. For your money just explore golden gate park.
author: Teresa B.

description: They have a few complimentary days of the year, New Year's Day is one of them. Unfortunately the directions didn't quite get get us to the front entrance and not being from the city it was hard to find. Parking was terrible but most of it it in the city. It said it was about 55 acres. I was a little unhappy going in the middle of winter since most of the flowers were not in bloom but there were some that were. I have been to another smaller garden and I felt it had just as much to offer as this larger one. The place was beautiful either way and if I had another opportunity to go in another season I probably would.
author: Crystal P.

description: Beautiful spot! There is an admission fee to get in if you're not a SF resident, but it's not much (around $10 I believe?) and it was a really gorgeous walk -- we especially loved the succulent garden!
author: Justine J.

description:
I didn't know such beauty existed in my own backyard. Living in SOMA, I'm surrounded by high rises, busy streets, and the hustle bustle of everyday city life. 

However coming here to Botanical Gardens at Golden Gate Park, I immediately felt rejuvenated. 

Walking through the garden, my senses were drawn in as I viewed brightly colored magnolias. I stood in awe of magnificent trees harvested from South and Central America. The vibrant lush greenery that surrounded me melted away all worries. The air was perfumed with delicately scented flowers and I couldn't help but breathe in as deep as I could just to savor it a little longer.

As I explored a little deeper, I walked endless trails leading into small pockets of hidden surprises. I walked upon a wooden deck and could imagine how romantic it would be for a couple. I came across a shaded bench and could've sat there forever admiring such an ethereal setting. 

One of my favorite parts was visiting the plant nursery. Curiously shaped succulents and peculiar green potted plants were lovingly placed alongside each other. The Orostachys Iwarenge is so beautiful that I even wanted one for myself.

Alas, I have found my own little Garden of Eden. 

I truly had an amazing time. I look forward to returning!
author: Ann S.

description:
Grab your California ID (it gets you in for free)...

and get your favorite people together.

Remember to remind them to bring their California IDs...

and then make your way to San Francisco Botanical Garden.

Unlike Golden Gate Park and other parks - you're encouraged to pack light. No big coolers or grills. No big boom boxes or radios. No loud voices or cigarette smoking.

Instead - bring jars of nourishing food. Bring your soft blankets. Bring your flasks of warm tea. Bring your hula-hoop. Bring your healing essential oils. Bring your book. Bring your self.  Bring your whole self...

To San Francisco Botanical Garden.

Plan a perfect picnic in one of the most epic and what's up spots in the city.

Just don't forget your California ID.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
This place is huge! It was much bigger than I thought. I like all the different paths and because it was an over

I had to pay $7 to get in for adults. Free for San Francisco residents with government id (driver license, passport, etc)

It's a great place to have a picnic on the parts you can go on if you like. Just clean up after yourself please!!
author: Corie L.

description: We've been here a lot of times for walking and just enjoying the plants. This is one of our favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Ruby F.

description:
Lovely. So lovely. I just love being able to walk around and be encouraged to smell the flowers. We spent 3 hours here doing just that. It was a very quiet weekday so we pretty had the whole
place to ourselves. You San Franciscans are so lucky to be able to do this pretty much anytime you want (I believe it's free with an id with a SF address). However, I felt the fee was worth it for the beautiful scenery. I am from Las Vegas so I am perfectly ok paying for a chance to few such beautiful botanicals. We didn't do this but the front office told us we could come back anytime that day as long as we had our receipt.
author: Terry B.

description: Wow. The Botanical Garden even has wifi for guests. Color me impressed.
author: Bourbon S.

description:
This is a great place for a date or for a really nice walk with friends (or solo! nothing wrong with that!).

This place is pretty huge! I loveee the lake section. There's a bench where you can just sit and watch the water with all of its ducks and turtles! There is also a part of the Moon Viewing Garden that looks MAGICAL. 

The "Wow" factor of your experience definitely depends on whether it is the optimal season. Regardless, this place is so large that there is bound to be a section that will tickle your fancy. The entrance fee of $7 for non-SF Residents is beyond reasonable, but if you are a SF resident, be sure to bring a utility bill or proof of residence so you can get in for free!
author: Shasta L.

description:
A beautiful and unexpected oasis in the middle of the busy city.  Lots of different types of botanical to explore and aw at.  Very picturesque, with lots of beautiful photo ops.  I absolutely adored the Garden of Fragrance- had a fun time trying to identify all the herbs you can cook with! 

SF residents get in for free (with proof of valid ID w/ SF address!)  Great first date spot.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
Winter is over the red leaves that kiss us,
The hour of love comes and goes,
Let us part, as the season of passion forgets about us,
With tears that are left in the Redwood Grove.
author: May Y.

description: I forgot how big this place is I haven't been here since the age of 25. good news if you are a resident of San Francisco you get in free if your not its $7 a spacious area where you could sit down just read a bOok lay on the huge field that's like as big is a football field.and just walk around and enjoy the weather and have lunch just chill.
author: Lizzie G.

description:
The botanical garden was a very peaceful place to go visit.  The botanical garden has a lot of different varieties of different plants from different countries, states and continents.  The day we visited we saw a crane we think in the bamboo forest the same day.  I misled my family the wrong way - my nephew was leading the right way and I made a mistake.  We were there for three hours but at the time we left everyone said we all had fun.

*submitted by me and my nine year old nephew
author: Ernest S.

description:
There are times in which I feel like I can't get enough of San Francisco and places like this are one of the many reasons why I really like this city. During Christmas Day, we were bored and were unsure what to do since a lot of places were closed. It turned out that the admission was free during Christmas Day for non-residents of this amazing city, so we went here late in the morning and stayed around here until the late afternoon.

This place is definitely one of the most wonderful parts of the Golden Gate Park. My favorite areas are probably the Great Meadow and the Waterfowl Pond. The grass of the meadow felt good on my feet, and was nice to sit down, and lie down to take a look at the clear sky. The Waterfowl Pond is a nice place to look at some birds, and I really liked the hilly terrain nearby where you can get some decent views of the gardens while doing a little hill climbing. I don't have much to say about the other parts of this place, but pretty much the plants are all nice to look at, and it felt great to get another fresher smell. 

Overall, if you are looking for a nice place to walk around on Christmas Day in San Francisco, this place is a really good choice. I thought I had one of the best Christmas Days and just going on a simple stroll around this place made that day wonderful. I would not mind coming back here again just to relax on the Great Meadow.
author: Ambrose C.

description:
I had a chance to visit the SF Botanical Garden in January, and I loved it.

I know what you're thinking -- January isn't exactly the best time of year to visit a botanical garden. But trust me, there was still a lot to see and it was definitely worth the trip!

Even when most of the flowers weren't in bloom, the gardens are still beautifully maintained and the plants are lush and healthy. I really enjoyed the couple of hours we spent strolling through the different sections: Australia, Asian, Smell & Touch ... it was a perfect day for a scenic walk. The grassy lawn with its huge trees was breathtaking. And we actually arrived just in time to see the first of the magnolia blooms! 

One of these days I'll have to go back in the summer. It must be lovely!
author: JoAnna D.

description:
Worth It, Even if You Have to Pay for It!

The weather was overcast, a little chilly, and looked like it would start raining at any minute.  That, however, did not deter us.  We broke out the rain gear, and spent a couple hours exploring one of the finest parts of San Francisco.  Even though it was January and many things were not blooming, it is was still a wonderful visit.  There is so much to see, it is easy to imagine spending an entire morning or afternoon here.

Hint:  if you go before 9:00 am, it's free!  So, get up early and go!  You won't regret it!
author: Ted Q.

description: My favorite spot in the city! Free for locals and well worth the price of admission for out of towners.
author: Scott S.

description:
The Botanical Garden is one of San Francisco's prize gems. 
If you are not a plant enthusiast, you will still love the beauty of this lush and peaceful place.
If you are a gardener, your mind will explode in this garden of Eden which is replete with exotic plants from around the world.  
They have periodic plant sales where you can buy choice plants that are not available any where else in the Bay Area.
author: Izzy B.

description:
So beautiful!! If you love nature, gardens, or just a peaceful and beautiful place to walk around you have to visit here!! One of the most stunning places I've been to in SF. I went to check it out on a Tuesday, and it wasn't too crowded at all. I brought my camera with me and was able to get some great macro shots. There's so much to see here, all SO beautiful. I loved everything about it! It's free if you get there before 9am. 
It took me about two hours to see almost everything, this place is huge. I didn't even make it around the whole park in that time so I'll be back!
author: Brigette A.

description: I don't think any normal people have given less than a 4 star rating, which tells you something.  This is a world-class botanical garden.  Plan on spending 2+ hours strolling through all the sections, then grab a bite to eat across the street on 9th Avenue. The Conservatory of Flowers is a mile away and worth checking out too.
author: J H.

description:
Right next to the Japanese Tea Garden! 

It's not as big and intimidating as you'd think. You can probably walk through it leisurely under 2 hours, and then head over to the gift shop to buy some seeds or vintage postcards.
author: Elsie W.

description:
Wow! This place is amazing!!!
You really cannot tell what's in store here from walking outside...you're literally transferred to another world once you pass the entrance. 

There is SOOO much to see here.  It's impossible to even walk the whole grounds in a day.  

It's free for SF residents and free for everyone if you come super early!

I did a docent tour and was absolutely burned out by the end of it that I had to leave early.   I would do another one next time, but I think the tour lasted for almost 3 hours. I had visited the Japanese Gardens right before, and had no energy left. 

Those who plan on coming should just plan on making this their one and only stop.  There's enough to fulfill you. 

The girl at the Friendship entrance was really pissy...
I know these are probably students just making minimum wage and trying to make ends meet, but the attitude almost staled the experience.  I almost walked way and skip this totally.  
Seriously, if they are so miserable with their jobs, I would gladly prefer to have one of the senior docents working there instead.  It's a rough economy, appreciate the jobs you have....
author: David W.

description: I totally appreciate the SF Botanical Garden as sometimes it is tough to feel zen in a city such as San Francisco, especially living near downtown where there are only small patches of green.  Sometimes we need to see some nature, some trees, flowers, greenery from all over from California to Southeast Asia to Australia to South America and Mexico - love it!  The variety of plants from succulents to perrenials to redwoods - just lovely!  You can either stay on the main path and see an outline of greenery or you can dive into the various smaller paths that take you deeper into the greenery and detail of each region featured.  Love it!  And I absolutely love most of all that this garden is free to all San Francisco residents - just show your ID at the entrance and you are good to go!  Bring a picnic lunch or a blanket and book and enjoy some sun!
author: Maile N.

description:
The gardens are very beautiful and I always get a very nice feeling of serenity here. There are numerous plants from all over the world and it's very fun being able to stroll through all of the different continents. 

There are also many different events that take place here so keep an eye out for those. My favorite thus far has been the flower piano (where 12 different pianos were placed around the garden for the public to play).
author: Manogi M.

description: Love it, so peaceful & beautiful.  Great diversity of different styles of gardens, botanicals & trees.
author: KC G.

description: They have so many different plants! This garden is definitely large and I wish I was able to come here during the spring when all the flowers are blooming. There are lots of sections with different plants and you'll take a good hour or more to walk around the entire garden.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I love botanical gardens.  If there is a botanical garden in a place I am visiting, I will go there.  So when I realized that this botanical garden had free admission at silly o'clock in the morning (or, you know, 7:30) and that my jetlagged self would totally be awake well before silly o'clock, this visit was a no-brainer.

And seriously, holy crap, this place is worth a visit at twice the regular price, let alone for free!  It is huge, it is gorgeous, and I want it as my backyard.

We weren't sure how much time we'd want to spend when we got there, so we asked the lady at the gate to point us toward the best areas.  She circled about half of the various gardens, but really she could have circled them all.  Even the ones that weren't really in bloom were interesting to see, and we ended up just wandering through everything at least once.

My favorite gardens:

1) Succulent Garden.  It is not possible to go wrong with succulents, and these were absolutely amazing.  Super colorful, super pokey, and with a neat winding path up the side of a hill.

2) Redwood Grove.  My first experience with redwoods but hopefully not my last!  It was amazing to see these tall trees first from afar from the entrance gate and then up close and personal in the grove.  And then to find out that they are basically babies compared to their giant cousins? Insane.

3) Garden of Fragrance.  Just... wow.  We must have looked a little deranged, stopping every two feet to shove our heads into a new flower, but it was super fun.  Not all of the flowers were strongly smelly when we were there, but we definitely got whiffs of some great new scents, including the interesting mixes of scents from afar.  A definite must-see!

Is it weird that I kind of want to visit San Francisco again just to go to this garden? Probably, but I will happily own that weirdness.
author: Alison M.

description:
One of my favorite places in San Francisco. 

San Francisco residents get in free but you must bring proof of residency - driver's license, check, utility bill, etc. What a deal - the botanical gardens are huge and are split up into different regions of the world. It's really beautiful to look at the different types of plants that thrive in different climates around the world.

There are so many areas to explore - there are small streams, small paths off the main paths, little nooks where you can take a rest on a bench. There are also lots of large, grassy areas for you to put out a blanket and relax. I once saw someone holding a birthday party at one of the few picnic tables - not sure if a reservation is required but if not, probably not a great idea since there are so few of them.

My favorite spot is in the Redwood Grove in the California section of the gardens - the most majestic trees. The area tends to be quiet and very still, and there's even a small "amphitheater" area where you can take a quick rest. The tall, majestic Redwoods feel like they are protecting you.
author: Wendy L.

description:
SQUIRREL!  

Where?  

Oh wait....SQUIRREL!!!!  

Beware, lots and lots of cute adorable little squirrels running a mock everywhere inside this botanical garden!  I had a lot of fun trying to capture the best shot of these squirrels running up and down the trees and across the sidewalks.  I would have to say that the squirrels were the biggest highlight of my tour around the garden.  

Under $10 per person for admission.  Maybe it's because I went in the middle of April but I couldn't find too many pretty flowers blooming.  I'm not much of a plant or cactus person.  The whole experience was A OK and I don't see myself returning here for another future visit.  

Parking is non existent but we were lucky to find a metered parking lot that had a car pulling out.
author: Christy L.

description: I just loved this place! You could spend hours here just walking around to all the areas and enjoying the nature. There are little off path trails that are especially nice to walk on and you really feel as if you are within that area (Asia, Afria, South America etc.) of the world. Great place to visit and even have a picnic!
author: Rashmi P.

description: Lots and lots of plants which is great! Great stroll through the garden and love the paths :D takes between 30-45mins to walk through most of the garden
author: Luis O.

description:
Super awesome beautiful flowers and plants abound this portion of Golden Gate Park. Grab a picnic basket or a Lunchable (yes, a Lunchable) and enjoy the flowering plants around you. You could seriously spend half a day here meandering about. 

Check this place out if you're trying to avoid the tourists.
author: Justin C.

description:
There are 23 distinct gardens in this 55 acre urban paradise. It's a wonderful place to visit at anytime of the year. 

I'm not sure if I could say which gardens are the best some are a bit tattered and some are not. I really like them all. If U  forced to choose just two, I would say the succulent garden and the fragrance garden are my favorite places to sit and enjoy this park.

Admission is free on the 2nd Tuesday of every month. It also free on Thanksgiving Christmas day and New Years Day

The squirrels are cute and very  aggressive and will follow you around whenever you visit.
author: Terry T.

description: A gem in the city. Free for SF residents. Spacious, beautiful, and never too crowded. Bring a book, friends and a picnic, and/or your toddler and just relax. It's lovely.
author: Sherene C.

description:
This place is magical and free! Is there anything better than that.  

If you have an id or bill that has your address in SF then you my friend can relax for hours or just wander through different climates at will for FREE. It's $7 if you are not a resident and frankly if you like to learn about the flora of a temperate rainforest or one of the other climates and you go on a docent tour it's worth that.

I don't bother with that I prefer to just wander around and find one of the many many benches. They are constantly adding new sitting spots and views and there is always lots of nice little vistas and views.

Today I talked to some of the volunteers tending to a hill top seating area, took pictures for a Japanese tourist and got to sit surrounded by the lush nature with seeing another person nor hearing a car for 1/2 hour. Can it get much better than that.

Also check out the Helen Crocker Russell Library of Horticulture which is before the entrance to the Garden. They have free open wi-fi, a 60's building and they sell for very cheap used Horticulture books that are donated to them.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Nice selection of plants to peruse, pretty butterfly room and a fair price. Bring your camera.
author: Travis S.

description:
As a visual person, I love art museums. I am also a tactile person which tends to be frowned upon in museums. If you ever see me in an art museum, you'll notice my hands are clasped behind my back. I do it to prevent scenes such as the following: 

"Ma'am, please step away from the Van Gogh."
"But, but, but it's so textured. It's taunting me to touch it. I'm touching it in the name of science; I need to empirically test the rumor that some of his works are still wet. You can't stop me!"
"Security, we need assistance in the Van Gogh wing. Bring gloves. [pause] And finger paints."

Lucky for me, the Botanical Garden has a section called the Garden of Fragrance where you are encouraged to smell AND touch the plants. Bliss. I plunged my nose and hands in every plant, bush, tree, and flower with glee.

Favorite touch: aloe plant. 
Favorite smell: pineapple sage.  (Or whatever is by the plant labeled as such.)
Which is yours?

I absolutely love herbs and was tempted to sneak a leaf or bush out. Sigh, that behavior is likely frowned upon as well so I did not. Darn my sociable ways. The other collections are nice as well. You can journey through prehistoric times, Australia, New Zealand, Central and South America, South Africa, Asia, and California. Keep your hands to yourself or hold hands with a date like many people I saw. 

Best of all, this is free for San Francisco residents, woo hoo! Show either your driver's license with an SF address, or a form of ID plus utility bill to prove your residency. Otherwise, entrance fee is $7. Highly recommended for anyone with a flower fixation.  Five years ago, I found all gardens to be mind-numbingly boring. Today I am too busy molesting, I mean, admiring flowers to be bored. 

Enjoy!
author: Yan E.

description: Amazing experience for my family of 4. My two young boys enjoyed the Redwoods, bamboo forest, and pond with ducks, turtles, and coy fish the most. And my 8-month pregnant wife did fine with the small hills. A ton of good options across the street for lunch.
author: Shaun O.

description:
There's no such thing as a bad garden to visit, especially in the midst of a large city like San Francisco.  The SF Botanical Gardens is a wonderful escape from the bustle of the city (except for parking which can be challenging on weekends).  The park is devided into numerous different climates like South Africa, Australia, redwoods, suculant garden and more, each with their own beauty that changes throughout the year.  Take a stroll, find a bench, slow down and take in the vibrant beauty, incredible diversity,  and the magificant creativity of nature on display at.  

Sometimes in the summer the fog hangs over this section of Golden Gate Park so bring a jacket or dress in layers or you'll have a short visit.
author: David L.

description:
This place is so pretty! I came here with my boyfriend on Friday at 7:30am, so we had free admission and the lady at the front desk was super friendly. This place had so much to see, but my favorite had to be the bridge with turtles and catfish (maybe..?) And the fragrance garden! My boyfriend and I were really surprised we could actually smell things ahah! 

Many people were also taking a stroll or just exercising and if I lived in San Francisco, I'd probably be going for a run there when I have time as well.
author: Doris H.

description:
Right across the Japanese Tea Garden, and much, much better.  It doesn't have the Japanese theme, but it does have peaceful trails and plenty of empty benches where you can sit down and just stare at natural marvels from all over the world from California to New Zealand.  I saw people just sitting inside reading or sleeping on benches (If it helps, I went there at around 3pm on a Tuesday afternoon).  The park quite small compared to, say, the NY Botanic Gardens, but the flowers are mostly alive and beautiful in August, unlike in NYC (probably due to the more moderate summer weather).  The employees at the ticketing booths are also quite friendly (they apparently ask all non-residents where they are coming from).

Admission was $8 for non-residents, and I was able to leisurely stroll through the park and take pictures in about 2 hours.

The bathrooms are pretty awful, but that is to be expected.
author: Sean C.

description:
One of San Francisco's treasures.

It is a must that you visit even if your a local.

The garden is just so beautiful and you want to stay all day admiring all the variations of flowers, etc.
author: Rogelio V.

description: I love, love, love this arboretum/botanical garden - trees and flowers from around the world including redwoods, birds including blue and green herons, California quail, and hummingbirds, ponds, paths, benches, yes, yes, yes, and so much more! It is so beautiful, so inviting, so diverse, so interesting, so relaxing, so San Francisco!
author: Veg V.

description: I come here all the time as a San Francisco native. I love it so much and I'm so glad we have a place like this. I recently brought my boyfriend (who plays jazz music and studies evolution) to the gardens, when the pianos were there. We ended up in the ancient plants garden, him playing the piano and talking about ancient plants as he did.
author: Jasper-Mikhael R.

description:
Wow what's not to like?  Beautiful plants, trees, flowers, pathways, lakes, ponds....I could go on and on.  So much to see, well worth the $7 to get in.  Way bigger than we thought it would be.  As you continue further in, the different paths, steps, stairs and trails take you to some very quiet and serene areas.  There are benches and places to sit everywhere to take it all in. So relaxing  The kids were into it, even the older ones (ages 15 and 21!) 
Will definitely bring a blanket and snacks next time.
Go and enjoy.
author: Julianna H.

description: Great place to see some of the most beautiful trees you will ever see in your life! Take tons of pictures and enjoy the tour. This is something you must put on your bucket list whenever you visit San Fran.
author: Chelsea R.

description: I guess I'm a bit spoiled living so close to Huntington park botanical garden in LA area.. But this was a gorgeous pit stop while being in San Fran. The lady at the ticket booth was super friendly, she gave us some quick tips to see the most in the time we had before they closed.. My favorite part of this one is the winding in and out mini trails it has from the main rode through each "exhibit" because you can easily get into your own space off the main path and find an empty bench to just soak it all in.. Also the redwoods exhibit was cool.. Love those.. But I felt like areas of the sections start getting lost in what looks like where they're still growing or fixing? We ended up finding the area where they keep all the potted plants (probably bought at Home Depot?) kinda made me bummed..
author: Heather A.

description:
I spent many an afternoon here as a child when my mom had a business in San Francisco. My mom would get fed up with having us around, so she'd send me and my sister out to Golden Gate Park with my dad to work off some energy. I used to love following all the little paths through the various geographic regions represented. We would take turns being the leader in deciding the path and play follow the leader as we meandered all over the place.

But I stopped by yesterday and discovered that they now charge admission! It's $7 for regular admission. It used to be free! Oh well, I think it's a sign of the times. I think it's still well worth the price of admission, but make sure to get your money's worth by spending at least a few hours here enjoying the absolutely beautiful flowers and plants.
author: Leslie H.

description: Wow.  Wow wow wow.  They have packed an AMAZING number of plants and habitats into a relatively small area.  This is one of the best botanical gardens I've ever visited.  Granted I am no connoisseur of gardens but this is stunning.  The Flower Piano exhibit this July (and last July also) is one of the most amazing art installations I've ever seen.
author: Rosy P.

description:
Open, green spaces? Tall trees? Flowers in bloom? The opportunity to visit New Zealand without leaving SF? YES PLEASE!

Golden Gate Park is a great place to spend the day when the sun is shining. While people complain about the $7 fee, you're supporting the park (so hush up and suck it up). Anyway, only the tourists (or residents with out-of-state licenses, shhh) have to pay a fee, so if you live here it's like being in your own backyard. A well-manicured yard filled with lakes and redwoods.

We spent a few hours here and could've stayed the day. I was amazed that it wasn't more crowded - there were only a few people in each part of the park, and we had the run of the place. I love that it is divided up into flora from different countries - walking through Australia was true to form (having lived there for a while), and we got to meander through a Meso-American Cloud Forest. The duck pond is a lovely place to sit; we watched a crane glide gracefully to the water's edge while turtles, geese and ducks swam in lazy circles. 

My favorite section is called the "Garden of Fragrance," and it is true to its name. There is an entire section of rhododendrons that will rock your world. My friend and I got light-headed from huffing the fragrance - we just could not get enough. Unlike most parks, there's even a sign that says, "Please touch and smell the plants!" which is just wonderful. We sprawled out on the benches within sniffing distance of the flowers, and tried to figure out a way to Occupy the Garden.
author: Ray J.

description: I can't believe this garden exists in the city; a beautiful place to escape to for a few hours. Plus, if you can prove you are a resident of San Francisco, admission is free! You can also bring in food and have a wonderful bag lunch on one of the dozens of benches- some hidden inside pockets of different landscapes within the park. There are different themes and eras you can enjoy throughout the whole park- my favorites were the Redwood Grove and the Succulents. The park is separated in different regions and countries and you can walk for hours and see so many new plants and flowers you've never seen before. The details and signs next to each plant are so helpful and I could walk for hours and hours in here- and do it all over again. 5 stars.
author: Grace L.

description:
Highly recommended for both locals and tourists alike. Especially considering that SF-residents get in free. Lucky ducks. They have massive fields of grass which are perfect for reading on Sunday afternoons--the good life. Adults are $7, they take card, no Student discounts.

They have short (and free) docent-guided tours which start at 2pm. It was a very brief 30-45 minute walk-around some of their most popular areas. They pride themselves on their Redwoods and Magnolias here. Personally, I've never seen such trees coming from the desert so they were pretty remarkable. Nature, dude. My docent, I believe was named Julie. She was a sweet old lady who could share some interesting facts about the place.

Stop by for some plant-watching!
author: Yuhi K.

description: I absolutely love coming to the SF Botanical Gardens to enjoy the nature, the flowers, plants, the wild animals, & all of the beautiful hortculture. I love the fountains & ponds. This is, a lovely place to browse for hours. The SF Botanical Gardens also offers free admission to SF Residents which is brilliant. The Gardens are tranquil, calm, and absolutely fascinating - year round, in all of the Seasons. I have lots od favourite spits and places but there is something for everyone and having these beautiful gardens in San Francisco does make me proud to live here!
author: Julian I.

description: The SF Botanical Gardens are spectacular, a true oasis in the city. The moderate climate allows various other geographic areas botany. The person at the front gate was incredible as well as she pointed out the area where the blooms were best. If you're in the city and looking for an escape from the grind stop by.
author: Randall H.

description:
One of the most amazing, tranquil and beautiful places to visit in San Francisco! 
Botanical Gardens can very well eat up a lot of your time, which may lead you to revisiting Golden Gate Park on another day.
This place is for all bird, flower and animal lovers alike.
Not only is it a place to walk all the different paths and sections to see all the flowers in bloom, it's a place where you can watch all sorts of wildlife.

Their are ponds to see turtles and ducks swimming, squirrels will stand near you or even follow you as you walk. There has even been fish jumping out of the water.
If your patient enough, you may even see a hummingbird or two.

Along all the major paths, there is even smaller paths and small areas to explore.
It's definitely worth it to explore all areas. Never stay on the main paths.
Rain or shine it's always a great day at the Botanical Gardens.

Photographers and painters can take full advantage of this garden.

 This place is not to be missed!
author: John S.

description: Amazing place to take a peaceful walk and find all kinds of foreign plants from all over the world! Reasonably priced to get in and free admission if your a SF resident and show ID.
author: Clark P.

description:
I try and hit the botanical gardens in every city I visit and I was happy to finally make it here this weekend after a few trips out here without. Worth the wait! It's a gorgeous and massive park that, like most botanical gardens, is sectioned off into different regions. Succulent gardens with delicious smelling cacti (seriously, give them a sniff), redwoods, the New Zealand Christmas tree, an Asian garden, all beautiful and all impressive. Plus so so much more!

They boast one of the best magnolia collections in the country and luckily we came at the right time as they were all in bloom. Unluckily it had been raining all week so most of the delicate petals found themselves on the ground. Sad face. But there were still  enough left on the branches to sniff and photograph. We just didn't the full experience. Lots of wildlife that got me very excited. Photographed some snails, saw a number of humming birds, and my oh my are the squirrels here brave! They will come right up to you and eat out of your hand if you let them (which I would recommend you do not, as there are plenty of "do not feed the wildlife signs around. Also you could lose a finger!). But they make for fantastic photographs.

Free for SF residents but a mere $7 for other folks ($5 for students if you have an ID) makes a cheap and lovely experience that you could easily spend the whole day exploring. I highly recommend!
author: Annette J.

description:
Amazing escape in the city. I'm a birder - and the birds are amazing here. It's the only place left in San Francisco where you can see the California quail in it's natural habitat :) Also, lots of hummingbirds. August is a great time to go if you want to see the juvenile hummingbirds. 

Oh, the flowers and landscapes are beautiful. Just beware the Canadian geese poop!
author: Sarah S.

description: Love it! Free for SF residents, $7 for non-residents. There's really a lot to see and it's a really nice place to walk around for a few hours. My boyfriend and I made the mistake of staking out a place under the cherry blossom tree and probably photobombed everyone taking pictures of the tree in bloom.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Fantastic place in SF to go. Feed the ducks and squirrels. Many spots inside for a good picnic. Need a place to just walk and relax come here. For plant and flower lovers there is lots of interesting ones. Sometimes you can see an artist set up and start painting something amazing. And yes there are bathrooms inside here. 2 walk in entrances and usually lots of parking except on the weekends. 

This place used to be free for everyone. Now it cost $7 for non residents.
If you live in SF with and SF address on your ID or have a utility bill if you just moved here its free.
author: T C.

description: Great spot for a 1st or 2nd date. The Botanical Gardens are pretty cheap to get into and offer beautiful views. Admission is cheap and Golden Gate park is right there as well. Parking can be a little dicey but there's a cheap lot nearby, just google it ahead of time.
author: Emyli V.

description:
It is my tradition to enjoy a relaxing long walk in this park, every time I visit San Francisco. I always discover a new plant or beautiful scene. It gets my mind right, and ensures I can focus for the week to come. 

Parking can be a challenge on weekends so arrive before noon if possible...
author: Dave W.

description: Love this place, it is a must see.  Take some snacks and water and wonder around all of the amazing different areas and soak in the plant diversity.  I am not a huge plant nerd and can barely spot the difference between a Tulip and a Blue Bonnet but still enjoyed all of the different scents and beautiful layouts of the various displays.  Absolutely wonderful way to spend an afternoon and get your walk on.
author: Heather D.

description: Wonderful SF treasure. ....all residents should take advantage of this green space. Give yourself away least an hour.
author: Sharine d.

description: Beautiful flowers and trees everywhere. Good date spot! It was almost like walking into a forest. Capture lots of pictures! Free admission when you're an SF resident!
author: Majell D.

description:
Botany 101 was a course requirement for college that was a total waste of my time. 

My professor brought in a different plant every week for show and tell. We got to know each specific plant well, down to the little details like scientific names and interesting facts.

It's not surprising that the only plant I remember up until this day is Theobroma cacao -- the scientific name for chocolate.

Go figure. 

SF Botanical Garden is a splendid oasis.  Plant life  from all over the world (China, Australia, Chile, etc) can be found here.  Flowering trees, shrubbery and  theme gardens (check out the Redwood trees in the California garden).   You'll also see squirrels scurrying about and these lil guys are not afraid to come up to you.  There are park benches scattered throughout, some cleverly hidden amongst trees, which are great for some quiet time. 

There's ongoing construction near the pond (feed the ducks!) which is an eyesore. 

If you're curious about the Triassic period and such,  when you walk in the entrance (from 9th ave and Lincoln) turn left and you'll find yourself at the Ancient Garden. Walk on the wooden pathway and see plants from ancient times, as in from the dinosaur era!  FYI: the plants in these section have GPS imbedded in them. Really! the sign says so. 

For you aspiring botanists out there or serious plant lovers, this is a must-visit.  There's a docent led tour everyday at 1:30pm. The best part?  it's FREE.
author: Janice C.

description: Beautiful area with lots different regions covered in the landscaping. Local, Chile, Australia etc. The Japanese tea garden was much more impressive to me across the street even though it is much smaller (2 acres maybe vs. 55 acres)
author: Chad W.

description:
This one of the most relaxing and beautiful places I've been to. Its like a grand park filled with beautiful, unique flowers, plants, and trees from around the world. It was really fun exploring this place with my boyfriend and also quite romantic. 
I loved how SF residents would just come here to relax, have a picnic, or enjoy a good read. I'm super jealous!
My boyfriend and I explored the entire garden, and it was so big that we had to rest our feet quite a few times. But no worries, it was really great sitting down, relaxing, and enjoying each others' companies in the midst of this beautiful garden. 
Its $7 for general admission but its free for SF residents (so jealous). Its also located in the Golden Gate Park. We came on a sunday afternoon and there were so many people trying to get in! We barely found parking (near the California Academy of Science).
Would love to come back here for a picnic next time!
author: Heidi L.

description: This one is also $7 per adult for the tourists. Huge area to wander around and explore. We especially liked the "Moon Viewing" Field...It was a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of the city.
author: Mike F.

description: After the insane weeks I usually have, my girlfriend and I decided to spend a relaxing afternoon in the gardens. It was just what we needed , beautiful and it did the trick Even though it wasn't my idea to come here I am glad we did.
author: Christopher E.

description:
A must see.

There are a wide variety of plants from around the world; the space seems to be organized by geography. That said, the temperature, scents and flowers are so different that it pays to take your time and relax on a bench and meditate. Every time I visit this place, I find a new favorite area or new scent- it changes with the season.

Tip: if you have a close up lens on your camera; you are golden =)

Free to residents.

$7 non residents.

Tip: near the entrance is a tiny bookstore packed with interesting reads.

Tip: on a hot day, bring some refreshment or light snacks.

Tip: just south of the park, about a ten minute walk is Inner Sunset, a charming neighborhood of varied casual restaurants.
author: Bert K.

description:
I've been to many botanical gardens around the world and San Francisco's is lovely, though there is definitely room for improvement.

The garden features trees, flowers, shrubs and other plants from every corner of the planet in a big, beautiful space that feels like a world away from the hustle and bustle of the city. There are many parts of the garden but my favorite are the Redwood Grove (redwoods/sequoias are my favorite trees and this grove is so shady and serene), the Succulent Garden and the Garden of Fragrance. Not surprisingly, the Garden's Asian section is quite small and unremarkable (what would be the use of competing with the ever-popular Japanese Tea Garden next door?)

Where I think the garden could be improved is in the layout. Many times, signs will indicate that certain gardens are coming up but there are so many divergent, winding paths that it's difficult to figure out where exactly the gardens are. For example, the Succulent Garden is high above the main paths and it would be easy to miss it unless you followed one of the smaller paths up to the end. Yet, the sign makes it seem as if the garden is right there when it's clearly not. I think arrows or more detailed signs would really help people find what they're looking for, as most of the actual plant collections are not visible from the main, paved paths.

Admission is free at all times for San Francisco residents (yay!) so if you live in the city, definitely set aside a couple of hours to explore this haven of nature.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Free the second Tuesday of the month or everyday for SF residents (with proof of residency.) 

We used to linger here with out of town guests but since the fee, we don't come as often. It's typically a matter of not having as much time to spend there to make it worthwhile. 

Beautiful for lingering walks, pictures, or a quiet place to read. I particularly love the redwood grove and the bamboo.

If you're lucky, the Twirl and Dip truck is parked nearby (you have to check their website for the schedule) and you can enhance your visit with a chocolate dipped cone sprinkled with sea salt.
author: Loli L.

description:
What a wonderful gem this is! And all this time, hidden from me in plain sight in Golden Gate Park!

You could literally spend a whole day...just plan ahead of time and do it! Take a picnic with you and take your time. There's so much to see, smell, touch. I love how it's divided up, and surprises await just around the bend.

For instance: the Redwood Grove! I've been up to the Redwoods in Northern California many many times, and the experience was perfectly recreated in this little grove. I sat on a bench and was transported instantly. It was amazing and lovely.

And the Succulent Garden! I want one of my own...that's how inspiring it was!

I could go on and on, but really it must be experienced with your own senses!
author: Greg S.

description: Came here with my mother over the weekend and had a lovely time.  The selection of plants was gorgeous and the gentle autumn rain really brought some of them to life.  I love how admission is free not only for SF residents and during holidays, but for any early riser who comes through the main gate before 9AM! Will definitely be waking up for that one next time.  Also appreciate how you can wind your way through one side of the garden, as well as the informative plaques scattered throughout.
author: San Y.

description:
One of San Francisco's treasures. 
When you start wandering around the garden you quickly forget you are in the middle of a busy city.  It's very peaceful inside.   It's also much bigger that I expected and rather empty,  
If you live in SF or the bay it is a must to check out.
author: Robert S.

description: Worth the money to check out. Beautiful and clean!
author: Tahima B.

description:
One thing about California that other places around the country are lacking is this: Variety! 

There's something for everybody in San Francisco, and the botanical garden is one of those cool gems tucked away that most tourists don't care to check out.

I think if they did a Guiness World Record count, the SF Botanical Garden would have the most squirels per capita, of any place on earth. They're EVERYWHERE in this place. 

It's a gorgeous place to walk around or just sit on a bench and take in whichever garden you happen to explore at that moment. 

MUST SEE!
author: Rachel S.

description:
And for reason #47 why Golden Gate trumps Central Park*: the San Francisco Botanical Garden.

This place is the perfect spot for a date, and the swarms of kids on field trips will ensure you keep your snuggling PG.  The narrow, winding, shaded paths make the space seem huge, and it's definitely big enough to get (a little) lost in.  This is one of those parks where you stumble on little secret places, whether Asian influenced ponds or prehistoric gardens or tranquil Redwood groves.  I am no botanist, but I love this spot -- so peaceful and intimate, especially for a city this dense.

Best part?  It's free with proof of SF residency, so bring that Comcast bill if you haven't braved the DMV for a change of address on your license, and enjoy.

* - Fine, whatever, Central Park is probably better, but let this SF diehard lose himself in his coastal insecurity.
author: James S.

description: WOW. this place was spectacular! We had a week in San Fran and wanted to hit all the good spots and I'm so glad we had saved this for our last day. It was a HUGE park, we went at 7:30 AM on Wednesday so we got in for free and had almost the hole place to ourselves. They have fantastic gardens, picnic spots, and water features. Lots of hidden paths to wonder down and cool plans and environments  to check out. Can't say enough good things.
author: Kate L.

description: Great place for a nice, quiet walk. $8 admission keeps transients out.  Super well maintained and beautiful flowers and trees.
author: Mark E.

description:
If you live in the city, this isn't a bad place to spend your time. Probably you've already figured that out. 

If you don't!--this place isn't all that interesting. And the Botanical Gardens are woefully short on information about the plants they DO have. If you like botany, you might want to splurge on a trip to the Academy of Science.  If you just want to see gorgeous plants and learn about them, the Conservatory of Flowers is a better pick. And if you want to see local plants in a natural setting, well, there's more impressive nature to be found just about anywhere in the Bay area. Scores of them are within an hour's drive of San Francisco. The state park entry fee is similar, too, and the larger parks have friendly rangers to harass for nature trivia. Choose the terrain or hiking path you want and find the park for you!
author: Eliza K.

description:
A & I LOVE taking walks here.  It's free for San Francisco residents - just show your CA ID or Driver's License.  I think the entrance fee for non-San Francisco residents is pretty minimal.

It's super pretty inside - especially around February-March when the magnolias are blooming!!  There are a ton of different species of plants from all over the world and lots of benches and grassy areas to just hang out and relax.

AND lots of water fowl to watch at the lake, if you're bored. :)
author: Kris L.

description:
Loved this place, gorgeous! 

I would strongly recommend this place for a first date, there is so much to see and very little that needs to be explained. This is date that you experience not just with your eyes, but with your sense of smell and the loving company of your wife/husband/gf/bf. 

This is very large garden so be prepared to walk! It took my wife and I 3 hours to casually walk the garden and i'm sure there was plenty that we missed.
author: Tomo K.

description: We walked around the gardens for what seemed like hours, just weaving in and out of the beautiful trees and flowers in bloom, and admiring the hanging vines and gorgeous flowering bushes. I would say if you'd going to do the botanical gardens and you live in San Francisco, go in March, April or May! Spring has got to be the best time to do it! The flowers are so gorgeous and fragrant and I couldn't get enough of all of the colors! We also got to see a ton of little turtles sunning themselves on a rock in the pool, along with some ducks and geese. Everything here was beautiful, but the Redwoods in the back are definitely a site to behold and if you're not going to a larger Redwood forest on your trip (or in your day!) then definitely check them out!
author: Amanda R.

description: Seems like I came at the perfect time! Flowers were all bloomed and the scenery was lush and green. The garden was bigger than I imagined and had different sections to go through with plants all over the world. It took my friend and I about 3.5 hours to get through the whole thing but she basically to stop to look at each flower, pondered and moved on. Not to mention, there were some great spots for jumping pictures and yoga poses! It would be a great place to chill, bring out a book or to picnic with the beautiful scenery behind you.
author: Stella Y.

description:
We visited the botanical garden on a recent trip to San Francisco and really enjoyed the beautiful day we spent wandering through the gardens (especially after swearing off Fisherman's Wharf for the rest of eternity - we needed some time away from the crowds!).  There were tons of beautiful little areas to walk around - pools, hills, hidden gardens, and restful benches.  Even at the end of December, there were still plentiful blooms to be seen (hydrangeas, camellias, agapanthus) and some beautiful tree foliage.  We spotted two hummingbirds while wandering through the garden and it was quiet enough that were were able to watch them feeding off of the plentiful cuphea.  The admission price was very reasonable (especially compared to other attractions within the city).

Our experience was great, but there were some improvements that would lead to a five star experience.  Some of the plants were not labeled (leading to a running joke that if we saw something we thought was really interesting inevitably it would not be labeled).  In addition, some of the paths were very meandering and it became confusing to figure out what garden we were looking at (the maps only show main paths).  This lead to us missing some of the gardens because we went off of the main path.  Despite this, we still count the garden as one of our favorite things we did on our trip.
author: Anne P.

description:
Although many parts are being improved/renovated, the Botanical gardens is still one of my favorite places to have lunch or a late afternoon stroll.  

***NOTE: as of August 7, non San Francisco residences will be CHARGED Admission!
$7.00 for Adults
$5.00 for Youth ages 12-17, Seniors age 65 & over, and College Students with ID
$2.00 for Children ages 5-11
$15.00 for Families (2 adults and one or more children)***

Some of the things I enjoy about the gardens:

Love all the creatures in the gardens, from the squirrels, blue jays, quails, ducks, turtles, dragonflies, fishes, humming birds and sometimes the Canadian geese - who poop in HUGE amounts everywhere they walk! Watch your step!!! There are signs that say "No feeding, but sometimes I forget ... oops sorry! Don't let the grey bearded man who works there see you doing it or he'll get pissed. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wHhA0cdo0Qzugga1LupN8A?select=Pw0O4vuJ5i0nF-U_N36WJg 

Love to drop by the children's garden most of the time even when nothing much is growing there. I live in SF and don't have a backyard where I can grow fruits and veggies, so I feel like one of the kids when we walk this area - over the years we have seen artichoke, apples, figs, lettuce, tomatoes, herbs, strawberries, sunflowers and a whole lot more grown here. Please do not pick the fruits/veggies...they belong to the kids ;)

Love the banana trees that keep on trying, but never are able to bore full size bananas!

Me and the wife have taken a gazillion pictures here since we went digital! I've included some of our favorites from this week...enjoy!
author: Peter L.

description:
An oasis within an oasis.  What a gorgeous peaceful paradise.  The scent garden is fun as I like to sniff things.  Breathe deeply.  The plants will give you a fresh oxygen infusion. Admission is free, as of this writing, but be a good citizen and fork up a donation.  The garden deserves our support. If you need to be soothed you must go to the  Botanical Garden.  I plan to take the docent tour.  There is a beautiful horticulture library on the grounds as well.

Go.  You will feel refreshed and renewed.
author: Bleep S.

description:
This was one of the first places I had ever been to in SF back in 2006, so I was surprised I hadn't written a review of this place till today.

I love wandering through all the areas in the botanical garden, and almost everything is clearly labeled. I found a new favorite tree called Picea Sitchensis Sitka Spruce. To me it looks like a "weeping evergreen." Gorgeous.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Love it, what is there not to love......I mean it's a botanical garden for crying out loud.
author: Sarah S.

description: AHHH, the perfect place to take a stroll, sunbathe, read a book, picnic.... It's much quieter than the baseball field, and I never have to worry about a wayward ball flying towards my head. However, it's because they charge admission now unless you have proof of SF residency. And I guess people in general aren't really aware of my secret garden that spans like 10 blocks.
author: Vivian H.

description:
I've been to SF Botanical Garden before pre-Yelp and didn't seem to appreciate it so went again to see if it's worth it.  Starting this Summer they will be charging Non-Residents of SF $7pp, so if u don't want to pay it GO NOW!

I went here on Fri after the Japanese Tea Garden.  It's in Golden Gate Park and walking distance from JTG.  They have a box for donation of $5 once you're inside.

I recommend the 1:30pm Docent Walking Tour they offer.  It's really good. I had docent Coley and I had a good time.  It was a pretty long tour at 1hr30min, but you can leave anytime just waving goodbye.

They have Monterey Pine, Cypress trees, Australian Eucylyptus.  The Monterey Cypress Tree is the Huge tree on the Right when you look out on the Main Lawn.  It's their icon, but it's not healthy.  Got lots of bees inside!  Be careful.

In the Fragrance garden you can Touch the plants.  They have artichokes in there!  

Did you know they have two Dogwood Trees in the Botanical Garden?  It's still blooming now as of May 29, 2010!  I love those trees, usually seen in Yosemite.

They have 2 Asian Gardens in there.  I went to both, not on the map u just walk around and notice ponds & lanterns, etc.

The Ancient Garden is pretty cool.  Looks like Giant leaves w/ pods.

They have a small library on the Left, I went inside & looked at a cool garden book from around the world.

Separate bathrooms available, I noticed 2 sets of them.

They have a monthly plant sale: June 12 is Perennials; July 10-Salvias & Shrubs; Aug 14 Shade Plants; Sept 11 - Native plants & Succulents; Oct 9 - Trees, ferns & Rhododendrons; Nov 13 - End of the Season sale.

Recommended, Go Now Out of Towners before they Charge you!

website:
http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org/visiting/index.htm
author: Ann L.

description: This is the largest garden that I've been too & is well worth the $7. You get a discount if you're a SF local so bring your idea. There's lots of plants to look at in this large location so make sure you make plenty of time to see everything. There are certain gardens that are in better season than others so try to look up what gardens you're interested in before coming to get a better view of what they have to offer. Plenty of benches to sit on if you do get tired. If you're lucky you'll even find a squirrel that will stop & pose for you.
author: Kevin Z.

description:
Q:  How many zen masters does it take to screw in a light bulb?
A:  The cypress tree in the courtyard.  

Reaching nirvana is what made Siddhartha Gautama become Buddha, the enlightened one.  He was able to mediate and reach a state of mindfulness, tranquility and insight by just being and breathing in the moment.  That's exactly what brought me to SF Botanical Garden.  I wanted to breathe.  I wanted serenity.  I wanted time to reflect and be still.  Like the oak tree that stands still against the torrid wind.  

The Botanical Garden is serene, peaceful.  I laid down on a bench, closed my eyes, and let the warmth of the sun soak into my tired body.   Across from where I rested, there was a white and pink flower that was fighting to stay alive, limp and barely hanging from the branch.   The cold, winter season left this beautiful flower thrashed, and if someone were to come by and just touch it, its petals would fall to the ground.  It was so reflective to see.  But, I knew that even if it died in that moment, by spring time it would bud and blossom into a more beautiful version of itself.   

Whether you're here to look at the various types of indigenous plants/flowers, or play with your family near the duck pond, or just be by yourself, it's the perfect place to do so.
author: Soo Jin K.

description:
I am not a San Francisco resident - I live in Daly City - but, as a senior citizen, it is well worth the $5 admission fee for a day of joy and beauty in this incredible showplace of 8000 plants fromaround the world.  Within its 55 acres, I can find serenity and peace from life's stresses, watch squirrels cavort, marvel at beesflitting from flower to flower, see beautiful crinkly white Matilija poppies in the California garden and feel glad to be alive.

I had seen the incredible gunnera plant before, at Mona Vale Gardens, in New Zealand.  Imagine my surprise when I encountered it here at SFBG, along with other favorites suchas the King Proteus from South Africa.  The flowers are like a brilliant journey about the world, without having to go throughairport security or lug heavy suitcases.  The staff do an amazing job keeping this showplace beautiful for the citizens of San
Francisco and its visitors from the rest of the world.  I can't recommend it enough.
author: Carmen H.

description:
I actually live in San Francisco so it's free for me to go in. So, I went in trough the main entrance and the guy was being so butt hurt because I showed my school ID. He told me it has to have my address on it. Most likely I wouldn't have gotten a school ID if I didn't live in the city. So what I did was, I went to the other entrance and showed the lady my ID and we went in. What's wrong with a SFUSD ID? I've been in many times with my school ID.  

Other than that, it's nice in botanical garden. Inside has various plants and creatures. Haha. There's like squirrels, turtles, birds, etc. I find it a cool place to chill and hike around.
author: M L.

description: Was really excited to go here... We were disappointed. The staff were great and very helpful. But the grounds were kinda drab and not maintained. I'm not sure if we just went at a bad time or they have done something different since we went in April of 2013  but there was not much to see. Also there were hardly any info on any of the plants, "what is that?" ..." I don't know, there is no information"  We are gardeners and have been to many nursery's/botanical gardens and such but this just came off as a walk through park to read or to bring a lunch.
author: Kisha B.

description: the smells! my nose hasn't had that much fun since my bday when my b friend got us some of that columbian. what an awesome place to take your man and rub up on him. flowers make me happy!
author: Laura B.

description: After coming back here with my parents a second time, I had the opportunity to walk around the entire park, and am blown away by how big and how many unique plants are here. Very much like walking in a microcosm of the Earth. Very cool.
author: Mel G.

description:
I left my heart in the botanical garden :(
One of my more favorite places in Golden Gate Park. You can take your time and not feel rushed and you get a wide selection of plant, flowers, trees and cool architecture . I guess that's the best part about it, you can come here and just chill out. Bigger then the Japanese tea garden and less crowded.
author: Lauren E.

description: I visited this place for the first time last weekend and it's free for SF residents. It is truly a gem in the middle of the city, with it's gorgeous trees and well-maintained landscape. I enjoyed coming here for a stroll and just enjoying the day. They have a good collection of plants from many parts of the world.
author: Karina L.

description:
I truly love this botanical garden. There are such unique trees, plants, and flowers. I wish there were more benches, but if you're lucky, you can sit and watch birds - and people - for a good chunk of your day. Furthermore, one of my favorite trees of all time exists in this garden. (Yes, I am an arbor-phile.) It's massive, stringy, and a hide out for lots of squirrels. 

Oh yes, did I mention the squirrels? Don't even think about eating a meal here without fending off squirrels the whole time. 

I'd say this garden doesn't do the best job of labeling all the different types of plants. However, if you're looking for another place of refuge in the Golden Gate Park, there are some good spots here.
author: Jess L.

description:
Love walking around the gardens.  Huge well kept meadows, lots of trees so lots of shades, quiet ambiance.  It takes about an hour or so to completely cover all the sections in the map.  There is a waterfowl pond and fountain plaza that are worth sitting around and enjoying the view.  They have benches almost in every corner.  

Do make sure to use student ID($5) if you have one =)
author: Hema K.

description:
Great place to walk around and enjoy the scenery on a nice day.

This garden is huge! it is sectioned by different themes. 
There are also plenty of side trails to walk on.

Discount for S.F residents and students!
They conveniently take credit cards. (Big plus!)

5 STARS
author: Karen L.

description:
Why havent I been here for the past 2 years? 

I love coming here for a great walk. Its nice to find a diversity of different plants within the botanical garden in sf. Lots of cool plants with different kinds of adaptation and development here. Walk through the main gate and embark yourself towards a mini hiking trail with friends/family! I believe its free to come in but they do say donations are welcome in order to improve the conservation of plants...

Remember guys, plants are what makes us alive!
author: Cavin T.

description:
I love it here!! It's so peaceful and serene. 

There are a lot of short trails and mini gardens to walk through. It's like a zoo for flowers and vegetation! You can see different varieties from all over the world. Take a tour through Japan, China, Brazil, and New Zealand to name a few!

After your walk, you can relax in the grassy meadow. It's so awesome to enjoy nature in the middle of our favorite busy City by the Bay.

Free to SF residents and $7 to the rest of the general public.
author: Earlene C.

description: As entry is free for SF residents, I have the pleasure of visiting the gardens often and affordably. I love walking through the different areas. The moon-viewing pond is a meditative spot that I'd hope to visit at night sometime, on a full moon. I'm not sure what else to say, other than I've really enjoyed myself and hanging out with friends every time I've visited. Thanks!
author: Michelle J.

description:
Love me some Magnolias
...and all pretty flowers that are not cliche roses for that matter

Great weather was the perfect companion to this outdoor, city but not city, walk. You know what I mean. You park in the city, but walk into this place and forget you are in the city. 
I was going picture crazy and falling in love with the beautiful variety of Magnolias and plethora of other worldly foliage

Our mid- week visit (Wed afternoon) was not crowded, had gardners eager to talk and share information with us and provided easy parking. Score.

Wish I was a local so I could visit this wonderful garden regularly :)
author: Leticia G.

description: A great place to go if you are really into botany. I appreciate it but not a giant nerd about it. I went here with my sister on a gorgeous day so just to walk around and take in the beauty was nice. Also if you live in the city it's free....alas I do not but it was worth the fee.
author: Andi W.

description: For non residents, the cost of admission is $7. I would say it's very much worth it if you want to learn about the different types of flowers/plants there are. A lot of couples go here to hang out and just lunch/picnic on a bench or a grassy area. I went on one of the earlier days of Spring so not much of the flowers were blooming. But for the most part, it was a lot fun. There are a lot of little plates by each plant that you can read/learn from. I would say it's a very ideal place to go for a romance picnic or just to walk around. The whole park itself is very big but there are maps there you can use as a guide ( so you can hit up all the secret spots). The scenery is truly beautiful. Not too far from the entrance, there is a big water fountain  with benches around it. You would see a lot of families taking pictures next to it. Throughout the park, there are a lot of hidden trails you can explore and take pictures of. Most importantly, it's a great place to take some great scenery pictures if you are in need of some pictures to color up your Instagram!
author: Katy W.

description: It is a good one hour trip to visit the place for variety of plants and fresh air.
author: nn X.

description: A beautiful place to escape and get lost. A self guided tour of the San Francisco botanical gardens. You can also have docents guide you through one of their  gardens are broken up to five different sections. Plants & flowers ranging from new Zealand to Asia to South Africa. They also have seasonal flowers that are highlighted during different time of the year in the free guide they hand you once you enter into the gate. Btw, entrance fee isn't too bad only $7 for adults, $5 for youth ages 12-17 years & 65+, $2 for children 5-11 or $15 for a family (two adults & all children ages 17 & under), free for ages 4 & under.
