Free entrance for SF residences & free for ALL on the second Tuesday of every month, Thanksgiving, Christmas, & New Year's Day!!!
author: Susan W.

description: Such a beautiful place to visit and read your favorite book. And conveniently located near a variety of eateries. I think I lucked out with the weather, but I'd probably revisit on a cloudy day too :))
author: Jessica W.

description: Though primarily for children, great lunar new year celebration for everyone here (2015) complete with music and crowd, different activities and the like.  Excellent species in the garden, and do not forget the concession for gifts and other items if you are interested at all in plant life - I purchased at a very reasonable price a large card with insect species illustration and some postcards, a map and so on.  Great!
author: Thomas H S.

description: I love walking 5 min to this park from my place. It's free and it's gorgeous! My favorite places are the Moon Viewing Garden and the California Natives. I can't wait to transform my backyard to mirror the beauty of the park.
author: Katie D.

description:
If I had a phobia of squirrels I probably wouldn't have given this place more than 1 star, much less taken the time to review it instead of calling animal control. SERIOUSLY! If you could get past the throngs of four-legged-nut-busters that will LITERALLY follow you around hoping you drop a morsel or two, this place if for you!

The lady and I picked up some dim sum to-go and found a nice quite spot to sit in one of the many gardens strewn throughout the garden. Needless to say, mad romance points were won that day!

PARKING TIP: I found the garden easy to access from the north gate. To get there I drove south down 8th ave towards the park. You'll eventually end up in an underground parking garage right beneath the De Young museum. From there it's an easy walk to the garden.
author: Charles B.

description:
This place is lovely -- a wonderful temporary retreat from the city!

One could wander endlessly if they wanted within the walls of the Botanical Garden. The garden itself is divided into different regions, most named after certain countries, ie: Chile and New Zealand. There is so much green and nature all around, one can hardly believe that you're still in the city. Apparently, the garden is set-up so that plant blooms are staggered; different plants are in bloom at different times of the year.

Bring your friend, bring your family, people or someone you care about, or just go alone for a nice quick get-away -- nature is calling :]
author: Michael N.

description:
Ahh...why don't they have more beautiful places like the San Francisco Botanical Garden?! This place swept me off my little feet!

Apparently it's free for locals, but it costs $7 for out-of-towners like myself. I honestly don't mind paying; the scenery is amazing and it's practically free anyway! I enjoyed walking along the paths and my eyes appreciated the vibrant colored flowers. Who knew that so many different flowers could be planted and could survive in one area?! It's such a great place for couples, families, and even singles. If I lived in San Francisco, I would definitely lay out, relax, and catch up on a read at this garden. It's lovely and I highly recommend checking it out!
author: Lien T.

description: There is a ticket special on Yelp now but even without it this is worth checking out. The California Redwoods alone are worth the price if you're from the east coast and have never seen them. This place is large and not too crowded, worth a stop for sure.
author: David H.

description:
A FREE attraction in Golden Gate Park? Amazing in the city where everything costs money!

I should point out this place is only free if you are resident of San Fran - definitely bring your ID that proves this (they check).

This place is very calm, peaceful and surprisingly quiet for being right smack in the middle of Golden Gate Park. Lots of sections of gardens from around the world - Asia, Australia, New Zealand, etc. They have all these little tags with the names of the plant or tree right in front, I like being able to learn a couple things while wandering around. 

I came during the fall so it was a little barren - not many flowers blooming and such, but would LOVE to return in the spring when everything blooms!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Our absolute favorite place to stroll, hang out...
Some days, we bring a drawing pad, a book, some knitting...and just hang out...
Our daughter loves the library....
author: Barb L.

description: A great way to spend a Sunday afternoon. It is free and there are a lot of nice benches to sit and just enjoy the view. I love the flowers and they have some really nice bridges and structures. I also like how it isn't that crowded. Theres a lot of space for a picnic.
author: Sarah C.

description:
It is an awesome feeling to walk through the grounds and remind yourself that you are in the middle of the city. It sure doesn't feel like it - it's quiet and peaceful, with an amazing collection of things to see and places to sit and enjoy the natural world. You can see themed garden collections from all over the world, like South Africa, Australia, or Native California.

Parking was a bit of a beast on the Saturday when we went (Museum lot totally full, street parking free but scanty), so I would recommend arriving as early as possible on the weekends. Cost is $7 for adults, $5 for students. Be sure to check out the plants for sale at the wooden building near the entrance.
author: Stacy G.

description: Best $7 I've ever spent. Interestingly, very quiet while the rest of the park was buzzing with crowds.
author: Amy B.

description:
Pros: Storks, swans, magnolias,..Free for SF residents!!

Yelp deals rock!! Buy one, get one? Sweet!!

Of course, if you're a San Francisco resident, the garden is free and, in my personal list, quickly becoming a contender for best reading spots in the city. With its lush trees, pastoral fields, and serene "lake," this is a great way to spend a sunny afternoon.

If you're lucky, they may be selling plants by the bookstore that day, and you can get a unique plant for next to nothing.

Check their listings for tour times. I overheard part of the it during my last trip. Not only was the guide incredibly knowledgeable, but also genuinely passionate about the garden. =)
author: Sue Y.

description:
The Botanical Gardens is one of those places that falls off most people's list of things to do here in S.F. It a beautiful, peaceful and CLEAN place to spend the afternoon on your own or with friends and family. Whether it's a quick jog to get through the park or a leisurely stroll to enjoy the scenery, there is a little something for everyone here. 

I tend to avoid any public or touristy places during the weekends because I am not a big fan of crowds (long lines, higher prices, interrupted photos etc.) but this place is never crowded. Maybe it's the $7 entrance fee (waived if you are an SF resident) or maybe because it's somewhat hidden in Golden Gate Park; whatever the reason, it's a must for any fan of plants, flowers, tranquility, photography or open green space.
author: E E.

description: Wow, the botanic garden is amazingly beautiful and serene.   I loved it here.  It is really nice for a walk with friends or family.  Don't forget the camera to take some photos.
author: D. C.

description:
As a San Francisco resident, this is one of my favorite places in visit year round.  This botanical garden is very large with many paths  that allow you to portal into regions throughout the world (within SF climate limitations of course).

Some of my favorite parts of the botanical garden include:

- the redwood forest: it 's so lovely it makes me forget where I am sometimes
- the garden of fragrance: there are all kinds of flowers and herbs here
- the Meso American Cloud Forest: I once found a flower I had never seen before on the ground here and have learned to look in the trees every so often when I walk around
- the pond by the Children's Garden: it is always filled with duck weed and looks almost like solid ground.  Sometimes you can see tadpoles moving in the water and egrets trying to eat them
- the New Zealand christmas tree: it has the coolest hair like needles and trunk/roots (sorry don't know the technical terms).
- the squirrels: I know it's probably bad that they are fed by visitors way too often, but this is probably one of the few places where squirrels will come so close
- the quail: sometimes you'll see quail families running around
- the bamboo path

There is really so much more than this list of things that I enjoy about the botanical garden.  There is always something different is in bloom year round, so visiting at anytime provides a wonderful experience.  It's really too bad that they started charging non-residents to visit because I used to love taking people from out of town here when I was a poor college student.  Definitely visit if you haven't already!
author: Stella T.

description:
I think all of the plants in the world are here. The garden has a wonderful layout, student discounts, trees, meadows, and flowers, ponds, and benches galore. 

My favorites: the redwood grove, which features a tiny stream. It feels like something straight out of Twilight. The succulents are also not to be missed and poked. 

If I lived in the area, I would totally buy a pass and come here so much. I would plant watch so hard, it wouldn't even be funny.
author: Emily D.

description: Wow. This is just a spectacular botanical garden. Free to SF residents. If I lived in the city if be here as often as possible. Beautiful and relaxing. I loved the Garden of  Fragrances and the California Native gardens. The gardens are well labeled and I especially loved the signs explaining how Native Americans used the native plants.  Definitely worth a visit.
author: Diane E.

description:
Did a trip to SF for my birthday last year and wanted to go to the park, this seemed like a cool thing to do.  Was a little hard to find the place because the people I asked kept telling me to go different directions, but once inside all was good.  

Really well laid out and several different climates/themes with flora from the region present.  Well maintained, pretty quiet, not overcrowded, very relaxing and enjoyable way to spend the morning before heading out to see other things in the city.  Pretty cool that there is a big park/forest inside a large city.
author: Craig G.

description:
Beautiful! Who knew you could grow so many different kinds of plants from all over the world in one spot? What's even better? It's only a $7 entrance fee for us out-of-towners, or free admission for residents of San Francisco and County. That's a sweet deal.

I came in through the front gate and the first thing I saw was this gorgeous tree standing dozens of feet high into the air. There was a person sitting at its base reading a book. It could've been the opening scene to some movie somewhere, or at the very least made a very pretty picture.

I spent about an hour and a half walking the paths and checking out the various plants. I'm no botanist, but I do love strolls through luscious parks. If I were a local, this would be a go-to spot for a picnic (which is allowed it turns out). 

Plenty of quiet nooks, there were people lazing together in the sunshine, reading books, and exploring the various garden breakouts. I lingered the longest in the Garden of Fragrance by this cute little archway. Aching feet from traipsing through SF all day and a growling tummy were the only things keeping me from staying any longer than I did.
author: Wendy P.

description:
Free to local San Franciscans, the botanical garden offers an array of different gardens around the world.

My favorite part of the garden is the Redwood Garden, as it has an awesome landscape and great bench under a few large redwood trees.  The price to enter the garden is moderately fair, and well worth the hour plus you will spend venturing off in the gardens.

I would recommend this place for meditation purposes, blowing off steam, enjoying the weather, or if you just like to see some beautiful plants and excellently landscaped gardens.

Will be back!
author: Tom L.

description:
Free for SF residents. 

The park was nice for a picnic.
author: Patty G.

description:
This is my favorite place in San Francisco, so far.  If the fog hasn't rolled in on the Sunset, then this is where to find me. I go to the Gardens to tan, read, relax, write letters home, walk around and get lost. I love how each section is divided based on the plants and flowers native to the area. I've seen Chile and Australia and I don't remember the rest because when I am there I feel like Alice In Wonderland and I don't want to read the signs. There is a huge area of Poison Oak, clearly marked. I thought that was pretty cool. 

The best part? A squirrel, that I decided is named Parnassus, tried to steal my cell phone while his friend created a diversion. They really come right up to you and will eat your sandwich. I'm posting pictures.
author: Nina C.

description:
First off - the Botanical Garden is gorgeous and one of my favorite places in the city. However, in my experience, the entrance staff is TERRIBLE - rude, uninformed and uncompromising. Specifically, the power-tripping women working the gates on the weekend need to get off their high horses and allow for some leeway. 

Background: 
I've lived in San Francisco for almost my entire life. I was born and raised here. I pay taxes. Contribute to charities. Give up cash towards more than my fair share of parking tickets (damn inner Sunset parking). My boyfriend has lived in SF for over 2 years, and is originally from the Bay Area. 

Setting:
One lovely, cold but sunny San Francisco winter Sunday morning, I was super excited to wander the Botanical Garden with my bf and our cups of coffee. We walked up to the woman who now "guards" the gates leading to the main entrance. I had my drivers license with my SF address. My bf, on the other hand, hadn't gotten a new license after moving so his had an old, non-SF address. 

Side note: DMV doesn't even make you get a new license when you move - they just require that you notify them of your change of address. 

Cage Match: 
The woman wouldn't let us in like the SF residents we are. We begged. We pleaded. We shared esoteric local knowledge. No dice. After contemplating hopping the 12-foot fence, we went to the other, side gate. That woman wouldn't let us in either, although she told us that they'd been letting residents-without-proof in free for the past 6 months, but NOW they were bucking down. 

The idiotic women working the little kiosks wouldn't budge an inch to let us in without paying the RIDICULOUS amount of $7. It's nature! It used to be free! I know $7 isn't all that much dinero in the grand scheme of things but seriously, after paying taxes and parking tickets into the city coffers for almost 15 years, it's time to relax a little ladies. Hope you had  a nice power trip. 

You can't contain nature, especially like this. The whole experience put a bad taste in my mouth, and it wasn't from the coffee. 


Recommendations:
It's plausible that an SF resident wouldn't have their local address on their drivers license. And who carries around utility bills? Really? The Garden should have a list of registered voters or some other way to verify residency. 
And they should look into some etiquette lessons for their clerks. I don't care if you're a volunteer, I volunteer too. It doesn't give you the right to be an a-hole.
author: Kayla N.

description: LOVED THIS PLACE. I'm not a local so I had to pay 6 dollars but worth every penny. One of the best gardens I've been to. I'll go here everyday if I lived in SF. My brother and I strolled in this garden for an hour, but I would have stayed more if we had more time. The grandiose trees, variety of flowers and plants, awesome little trails and green space to sit and enjoy the sun..!
author: Jenny B.

description: On a recent visit to San Francisco my mother, sister, husband and I spent a quiet afternoon in the Botanical Gardens. The park is free for locals which is a huge incentive to visit. We were a little disappointed by the signage: only roughly a third of the plants were labeled. However we could fill in some of the gaps. We are frequent visitors to botanic gardens and avid gardeners ourselves. We have a soft spot for California natives and on that score this garden does deliver. Their California section displayed chaparral, arroyos, ponds and woodlands plantings. We also had fun in the Australia and New Zealand sections. There were sparse educational materials throughout the park and they give a daily tour. I highly recommend checking this out if you are even remotely interested in ecology.
author: Kathryn B.

description:
There are two entrances. The main entrance at the south side of the park, but the more convenient entrance for those coming from the De Young, Academy of Science, or the Tea Garden is the north entrance which is on Martin Luther King and Hagiwara Tea Garden Drive. The north entrance is just south of the Tea Garden.

The pond areas near the main gate were my favorite part of this place, but most of the gardens need more work and development as they don't feel encompassing and complete. Despite the size of the grounds, we only spent an hour there.

If the Golden Gate Park gardens, consisting of this Botanical Garden, the Japanese Tea Garden, and the Conservatory of Flowers, were all one attraction with one entry fee, I'd give the theoretical collective 5-stars. Among of the three gardens, the Botanical is the biggest, but the least likely I'd recommend to anyone.
author: Brian U.

description:
Every time I go to Golden Gate Park, I always think it's going to be a shorter walk than it actually is.  This place is no exception.

I thought it was going to be a small place to look at pretty little flowers, and I was only right about the last part.  I like to look at every nook and cranny of a place, so this turned into really good exercise.  It's actually a cute place to do mild hiking or have a picnic.

The whole place is worth a look, but if you're short on time, don't miss the pretty Chinese and Japanese gardens and the redwood grove (look for the place with the benches!).

Oh, and look out for free days!  :)
author: Lily N.

description:
I love this garden--it's full of funny-looking plants and berries! Check out my pictures for a few of our sights. The animals here are very brave--I was able sit up right next to the ducks, and take a little video of a cute squirrel eating stuff on a branch. We also spotted a group of people having a picnic amidst flocks of geese.

I do wish there was some sun on this day--San Francisco is always so damn cold and cloudy. It was still pretty enough, however, for a couple to get married here!

There is free parking reasonably close by, and free entrance (unlike at the Japanese Tea Garden, which is directly across from here).
author: K W.

description:
It's a short walk across Golden Gate Park when you're in a garden.  

I was happy to report admission would be free, due to my research on Yelp.  We entered at the Friend Gate, and made our way south.  We found a grove of trees inhabited by brown squirrels.  The squirrels were quite tame, and a group of people hovered nearby waiting for squirrelly photo ops.  We found two little lakes that don't show up on some maps.  We found South Africa.  A very large collection of South African botanicals, that is, titled "Cape Province Garden."  We found the library, and exited by the entrance library patio.  The San Francisco County Fair Building appeared to be sound and available.  

Everything was labeled.  All, in all, it was quite entertaining.
author: David D.

description:
pros: very friendly area, grounds were well kept, not crowded and it is 55acres of land

Cons. i was expecting it to be a bit more alive with colors but hardly did i see any colors. maybe i missed a section considering its a huge garden. 

tips. bring snacks, have a picnic a blanket and drink and enjoy the birds and just relax!
author: Jessica C.

description: Vast garden with beautiful specimens. I appreciated that there were numerous small dirt paths one could take to go deeper into the planted areas. Frequently there would be a lovely sitting are tucked away. It was nice to not have to stay on the paved main pathway.
author: Mari N.

description:
I used to be a docent for the Botanical Gardens (also known as Strybing Arboretum), so I did think they were marvelous.  (The plants still are.)

However, the garden allowed itself to become embroiled in city politics, so now, unless you can prove your San Francisco residency, it costs you a cool $7 entrance fee (less for children).  The result has been predictable, but dismal.

Where once the garden overflowed with enthusiastic visitors, so that on weekends and beautiful days, a kind of carnival atmosphere prevailed, now you will be lucky to meet half a dozen groups in the entire garden.  San Franciscans rightly think that they have been deprived of one of their city heritages, so even those who would be admitted free tend to shun the garden.  The staff doesn't say anything, but it must be odd to maintain an extensive garden -- which is primarily seen by the staff.

A similar atmosphere infects the horticultural library, which has become a library for the librarians. (The assistant librarian thinks she has done something really outstanding if she reads -- LOUDLY-- a book to one visiting child.  Should any adult have the temerity to stray into the library during the time of her pet project, woe be the adult consulter of books, who might like to work in peace.)

Fortunately, Golden Gate Park is large and extensive.  There are plenty of other areas that are free and equally rewarding to visit.  Explore beyond the botanical gardens.  I suggest you head westward for the less developed sections of the park.
author: J.M. K.

description:
Now that the gardens have started charging admission, it's somewhat peaceful with smaller crowds inside. Luckily, I'm a local so it's still free for me. The worst part - fewer people = more geese. I mean there were so many geese in there it was almost overwhelming. Not only because birds really freak me out, but because there is so much (large) bird crap in the garden that nobody seems to be cleaning up. You really have to look down when you're walking on certain paths, which takes away the beauty of the park. Otherwise, you're bound to step on a mound of green turd. I thought I found a good spot for a picnic inside, but upon looking at the grass, it was so full of poop I had to search carefully for another spot. 

On the particular day that I was there, a crowd was there with bear heads, a moose head, and some other things like drums hidden in the back area. So in addition to the peacefulness of the garden, there were faint drums and all I could think of was The Proposal... "to the window... to the wall."   

It's still a nice quaint area to spend time in the park. They have plant sales outside if people are interested in that too. After the renovations are complete, it will look even nicer.  Can't wait to go back when the fountain is complete.
author: Stacey C.

description:
I've spent many summers here reading, taking naps, letting the dogs frolic, or sharing sangrias with friends. It's gorgeous here, and green grass always makes me smile. The trees are gorgeous, though I'd much rather surround myself with some redwoods in Muir Woods, but the California Garden has some lovely ones. 

This place is one of the few reasons I love my hometown so much, even in the worst weather. 

Except for that one squirrel that grabbed my blue scarf and proceeded to climb up a tree with it. It might still be there. If you see it, holla.

That squirrel can go to hell.
author: Colleen M.

description:
Beautiful place to walk around and highly recommended place to take visitors when they're in town. Many different areas either categorized by country (Australia, South Africa, New Zealand, etc.) or by plant type (succulent garden, fragrant garden, etc). I love sitting by the duck pond and watching the animals. Watch out the squirrels are aggressive and will even climb on you if you have any food within their reach - one woman enticed one to climb up her leg and it did to get the food in her hand! 

Downside- it's no longer free for everyone (SF residents be sure to bring your ID), closes at 5pm or 6, and the park closes its gates one hour before closing so be sure to get there in time.
author: Kay S.

description:
Got lost in my city today. I explored a redwood grove, stumbled across a hidden amphitheater, crossed meadows and ponds and saw plants and flowers from South America, California, South Africa and Japan. The beauty was stunning, the peacefulness comforting and the air refreshing. When I finally made my way out, I was a little disappointed to no longer be lost.

That this place exists within the confines of our city amazes me. Then again, considering how amazing our city is, it does not.
author: Jason B.

description: As a horticulture major at Merritt, I love love love plants. This is my favorite place to adventure to from the east bay and have a picnic, read a book and see some lovely sights.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Love the botanical gardens. I bring everyone who is visiting me in the city here. Maybe because it's so close to my house, I can walk here and well it's FREE! 

It took me 2 times being here before I actually saw everything. I always end up taking a million pictures because everything is so beautiful and very well kept. You can tell lots of love goes into the gardens. I could seriously just hang out here all day and just read a book in the sun. 

If you are in SF this place is a must see.
author: Danielle K.

description:
Perfect spot for a mommy and baby date with two other friends.

In between the sneezing and sniffling from allergy season, I really enjoyed my time.
author: RoseMichelle M.

description: Wonderful "hidden gem" in Golden Gate Park. The entrance by 9th and Lincoln is well-marked, but I say it's "hidden" because it's not clear that the garden is FREE to residents until you get to the ticket window, and the garden seems to be less crowded than other areas of the park. There are many different gardens inside, featuring plants from different climates and regions of the world. Look for foot paths in addition to the paved sidewalks and explore the nooks and crannies. The Garden of Fragrance near the entrance is nice, but take some time to walk through the different Cloud Forests, explore the ponds, and find a favorite place to appreciate the flora and reflect on the diversity of what's there.
author: Steve F.

description:
It's looking a little beat up with the weather lately and all, but a great and (FREE) wonderous place to get lost. 

Did I mention it's FREE? 

On a nice day, bring a picnic. If you dig flowers and interesting vegetation, bring a camera, preferably with a macro lens.

UPDATE 5/1/06: Ok. This is now my favorite place to get lost on a beautiful day in the city. There are plenty of nooks and crannies to sort of hide away and read a book, or...smooch with your sweetie. And the PLANTS! May favorite area is the succulent area, which is like nature's sculpture garden. Be sure to check out my photos for examples.
author: N B.

description:
Excellent! I used a Yelp Deal to go here with my boyfriend (2 for $7). It was New Years weekend so the weather was a little chilly and overcast. However, the plants are amazing to look at in any weather. I didn't get to explore the entire Garden (there are a lot of differently themed sections) but I was very impressed with the size. 

It's refreshing to enjoy such an inviting and enticing outdoor space right in the middle of the city. I will definitely buy this deal again and bask in the beauty of this Botanical Garden :)
author: Nicholle P.

description: Wow, this place is wonderful being located in Golden Gate Park.  We got to see the entire place including the Japanese tea garden and the Conservatory of Flowers.  It is easy to miss this place but just look for the signs once you are close to the de Young museum.
author: Phillip Y.

description:
Stow Lake, Strybing, and the Japanese Tea Garden together form the scenic apex of Golden Gate Park.  You could easily spend an entire afternoon here, and I'd wager even your out-of-town visitors would find it engaging.

If you've only ever walked along the eastern edge of the arboretum, you might think it's just another glorified meadow in GGP--if you even noticed you had entered an arboretum at all (admission is free, and although the gates close at 5, during the day it's pretty easy to just wander in here).  But the real highlights lie off the asphalt paths, in the western end.  You'll find all sorts of glades, pools, and the like back here, along with a strong asian-and-redwood theme that truly makes this one of the prettiest gardens ever.  I wonder if you can do weddings here--you could have some freakin' amazing photos, that's for sure.

There's also a large area devoted to native California plants, and while it's not as superficially pretty as the other sections, it's pretty fascinating if you've spent a lot of time hiking in Cali.  There's lots of other curiosities in here too, such as the bizarre "witches circle" (you'll know it when you see it).

All in all, Strybing could give the world-famous Huntington gardens a run for its money, especially if you prefer wetter flora to the desert kind.    But what really amazes me is that it's FREE.  You're doing yourself a great disservice if you live anywhere in the bay area and don't come here at some point.
author: Wes M.

description: This garden is so peaceful and has such a variety of plants and trees! This such a great place to relax!
author: Charles Z.

description: NOT FREE ANYMORE!!!  This place rocks, but unfortunately I had to minus one star.  That is because this place used to be FREE!!!  Just this weekend I had these huge hopes that I could walk into the gardens, nope.  They now have this booth set up with some person nestled inside reading a book and then looks up at you and says, "$7 please."  What??????  So I'm not sure what is going on, but if you have the money to fork over, it is a great place to visit and look at plants.  Oh and bonus if you live in the city, you get in for free.
author: Michelle M.

description: Really relaxing spot to enjoy nature and plants from around the world. I come here once a week to stroll and let my mind clear. And the squirrels are so cute. The geese poop everywhere haha but they feed on the grass and that's wonderful. So that the park can be enjoyed by people AND animals! I love going near the pond where there's ducks and turtles and some fish too. I wonder how deep that pond is. Free for SF residents with ID. You can also volunteer here on certain days.
author: Natalie Charlotte W.

description:
This place was awesome! Pack some stuff for a picnic and enjoy the plants from all over the world. It was beautiful and super peaceful, a great thing to do to relax and enjoy the great parks in San Francisco. Doesn't hurt if you have a bottle of champagne either. . .

The Redwood forest area was definitely my favorite!
author: Austin H.

description:
Dig this. Me and one of my best friends decided to knock off work, grab some beers, and sit in the botanical garden after work. For some reason, it was open past 4.30 today (Thursday in July), and we sat until 8.30 by the empty fountain... chatting, waxing, musing, blathering.  I know they usually close it and let people meander out... but it was empty. We were totally alone in this beautiful, stunning arena of nature.  There, literally, was not a human being for two hours.  I mean, just that fog rolling on top of the trees as it was torn asunder by the sun.. .sort of unbelievable. It's like your cartwheeling through the universe. (I thought of deleting that thought, actually. Come back to haunt me, likey?).  Sort of badass.  Like...

We actually live here.  People are arguing over fence post locations in suburban South Dakota, and we live *HERE* among Monterey Cypress and Blue Heron?

What?


Okay so this place is pretty cool. 
[intended understatement intended]
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
1. Get some friends
2. Or not.
3. Pack some food
4. Maybe bring some reading material as well if you are by yourself
5. Bring a frisbee or football if with friends
6. Enter the Garden
7. Laugh to yourself at how awesome it it.
8. Enjoy your afternoon.

Not only can you walk around and look at different plants, but there are large grass areas for picnics and fun. Perfect for birthday parties.
author: Walter M.

description: The garden is beautiful so my complaint is really the fees.   I wanted to get married for only 20 minutes with just the fiance, minister, and two witness plus myself.  We wanted to get married in the redwood grove area on a weekday in September.  You know how much they were going to charge us?  $1000.00+ !!!!  for one hour.  I said it was only for 15-20 minutes with no other guests, no set up, etc.  Still $1000.00!   UGH!  What a robbery that is.
author: Sweetpea M.

description: Beautiful gardens to explore. You can travel from Asia to Chile and lots of places in between.
author: Devin D.

description: Fantastic place. We went here after going to the Japanese Tea Garden and I happened to like this place a lot better.  Its the same price but much larger.  I am not a lover of plants like some people but I still enjoyed walking around the beautiful grounds and looking at the plants and flowers. My favorite section is the Redwood Grove. As soon as I walked into it, it felt like the atmosphere almost changed.  It felt like some of the redwood forests that I've been it. Obviously the trees aren't as big but it's still great to experience while still being in a major city.
author: Brad C.

description:
Come on with the come on!  What is up with the turtles?  They are adorable.  Less adorable? The squirrels that keep coming up to you for food.  Gross.  Rodents.  Cute little faced gross rodents.

It was a lovely day for a bike ride, lunch, and sitting out in the sun by a pond staring at guppies and turtles.

Best part- free if you are a resident of San Francisco.
author: Ashley I.

description: I loved this place the moment that I went in it was a piece of heaven (love plants and flowers). I was amazed by the different plants from around the world my favorite is Australia, made my day. I would recommend this to everyone especially for families cause its big enough to entertain children and teach them a few things.
author: Rosa A. F.

description: $7.00 entrance fee. Not too bad. I was mostly interested in the Redwood Trees. Other than that, I was not impressed.
author: Yvelisse L.

description:
I've seen the gardens on my way into the park, but I had never visited until this afternoon. Since it was a beautiful day out my friend took me here for a stroll and to take a lunch break. 

My friend volunteers here and seems to know the area pretty well. I discovered he likes to come here to take close-up photos of the flowers. I wish I was as much into taking pics as he is.

The different gardens based on geographic zones and plant types are stunningly beautiful. We only walked through maybe half of the twenty-something gardens before settling on a nice stone bench for a little food, a little sun and catch-up conversation.

It's such a wonderful place. Glad I finally got a chance to visit it.
author: Sara A.

description:
this place is absolutely corrupt!

they talk about how kid friendly they are on their facebook page but in reality they only care about money

we decided to ask botanical gardens to have a birthday party for our daughter there and received a denial, here is a part of it:

After review, it was determined that the botanical gardens is not a suitable site for children events or group picnics or similar activities.  The Botanical Gardens is primarily a corporate and premium wedding rental site.
 
few days later i see their post on facebook page about how great it is to spend time with kids their - see the screenshot i posted.

i posted a comment to this post on facebook letting them know that it totally contradicts with their denial letter and they removed my comment! what a sleezy act and what a sleezy group!

i am not going to support them in any way after this. eventhough i always considered this a community place this place does not concern themselves about the community.
author: Leyla A.

description:
This is my favorite place in San Francisco. It has supplied me with hundreds of photos, and handful picnics, piece of mind and many leisurely strolls through its beautiful garden. My favorite story of the garden was told to me by a friend, back when I lived in snowy Buffalo NY. 

She was on a tour of the grounds and found herself interrupting the tour guide to ask "Excuse me, but what month is it here? The tour guide, undoubtedly stalled in front of some glorious flowers, responded "January". My friend said at that very moment she burst into tears. If you have ever been to Buffalo New York in January, you know why. 

Although you may not find me convulsing uncontrollably trying to hold back my tears, you might find my eyes a little misty as I take in the wonder that is the garden. 

Sure, there are gardens that are more grandiose in scale and reputation, but this park is more humble and welcoming of its guests. It is a good place to sit and just simply be.
author: Tina E.

description:
One of my favorite places in S.F. and unbelievably it is still free. This is a great place to take a walk and completely relax and you go through the foliage of different parts of the world. Lush tropical areas and great big plains with cacti - this place has it all. 

A much better place to take tourists than Fisherman's Wharf and the other tired overpriced stuff.
author: Marco M.

description: i'm lucky to live in this neighborhood and love coming here again and again ! this place is a true sanctuary.
author: Gudrun L.

description:
Made a great day of seeing the garden with a friend who could demonstrate some seriously botanical know-how. Fun time exploring all the different regions represented in the collection while looking for some  of the more recognizable specimens.

Great place for a picnic while taking in the greenery. Definitely worth the price for us out-of-towners, especially with the great yelp deal discount thing. Only problem: don't arrive too late in the afternoon or you might be disapointed when the park suddenly appears to be closing!!
author: Rosie N.

description:
The botanical garden is good sized and FREE if you can prove you live in SF county/City. I had to explain to the woman that I live only 6 blocks away but it doesn't say that on my ID because I was too lazy to change it when I moved to SF.

She eventually let me in for free.

They do offer student discounts even if you are not from SF.

The only unfortunate thing was I went today (winter time) and it wasn't flowering the way I would like to see it.

Next time I go I will take a pick nick on a warm day.
author: Alex W.

description:
San Francisco is one of those cities whose pace can wear down the soul.

The San Francisco Botanical Gardens is the kind of place, once you are inside, that you tend to forget you are in a huge city. You walk slower, you take time to appreciate the beauty around you and if you are like me, you lay down on the edge of the fountain with one of your good friends and talk and laugh and enjoy yourself.

Gorgeous and healing - you go now.
author: Tara H.

description:
Beautiful place to take a stroll if you are in the Golden Gate Park area. As everyone said, admission is FREE. 

Walk around to see the exotic plants. Take some side paths to see where you end up. Just appreciate Mother Nature!

There is a donation box near the entrance if you want to support the maintenance of the garden.
author: Jackie S.

description:
The previous time I was here, the Botanical Gardens was known as The Strybing Arboretum. That was back in elementary school. So much has changed it seems, if my memory serves me right. Walking around today made me realize that there is an utter lack of guidance. I have absolutely no idea where I am going as pathways have no identification and maps are seldom seen. There is construction happening by the fountain but that's not a big deal. The best part was the redwood trees. Watch out for the feces around the pond where all the squirrels and geese congregate because people love to feed them.

I would recommend going on a sunny warm day. Today was a freezing summer day and even two layers of fleece didn't barricade the strong winds blowing from the Bay. 

There has got to be an exponential number of ways to complete walking around this garden. It may even take multiple visits to recognize your way. I still have no idea what my pathway around was since there seems to be a trail/path junction every 30 feet. Although not exactly comparable to the zoo, the upkeep of the place is average. There should definitely be more visitors. Even though I am a SF resident, I would not pay $7 for admission, nor the $5 college student with ID price. My friend did not bring her ID and had the admission prices been effective last Saturday instead of this coming Saturday, we probably would have turned around and left.
author: Dominic T.

description:
/I think there was a book titled, "The Secret Garden," and I'm pretty sure they're referring to this garden...well this place is pretty much a secret, hidden oasis hidden within Golden Gate Park. 

Admission to SF residents: 0. $7 for non-residents.

Took my parents here on Mother's Day and we thoroughly enjoyed the walk throughout the garden. It's much more like a big park with flowers here and there. I'm not too big into gardens but my mom is...and as long as she enjoyed it, that's that matters. 

You'll see squirrels running about looking for food...it's kind of cute how they just stare at you and follow you around looking for food. These squirrels wouldn't last an hour in the "wild."

If you're from SF and around the area, it's free so why not just come in and take a stroll?
author: David W.

description: The Botanical Garden is a civic gem, a living museum whose importance for San Francisco residents and visitors. It's free for residents of SF and a bargain for visitors at $7 per person. Find some solitude in our busy city among the redwood grove!
author: Lillian B.

description:
Years ago this was free for everyone. But just as all costs go up through the years, inflation, yadda yadda yadda, prices go up and the free becomes not free. 

Still free for SF residents! One of the many re asons why I love living here. Few bucks for visitors. HUGE park! so many flowers. Such a great peaceful walk. Not crowded at all. Lots of geese and squirrels BUT BEWARE THE SQUIRRELS WILL BITE!!!!!!!!! These ones here arent afraid of humans. I am for real.
author: Veranna N.

description:
The plants and landscapes in this park are amazing! However, the other very exciting aspect here are the fauna.... California Quail run about in the bushes, along with goofy little gray squirrels, and overhead are Allen's & Anna's Hummingbirds galore!

Also, admission is FREE and you can hang out from sunrise to sunset if you want!

Springtime is definitely a lovely time to go. The flowers and blossom trees are blooming, and the air is warm and the grass and foliage is fresh and green!

A million people have already yelped it, but I just wanted to add that the succulent garden here is AMAZING!! Also, the East Australian zone of the park is very cool... check it out and find your favorite spot. Everyone that comes here seems to find their own!
author: Shari D.

description: This is a great place!  Lots to investigate, but you have to take the small trails off the main path to see the best stuff.  Worth the money (you have to pay if you aren't a SF resident).
author: Simon A.

description: Went here on a slightly overcast monday and had a great time. My friends and I really enjoyed going through the different gardens. My favorite was the one with the native california plants and the fragrance garden. I loved walking through all of the gardens. Its such a peaceful experience right in the middle of a city that makes me anything but peaceful. :)  Overall it was a great experience for $7 and I'll definitely go back.
author: Stephanie S.

description: After leaving the Japanese Tea Garden we stopped here and it was a nice way to spend an hour or two. Exploring through the garden with plants from around the world. When I was smaller I used to come here many times as well, but visiting it as an adult is different I think because instead of just running around I was able to just appreciate the relaxing environment here and really pay attention to each plant and tree around me. For the lovely price of free, why not stop by here and appreciate this beautiful garden in San Francisco.
author: Carlos H.

description:
One of my absolute favorite parks! San Francisco Botanical Garden is huge, and contains such beautiful scenery and even wild life!

I love how they maintain the park, leaving it beautiful every time I visit. The grass is nice, and there are great trees and flowers. The only downside to the park is there are a lot of homeless people lingering around sometimes, and I always find smashed glass around the parking areas around the park. 

My favorite are the little lakes. If you watch carefully you will see turtles popping out of the water and sometimes the fish will also jump above the water. It's a wonderful place to stop by and take a walk or have a picnic to pass time. Gorgeous on sunny days.
author: Stine H.

description:
I've walked by this place for 3 years and never went in until the big Plant Sale last month! Man, have I been missing out! 

The wifey and I went home with an adorable bowl of mini succulents and three good sized individual succulents that are now rockin' the hallway outside our front door for $40! For everything! 

I can't wait for the succulent sale next month. Because, well, I kill everything that's not a succulent. Thus the lack of a pet or a child or ...
author: Kate P.

description: I could have spent all day here!  So much to look at and great places to just sit and gaze at everything!
author: Kimberly S.

description: Lost me with the addition of a fee. This is a public park. Its not a museum or an amusement park with rides. What's next? Charging a fee to run on the trails in the park?
author: E M.

description:
Spent half of a day here and loved every second of it. Wish the trails were marked more clearly but oh well. Sometimes getting lost is part of the experience.It's all very well maintained and amazingly beautiful. The forests, especially the redwoods, were awesome. Don't miss the succulent garden!
Will not go back to SF without coming here.
author: Isabelle Z.

description: Good relaxing place to go. And getting a deal through Yelp made it even better!
author: Eva H.

description: Who knew this place was even there? Apparently I didn't. In all fairness I went because a co-worker of mine is a tour guide there. Our tour guide (Stacie) was very friendly and well-informed. She didn't just list off information. She was very entertaining. The experience you have at the garden will vary on the season. I went in the winter so I imagine the best time to go is in the spring. Either way, you'll leave knowing a lot more about native SF fauna than you ever knew (or wanted to know). It also has a great lawn area where you can just hang out and read or do whatever. Very close to some good spots to eat once you're done lounging.
author: Carlos A.

description:
A paradise oasis in a big city. 

Surprises around every corner.

Walk thru the eucalyptus grove and you'll think you are in Muir Woods. 

Great people watching too!
author: Chris S.

description: People seem to forget about the Botanical Garden, it's FREE for residents! Whenever I get the chance, I come to the Botanical Garden and just wander around aimlessly among the various trees and flowers. It's really breathtaking scenery. There's even two ponds you can sit around and just reflect or watch passersby. It's great for photo ops and tourists and locals alike. Trust me, if you're out of town, it's worth the $7. I donate every time I go there.
author: Jessica G.

description: Bravo to the SF Botanical Garden for improving the signage in the gardens!
author: Desiree A.

description: Great place to spend an afternoon.  The Yelp 2 for 1 ticket price saves $7...
author: Alan Z.

description: If the weather is nice and you have a lovely friend take them here. It is free for residents, quiet, and relaxing. They need to do a bit more maintenance, mostly weeding. Not as nice as the Huntington Library and not as epic as Berkeley Botanical Gardens, but a great spot in the park none the less. I'm partial to the California Native and Redwood Grove sections.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Simply beautiful and gorgeous...and yup it's free.
and here are their flowers
http://www.flickr.com/photos/anakdewa/sets/72157594534021464/
author: toto h.

description:
One of my favorite getaways in San Francisco.  I've been coming here since I was a kid, and still find paths (albeit short ones) I've not walked before.  

Do yourself a favor, take a look at all the user-submitted photos, then plan yourself a trip here on a nice sunny day.  There's a bike-rack just outside the entrance to the Gardens (no bikes inside) - so put your camera in your backpack and go.
author: Jon M.

description: E. and I went for a stroll through the gardens after several coffees. I am happy to report there are several bathrooms within the 55 acres, centrally located. So much more was in bloom this time around. We went through the succulent section, Redwood Trail and South American species sections. Such a relaxing, easy place to be. I do ope the Board of Supes don't charge folks to come and look.
author: michael s.

description:
it's so beautiful and tranquil here.  I literally felt like I was at an oxygen bar! haha, just stick all that fresh oxygen straight into my veins!  
Favorite part? The garden of fragrances. BF and I spend 20 minutes sniffing everything!
author: Laila C.

description: From all the pictures on the website, it looks awesome! But for some reason when we came here it was more Botanical weeds than gardens... It's free, which is cool (especially since almost nothing else is free in Golden Gate Park), but I just didn't see anything that cool.  For some reason there was a lack of colors and luster... maybe I should give it another try some other time.
author: Denis S.

description:
The gardens and plants here make me dizzy and giddy with delight.  I love the habitats which allow you to go around the world without leaving 415.  

Just wish that the plants were better marked so I'd know what I'm gazing upon.  

The library near the entrance is quite fabulous.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description: I got some gorgeous pics of all different flowers and plants here. There were a lot of geese running around, don't mess with them...they will attack you! haha
author: Sandy N.

description: I'm so sad that this place is charging now but I think it's still really worth it to come. I made many visits from South Bay to this garden before they started charging. This is one of my most fave places in the city. It's humongous! I've never been to every single part of this garden, even with multiple visits. I can get lost in this place forever. Be prepared to spend an entire day if you love nature. When your feet get tired, lay down on the grass, take in the air, and eat lunch. Love the city.
author: Sally C.

description: I've been here once before.. and came by over the weekend... but they were closed by the time we were ready to go in (we went around Golden Gate Park--didn't realized they close their doors at 5PM!)  From what I remember, it's a beautiful park!  Definitely will come back for a romantic stroll. :)
author: Wendy W.

description:
How is it that so many of us, who spend so much time in this neighborhood, have NO IDEA such a wonderful garden is hiding just inside the park?   

In the back of my mind, I knew it existed, but I'd never really bothered to go visit until a few months ago, when I finally stopped by. 

Now every time the weather's decent, I take my lunch to the park.  My favorite spot is a sunny bench next to a pond filled with water lilies... a lot of times there's a beautiful white bird (maybe an egret) that hangs out in the pond.  I like to think of him as my lunch buddy.

It's the perfect place to get away from work for a little bit for some much-needed relaxation. :-)
author: Jane A.

description: We have been to very cool botanical gardens so I can't honestly give this place 5 stars, but they do have some very cool exhibits and it's affordable. You can get two tickets for $7 here on Yelp, they also offer a student discount if you have an ID and aren't near a computer/phone to do the Yelp deal. We loved the cool orchids and displays, it was a fun walk through the area. It's really humid in here like a jungle, you feel like you're in another world. Lots of unique stuff here, definitely worth a stroll through if you're in the area. The building looks very cool from the outside and if you hit it up around June there are tons of beautiful flowers out front.
author: Kerry B.

description: What a pleasant place, staffed with friendly folks, many of whom are volunteers. We went with a Yelp 2 for 1 coupon, which was an added bonus. Bus # 71 takes you right to the front door. Put it on your SF trip planner!
author: dg g.

description:
A few blocks from my hose... this is the perfect place to sit down and enjoy an afternoon lunch with friends. 

Really the only down side is the fact that I can not bring my dog in here with me... though I certainly understand with the AMAZING variety of plant-life that they have exhibited throughout the Gardens... and the desire to keep intact and unabused by ureic acid. 

Botanists could loose a weekend easily in the park, and lovers of nature can stroll easily through the different sections of the Garden and see a vast diversity of flora.
author: Jordan Y.

description:
This garden is huge, gorgeous and free. If I get tired of the California native section, with its huge blue ceonothus (California lilac) and yellow fremontodendron bushes, there are a lot of other gorgeous gardens. 
The Japanese garden in the botanic garden is lovely and FREE, compared with the nearby tea garden.
author: Vena V.

description:
A walk through here is very relaxing and educational, as all the bushes and trees are labeled with both common and scientific names. The whole park seems so far removed from the loud, hectic rush that is SF. And omg, the ducks and geese in the ponds here are sooooooo cuuuute!! My husband and I make a point of going to see them every now and then, even though we now live in Millbrae. If you go, keep in mind that they love strawberries in addition to the usual bread and crackers.

***Update: There is now a sign by the pond which reads: "Please do not feed the geese. Their feces have become a health and safety hazard to our visitors." Also, there were no geese in sight today. Boo.***
author: Ramon E.

description: Beautiful Gardens.  Certainly worth your time.  Plus, you are in San Francisco near the Academy of Sciences.  So much to do in the City.
author: Michael S.

description: I was a little disappointed with the botanical gardens.  They were beautiful, but didn't leave the impression that I was hoping for.  I think the idea is that you kind of get lost in the gardens, but the twisting and turning didn't give me a magical lost feeling, I just felt lost.  There were a lot of interesting plants to look at, but unless you're a plant enthusiast, it wasn't as much fun as I expected.
author: Keely D.

description:
Thank goodness we used the Yelp bargain to get in here. This was a big let-down in content compared to other gardens like The Huntington Library in LA; it was especially disappointing considering the increased rainfall in SF makes it MUCH easier to keep things alive and healthy compared to SoCal.

For a better use of your time and money, go across the way to the Japanese garden. Much more compact and better maintained.
author: D F.

description:
On our last day in San Francisco, we decided to spend a few hours at the SF Botanical Gardens, which we had noticed a few days earlier on our way to the Academy of Sciences.  This was a fabulous decision on our part.  I only wish I had known earlier how extraordinary this place is, so we could have arranged to spend more time here.  

How amazing to find this foliaged wonderland in the middle of the city!  Another reviewer used the word "sanctuary," and I completely agree.  We were there on a beautiful summer day and loved every minute we had of wandering, exploring, discovering and just taking it all in.  And it's all for free!  How lucky you local folks are to have this wondrous back yard at your disposal.  We'll definitely be making a return trip the next time we visit your beautiful city.
author: Elena M.

description: after going thru the japanese tea garden and the science center.  The park was just ok.   Lots of things to look at and a large area if you were going to hang out for some time.  But paying $7, if you are from out of town...I would probably say if you have a park in pretty much any city and you came into San Francisco...your time could be better spent elsewhere in the city.  It was nice and clean-- plenty to look at, but not sure its worth $7 to get in plus your parking cost.
author: Jerod M.

description:
Easily my favorite part of Golden Gate Park, the Strybing is a serene oasis.  It's large enough that it can accommodate many people without feeling crowded and it's the best place to watch the changing seasons.  And it's free.  

Food is allowed so you could have a picnic there or just bring in coffee & something sweet from Arizmendi Bakery and enjoy it inside.  My favorite spots are the peaceful Japanese area with its stone lanterns, the bamboo forest, the pretty new camellia forest, primitive garden, Chinese redwood trees, and the dark redwood grove.  There's a tree in there with bark that smells like vanilla near the Chinese redwoods.

The squirrels inside are the boldest I've ever met since they're used to being fed by humans.  They run up to you and then stand up with their paws extended for treats.  There are certain spots where you're sure to find cute little squirrels.  Technically, you're not supposed to feed them.  You'll probably be able to see quail especially during the spring time when the chicks are born.  Once, we even spotted the fox.  

You might run into a guitarist or flutist and on the weekends, you're likely to run into groups practicing tai chi.  The library has a nice collection of books on Golden Gate Park, plants, and gardening.  There's a tiny gift shop at the entrance closest to Lincoln along 9th.
author: Lolia S.

description:
This place is pretty nice.. and huge! There's lots of grass for people to just lay around on and hang out. 

I thought there would be more to it but for what it's worth (free admission) it's a great place to check out and walk around in. 

Very peaceful and relaxing way to just soak up the sun.

There were lots of turtles in the pond and these things in the water (I'm sure they were fish) that would stick out of the water and twirl their fins.. very intriguing as we really wanted a closer look but couldn't really see them still. The water must be that shallow??
author: C C.

description:
Caught up with NC here after a few hours at the County Fair Building one Saturday [Bizarre Bazaar or Bazaar Bizarre]. We hadn't seen each other in more than five years. There's something about this place that makes me comfortable and open. We talked about school, music, zines, and craftsy things. We traded old LDR stories - the boy in the east, the girl up north.

Take a walk alone, with one other, or in a group. Bring a blanket, a picnic, a book, a frisbee, a camera, none or all of those. Spend 30 minutes or all day here. 

I would recommend it to visitors wanting a break from the scene at Fisherman's Wharf or Ghirardelli Square. Something useful from the Botanical Garden website: The garden is open daily and is FREE. Weekdays: 8am to 4:30pm. Weekends & Holidays: 10am to 5pm. There are self-guided tours available for download from their website too. I'll be back for one of the free guided walks [daily at 1:30pm]. Plenty of parking, or grab the MUNI. It's not far from the de Young Museum, Japanese Tea Garden, or the San Francisco County Fair Building. So stop by if/when you're in the area! 

Four stars because I'm very certain that I'll have to stock up on Allegra or Claritin in the spring as my hay fever would act up here. Sorry, no dogs either.
author: Tinna H.

description:
We were a bit disappointed to see that large portions of the garden were closed off by ugly orange gates. Not to mention the lack of botanical-ness (haha). Besides this, and the large collection of man eating geese, it was a nice quick stroll that I'm hoping will be blooming with pretty flowers next spring. 

Check out the other places we visited in GG Park and some pics we took of an awesome little squirrel we met in the garden here http://www.sanfrancisconoobs.com/09-08-2009/golden-gate-park-adventure-japanese-tea-garden-sf-botanical-gardens-the-conservatory-of-flowers/
author: Casi C.

description:
I come here to walk around when I just need to unwind sometimes. It can get a little crowded on the weekends/in the summer but is large enough that you don't feel too crowded in. 

One of these days I am actually going to look at the names of all of these amazing plants from around the world, and increase my knowledge and vocabulary. For now I am just content to stroll and get lost in my own thoughts. 

This place is particularly beautiful in the spring when the flowering plants and trees are in bloom....oh, and its free, so no excuse not to check it out.
author: Drue C.

description:
HIDDEN SANCTUARY IN A BUSTLING CITY

When I am feeling stressed or overwhelmed, I like to spend an afternoon here.  There is something restorative about this place and I always discover a new and unusual plant.  My favorite areas are:

Moon-viewing Garden
This garden is so much more peaceful than the tourist trap known as the Japanese Tea Garden.  It is such a peaceful place to stroll and reflect.

Garden of Fragrance
I like the idea of a garden dedicated to fragrant plants.  This area is in need of refurbishing but I still like to walk through here and touch the scented geraniums.

Redwood Nature Trail
A magical trail through 100-year-old redwoods that feels like a real forest in the middle of a city.

The entrance gates close around 4:30 p.m. and beware of the aggressive squirrels.
author: Rob L.

description:
It's free...
it's pretty...
it takes my breath away. 
*sigh

when you have the time...
go there and find out for yourself.
author: John-Michael C.

description:
Otherwise known as Strybing Arboretum...

while this is by no means the best Garden in California (Huntington!!) it is a great, FREE, expansive place that can be relaxing and enlightening. 

Come on a sunny day - explore and aim to get lost... you may find yourself in a mini "redwood forest" one minute and in with all the crazy forms of cacti ("succulents") the next minute. Once you have re-found the fountain, you know know you made it back to the main entrance (FYI there are 3 entrance to Strybing around it in Golden Gate Park.)

The main entrance includes their super cute, mini bookstore and an area to grab a free guided walk at 1130am or 130pm.

When you want something a bit more exciting and are willing to spend the $$$ THEN go to the Conservatory of Flowers... until then, SFBG rocks!

HINT - THERE IS A FREE DOWNLOAD TOUR here 
http://www.antennaaudio.com/content/view/403/23/lang,en_GB/sample,tours/
AND MAP ON their website.
author: Jessica L.

description: 4.5 stars plus. Parking was a bitch-and-a-half Memorial Day weekend, but it was worth it! A wide variety of trees & plants (duh!), many of them flowering or sporting other parts intended to entice. We saw *almost* the whole thing (well, two of the four of us did)--nearly everything but the Garden of Fragrance (which is probably just as well, given my allergies). I can't imagine the work that must go into a place that has a redwood grove adjacent to a succulent garden. Signage is pretty good but could use a bit of improvement. Nice little gift shop with some unique chotchkes, cards, etc.
author: J R.

description:
So beautiful!!
I love taking a stroll around this part of the park any day of the week.
When the weather's especially warm  it's the perfect place to lounge in the warm grass with friends.. And you're surrounded by beautiful plants.
author: Ashley F.

description:
For review No. 1,400, I'm going medium school.  What is medium school, exactly?  Well, I'm not really sure.  I normally dig way back into the deepest, darkest recesses of my childhood memories for milestone reviews, but I recently realized that I've now lived in San Francisco long enough (seven years) to be able to review something nostalgic without having to remember anything prior to 2003.

Golden Gate Park is an amazing place.  Every time I have the slightest notion that I know it well enough to be bored by it, I unintentionally don't visit it as often as I normally do.  Why?  I'm afraid of it losing that magic.  But then I discover something new (or rediscover something old) about it, and it's like falling in love all over again with the same person--there's an excitement, but there's also a familiarity, and those two things combine in a beautiful, life-affirming way.

That's exactly what has happened with the San Francisco Botanical Garden.

I had come here a bunch of times soon after moving to the city, but there was about a four-year lapse in between visits.  Even when I resumed coming here semi-regularly, I wasn't terribly consistent, and months would pass before I'd remember just how special this place was.  And then I came here on my last birthday with my brother and my nephew, and I've probably visited more times in the last six months than I had in the previous six years.  It helps, of course, that I've been either under- or unemployed during this time--OK, it doesn't really "help" anyone, but having a lot of time on your hands is good for some things.

Plants are amazing.  We all know this, but we don't think about it often enough.  Yes, animals are amazing as well.  And certain geological features.  And views, especially of large bodies of water whose edges you can't see.  But plants.  Besides oxygen and water, they're the basis of all animal existence.  Actually, they produce oxygen and provide many animals with their only source of water, so there's no "besides" about it.  

I love the hard-to-find labels for the random South American plants.  I love the tree whose bark looks like it's made of copper.  I love all the redwoods and the weird hedged-in amphitheater that slightly resembles the site of some ancient cultic human-sacrifice locale.  I love the trails and the strange workers' buildings that are scarily deserted and inhabited at the same time.  I love walking up and then down.  I love the strange rain birds and sod and wood chips and non-botanical-garden-looking areas, the strange leaves that hang down and that squirrels often seem to fall off of, the grebes in their pond.  I absolutely love the fact that I've had important conversations with old friends here.  I sometimes regret the fact that I never brought other dear people here, and this makes me think about them and what they're doing, but even this regret is softened by the surroundings; appropriately enough, I'm often in the Botanical Garden when I'm thinking about these people, and although an intention is never as good as an action--it's never the thought that counts--it is comforting to be in a safe, reassuring place when I'm feeling down.

I also like to read here.  And to want to read here but to get too caught up in thinking to be able to get any reading done.  I wanted to write here at one point, but then I decided not to, and I haven't changed my mind about that yet.

I want to be angry that they're now charging non-San Francisco residents to visit, but I can't really be angry with the Botanical Garden.  I'm not even sure that it should be free for anyone, and I've always left some donation every time I've visited, even when I haven't been working.

Sometimes, it's too easy to get angry.  I know too many things bother me too much.  This doesn't really have anything to do with the Botanical Garden itself, but being here is definitely a healing experience, almost every time.  If you're able to, be sure to visit at different times of the day and in different weather.  You might not think a foggy day is the best time to visit a botanical garden, but you'd be surprised, especially if you've also been here when it's sunny.

It's been a little bit more than two-and-a-half years since I began writing Yelp reviews, and in one of the first reviews I wrote, I thanked Amy for introducing me to Park Chow.  Well, Amy, thank you for introducing me to the Botanical Garden as well.  I don't know whether you read Yelp or whether you even live in the Bay Area anymore; but I will always be glad I met you and that you, an East Bay-ophile through and through, introduced me, a recently minted San Franciscan, to one of the most beautiful places amid these forty-nine square miles of ours.  Even if we have to agree to disagree about Hemingway and other virtuosic suicides, I will always consider you an eminently intelligent, thoughtful, and beautiful person.  Be well.
author: John S.

description:
This is quite possibly the perfect place to engage in no-pressure, flirtatious banter with a cute boy from high school.  

Note: not *IN* high school, FROM high school!  :P
author: Karen F.

description:
This place is so cute! I want to take my mom here because she loves plants. It's also FREE to go!

I went here to learn more about the plants we are studying in a biology class. It was a really cute and informative field trip!
author: Kimberly L.

description:
For free.  How nice there are still some things you can enjoy sans $.  I've gone for class field trips, with my family and friends, and recently on a solo journey.   The park can get cool but on nice sunny SF days (which are rare but they do happen), it's a nice temporary escape.  

Whenever I'm in the area, I try to visit and see what cool new plants they have.  The Arboretum has a great plant sale once a month: http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org/plant_sales/plant_sales.htm  The staff is friendly and highly knowledgeable.  Prices are moderate and plants are healthy.

Scored some nice plants for work!  Will go back soon to see what else is available.
author: Jen L.

description: Awesome, GGP once again you've rocked my sox off.
author: Y S.

description:
It was once again time to take out-of-towners sightseeing.  The Botanical Garden is that reliable, eternally pleasing, FREE way to entertain visiting relatives and friends.

Your friends will love the Botanical Garden if they:

1. Love trees and hiking and are generally outdoorsy.
2. Are older than 40 (and extra points for aging hippies)
3. Talk about plants and gardening.
4.  Smoke weed regularly.

Our guest met all four criteria and was indeed an aging hippie -- JACKPOT!  He was all smiles and left the botanical garden elated.

Score for Cyn and Eva, master SF tourguides.  

The Botanical Garden's right at 9th and Lincoln, right across from the Japanese Tea Garden, the Shakespeare Garden, and the De Young.  It's over 55 acres so you and your guest will take at least an hour or two to explore.   Parking can be a bitch and the parking lot ain't cheap -- but even the walk through this area of the park can be worth it.
author: Sid D.

description:
No matter the occasion or need, Strybing Arboretum is perfect. Third-grade field trip to learn about the native plants of California? Check. Picnic with old family friends? Check. Desire to feel like you're living with the dinosaurs? Check. Want to find some turtles? Check. Calm place to walk while talking with a new acquaintance? Check. Place to get lost without any danger of remaining so? Check.

See? It's perfect. Don't believe me? Go there and see for yourself.
author: Katie I.

description: A nature photographer's wet dream.  I love this place. :)
author: Shannon N.

description:
Dear fellow SoMa dwelling vampire-esque commrades:

It's ok to go outside during the day. The sun won't melt your skin. It's pretty here.  The park  smells nice, too.

Sincrely,

Matthew
author: Matthew R.

description:
Very big attractive garden, dog-friendly, picnic friendly, and Frisbee friendly.

Other than what's already been mentioned by others I like the fact that it is marked by a region of the Earth, and that the plants & flowers in that area are of that area, and smell like that area. The Southern Africa section in particular smells like Southern Africa and my husband finds it really calming.
author: Valerie F.

description: $7 is a bargain!  This place is absolutely ENORMOUS and beautiful!  If you dig flowers, this is such an amazing escape from the City within the City.  You can spend ALL day here without a problem.  There are places to sit, rest and enjoy a meal.  I guess the only fault I can find with the garden is that it isn't advertised enough!  Or maybe that's why it's great for the lack of people.  If you get there early, you have the whole place to yourself.
author: R G.

description:
As I was strolling through the Botanic Gardens (aka the Strybing Arboretum), eating a Mexican rice Popsicle that I had just bought from a friendly man pushing a cart with a bell on it, I started thinking about all the lovely things for which the garden would be idea. Eating cheese and drinking wine whilst sitting upon a red and white checkered sheet, for instance. Practicing Tai Chi in the early light of the morning. Making paper boats and floating them in the pond, waiting giddily to see how the turtles and the water birds that live there would react. A spirited game of frisbee. Making out while hiding in the bushes next to the tiny creek. Or, taking hallucinogenic drugs and staring dopily at the strange flowers. 

And, right about the same time I had that last thought, I noticed the squirrels. Dozens of them -- every single one fearless. They crawl right up to your shoes to beg for food -- you could kick one if you wanted to. But you don't want to because they're squirrels and squirrels are adorable. Right? And so I just stomped my feet and the one that was about to crawl up my pants leg scampered back. But he only scampered back like 6 inches! And, five more squirrels emerged form the underbrush. Theses little fuckers are probably responsible for no less than half of the children that go missing in San Francisco. I don't doubt that these squirrels could devour any living creature weighing less than 95 lbs. I started throwing berries at them and running for my life.

As I was catching my breath, I decided that, while most of my ideas about the Botanic Garden still held true, the hallucinogenic drug thing probably wouldn't be the best option.
author: Ben P.

description:
I'm not a plant person, but I love this place.

The first time I stepped in, it was because my friends needed to use the restroom, so I didn't see much.

The second time I went in, it was because it was free.  And although I'm not a plant person, I am an animal person, so I loved the ducks and squirrels here.  I was also impressed by the moon-viewing garden (which I didn't know was called that at the time, since we were just wandering around randomly) and thought that it would be a nice place to just sit some day.

Since then I also like the Redwood Trail as a nice place to shut out the world as fewer people go by there.  Unfortunately, it is closer to the traffic, which does ruin the experience a bit.

The Golden Gate Park Band also plays on the lawn near the main entrance on Sundays starting from 1PM until about 2:45.
author: Yeh F.

description: Absolutely loved it.  Wonderful place to rejuvenate and absorb some lush natural beauty after traipsing about the maze of dirty concrete streets that is SF.
author: Jacklyn P.

description:
Let me tell you a little story about SF Botanical Garden during the Memorial Day weekend. My friends and I decided we wanted to forgo the entire BBQ experience (all of us were vegetarians at one point) and take in a little nature instead. This was mostly from the suggestion of my biology major friend, who wanted to impress us with her extensive knowledge and large vocabulary of everything plant-ey. We also thought that since it was memorial day weekend, and as such most people spend time with their families, going to the Botanical garden would be nice and relaxing. 

WRONG! 

Everybody and your cousin's hairdresser was there! There were little kids complaining about smelly flowers, depressed teenagers trying to escape family gatherings, hazardous flying frisbees, fat little pugs chasing the cheeky little squirrels and a Chinese WEDDING PHOTO SHOOT (honestly, point taken). After dodging out of the way of a toothy grandmother who looked like she might trap us in her gingerbread house around the next bend, we finally decided to ditch the little paths and go for the open grassy fields, kite-bearing frisbee tossers or no. And all of this while enduring bio facts like 'hey, Aminah, did you know that cashew oil is used in airline brake fluid?' No, I didn't. Did you?

Once dropping into that grassy safety, ready to get sun burnt and dehydrated, I thought all was well. Until my bio friend started with the facts. Did you know that daisies are actually a combination of two flowers, and that each white petal is a single flower comprised of five petals fused together? Well, now you do.
author: Kalyani Y.

description:
THE BEST part of GG Park! 

Flowers and plants of all kinds come together in this AMAZING garden. Signs naming each are interesting to look at. Everything from artichokes to birds of paradise. 

Large grassy areas, big trees to sit under, benches in the sun, pond with ducks, and everything else in between. 

Walk towards the back and find a pretty little waterfall.  Nearby are tons of little squirrels scurrying around. 

Perfect place to take a nice walk on a sunny San Francisco day. Bring a camera, there will be tons of beautiful things you'll want to remember.
author: kristen b.

description:
Huge! Good price for entry ($5 student; $7 adult). Glad they had a native-plant garden, but I was actually much more impressed with Santa Cruz's native plant garden. In particular, the labelling was often difficult to determine which plant it was referring to.
Great place for a date b/c you can walk for ages in a beautiful setting.
Loved the Redwoods forest section. The understory of Redwood Sorrel (a small, purple-flowering plant) was peaceful.
author: Christina Z.

description:
