Wasn't particularly impressed by the gardens, though I did just go and it's not like there should be a bunch of flowers or anything. It was a nice stroll around the gardens, very relaxing. I like the hidden trails, pretty cool to wander around on. Is it just me, or is the California section really sad? I mean, it's basically just a bunch of scrub brush... 

I would guess that it's a lot different/better in the spring and summer, so I'll be back and update my review then...
author: The Sock S.

description:
Came here after stepping into the Japanese Tea Garden..

Squirrels are awfully friendly here..

BlueJays will fly by and eat nuts and fruits off your hands if you hold it out

Plenty of different flowers and trees

And a big plastic flower at the entrance~

Come down on a nice day, it'll be worth your time....only if you like looking at plants...
author: phillip w.

description:
Not much to see during the cold weather, but it's still a beautiful place. Very peaceful. A nice place to take a walk. Most importantly, FREE!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Just go get lost. 
This place is so lovingly maintained and there are so many wonderful little things to find. (Like clean public park bathrooms. Holygoodgoddamn.) 
Just beware the sprinklers. I believe that they may be linked to a video-moniter lined room controled by a bunch of guys with a deep appreciation for physical comedy.
author: Mer S.

description:
Me sitting in the redwood grove: "How long do you think it took to plant these trees?"

Him: *stares in disbelief at my statement* "How long did it take to plant the redwoods?"

Me: "Oh... right. I just had a me moment, didn't I?"

Him: "Yes, and that's a bit of an understatement...."

This is one of the most beautiful places in Golden Gate Park. They have a large selection of plants, an amazing area for picnics, and makes for great photo shoots with friends or boyfriends.

The first time I came here was with a friend last summer. He is originally from Australia and New Zealand and hadn't been back for quite some time. He loved seeing so many plants he remembered, falling into the trees, and getting lost in the secluded areas of the botanical garden.

Also amazing that they have an after-hours gate too.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Beautiful garden. Huge garden. More like an educational park than a garden. 

I explored each area the other day, and have concluded that I need to come back to find the best nooks and crannies where I can sit and read. The dirt trails are a fun and quiet getaway from the paved roads and the bustling urban landscape.

But! the squirrels really creeped me out. They followed me in the trees and down the paths and were definitely not shy in approaching me. I didn't feel comfortable being completely alone and surrounded by squirrels. People should stop feeding them!!! The turtles are cool though.
author: Liz L.

description:
This place is perfect to hang out and have a picnic with friends. Maybe even pull out a frisbee (which I can't really play, but you could bring one), bring your pooch, and walk around barefoot and people watch. 

Yes, SF is a great place to people watch....
author: Anna S.

description: What a beautiful place. Redwood trees, lakes, plants, you can have a picnic, read a book...Awesome! And it's free for residents :)
author: Jasmina T.

description: They've lost me, with the gates and the id check and the out-of-towners fee.  I urge everyone not to pay their fee.  This place was free and open to the public my whole life.
author: Ben K.

description:
Want to get away from it all? The fast cars, loud trains, screaming children or just about anything? Well come on down to the Arboretum and get lost in the many paths and hidden knolls. 

The Arboretum is one of those special places in San Francisco where all time stands still for you to enjoy a small quiet picnic and an afternoon of reading to yourself in the sun (or more likely, the fog).

This is a place where you can come with a large group and have a party picnic, with the frisbee or come for quiet solitude. Obviously it is always much more crowded on the weekends, but I have always been able to find a place to sit by myself when I needed it. Aside from being a nice place to spend some quality "me" time, the Arboretum is home to many rare and beautiful plants, and an informative plant library.

Technically this place closes around 5PM, but any good San Francisco knows that it is no challenge to slip through those bars and enjoy the sweeping lawns all by yourself or with friends.
author: Allyson S.

description: A park within a park, and a great escape from life in the city without having to leave it.  Even on the sunniest days, it never seems to be crowded, and the deeper into it you go, the less likely you are to have your peace of mind disturbed. Much of the clearly marked flora is grouped by its global origins. The squirrels will eat right out of your hand; the predatory seagulls near the pond are more aggressive and less friendly. A great place to bring a blanket, a picnic lunch, and that three-inch-thick history of the world you've been meaning to finish for the last six months.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Dear irresponsible Bay Area parents: every patch of grass is NOT a playground.  Botanical gardens are for sure not playgrounds. 
 The open areas here are always filled with screaming children and today I literally saw a father "teaching" his teen age son to fight. 
Uh, not only is this a place where people come to look at and experience plants and flowers, it is in the middle of one of the biggest urban parks in the nation - there are plenty of appropriate place for these activities just minutes away. 
This place would be much better if they charged admission and laid out some very basic ground rules, so they lose one star for free admission. 

Other than that, it is  huge, always changing, interesting at all times of the year and has so many incredible details you could never see them all. It is really great.
author: Damon S.

description:
Free?  Free!  FREE!  I like free.  Wahoo... something that is free!

Gardens=beautiful flowers.  
Where were the beautiful flowers?  All I saw were sprinklers and grass (oh, and a bunch of high school students volunteering with the gardening.  I thought that was pretty cool!).

I was just at Buchard Gardens in Victoria (British Columbia, Canada).  Maybe I have a skewed opinion.

I'll visit again sometime and hope there are more beautiful flowers.
author: Juliana T.

description: Great collection! Especially to draw! The prehistoric collection is my favorite, especially the rhubarb. SF residents get free entry!
author: Erika C.

description:
We've probably visited this location more than any other since I've moved here. There's always something new to discover - seasonal plants and flowers blooming, duck drama and turtle action at the pond, and the squirrels are something else :)
I spend a lot of my time here taking photos of flowers, which I can never remember the names of - there are so many beautiful things! The succulents are especially wonderful - I had no idea there were so many varieties! I could probably visit here every weekend and not get bored... Thank you, McLaren, Strybing, and San Francisco!
author: Marianne S.

description:
This Garden is magnificent. Especially nice if you are walking and talking with a gorgeous girl. One from high school. Not  -IN-  high school,  -FROM-  high school. 

*assentful nod*
author: Dan S.

description: Amazing.  The docents here are very bright, very knowledgeable, and very patient.  Beautiful place.
author: Mosey S.

description: AH-MAZ-ING!!!  From the prehistoric plant life to the Japanese tea gardens, this is very impressive and I look forward to coming back to the Bay area just to relive this experience!  Great way to spend a beautiful afternoon!
author: Jessica E.

description:
I adore the arboretum! My husband and I used to live at Lincoln and 4th, so we used to walk down here all the time. Now that we're living up in Marin, we hadn't been in ages...but it was just a lovely in the almost-winter as it is the rest of the year! Meandering paths, always a little hidden vista just around the corner.

Okay, yes the squirrels are seriously bold, but we saw a pheasant! I've never seen one in person - it was digging up the roots of some plant and just ignored us, as we happened upon it not 2 feet away. Beautiful!

I can't wait to come back when the magnolias are in bloom!
author: Jennifer C.

description: In what I can only call "my luck" I came out here to see the gardens while on my SF trip from Miami... and of course, their whole theme was "tropical plants" aka... my back yard :o
author: Frank E.

description:
I'll skip over my favorite spots in the Garden that have already been mentioned, and simply mention that you must push on!  Don't walk through the main gate, get as far as the lake or Chile or Australia and plop down for the day:  the most wonderful part of the Garden is the redwood forest, toward the back.  You follow thin little trails that are completely engulfed by trees, breathing air that smells heavy and green, safe like an arboreal womb.

Some of the most undisturbed spots are among the greatest.
author: Jon B.

description:
The plant sales held here are awesome!  Local plants, resourceful sellers, and reasonable prices.  There's also a book portion of the sales with used books priced starting at a dollar.

These sales are monthly.  Check the calendar http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org/plant_sales/plant_sales.htm
author: Sarah X.

description: calmness in the middle of the busy city
author: P J.

description:
a true gem hidden in the concrete jungle that is san francisco. i went today to take pictures for a biology project , and i loved every minute of it!  as cheesy as it sounds, the sun was shining (a few hours before the rain started), the flowers are in bloom,  the birds were chirping, and the kids on a field trip were laughing up a storm. overall, the park is broken up into different sections: primitive plants, native california plants, plants from every continent, a moon viewing garden, a nursery, and even a children's garden just to name a few. there's nothing more invigorating than stretching out on the grass and watching the clouds pass by or sitting under a tall redwood tree, drinking tea. 

there is no admission fee and that feels twice as nice when you find street parking. unfortunately, tours arent given daily and on the days they are offered, it's only twice a day.  but hey, who really needs a guide? just jump in and discover it for yourself. you actually might like it. the botanical garden is located across the street from the japanese garden and the de young museum ( check out the vivienne westwood exhibit here!!! ). so take advantage of what sf has to offer and make an entire day out of all your options!

by the looks of it, kids come on field trips, pregnant women take walks in their preggo packs, and old couples take pictures while walking hand in hand. actually, it looks like a great place for a run too! what a great way to unwind, get off the couch and out of the house,  or to test out that new camera. just dont feed the squirrels, the birds, or the turtles in the australian section. yeah, thats right... turtles!
author: marlene m.

description:
This place is my temple.

You can lay on the giant lawn under a huge cypress tree and read. You can stroll through a Japanese garden or sit and look at California's wildflowers. You can lay on your back and look up at redwoods. You can hide in the cloud forest or play make believe in the Jurassic garden. The biblical gardens are cool too. There are benches at the top of a set of stairs in the azaleas. Bring peanuts and feed the squirrels - they will eat out of your hand. :)

I have spent many an afternoon here - alone and with others - and every one of them has been amazing.

Even writing this review makes me feel more serene.
author: Neely M.

description: WOW Amazing plant life.  There are some seriously extraordinary plants here.  And the overall atmosphere in the park itself is outstanding.  I was there on an overcast day (I know big surprise for SF) and I have to say it was one of the most amazing experiences I have ever had on such a day.  And really, $7 to see that beauty - my coffee is more expensive - almost.
author: Joe H.

description: The gardens are beautiful. Tuesday afternoon gave us the place to ourselves.
author: Rachel B.

description: I have decided that I will have my backyard lanscaped to look like the back of the Botanical Garden.  There is this one great little gazebo covered in flowering vines from which you can see a good portion of the back side of the Garden.  Everything there was aromatic and lovely, even the squirrels who seemed to udnerstand my saying "No!" when they tried to eat my sandwich.
author: Traci G.

description: I just moved to San Francisco and I came across this while strolling thought the park and it happened to be a free day. The free days happen once a month but I am not sure which day but it was beautiful. I will be coming back next month for the next free day I think I will make it a monthly thing!
author: Lauren L.

description: One of the best places in SF! It is so full of life. I really enjoy going here and just being able to see all the plants and flowers. I could spend every day here!
author: Star Z.

description:
To be honest, I'm not a fan of nature, because I don't like dirt and bugs.  But this place isn't so bad. There are nice (stroller-friendly) paved paths so you can enjoy the view without getting rocks in your socks.  If you do feel like roughing it, there are real trails too, the kind made of dirt instead of concrete. 
 
I like the bizarre-looking plants (check out the protea) that look like they're from Jurassic Park or those planets on Star Trek (but really they're from New Zealand or South Africa or Australia).  There's a big pond with a heron and an egret.  On July 4 a bunch of folks were picnicking (someone even brought a grill!)
author: angela n.

description: Unfriendly for persons and for pets. SF is becoming an unfriendly IT city
author: Luis I.

description: Gorgeous. Worth taking a few hours to explore. One of the best points for me is that I went on a Saturday and it didn't feel crowded, which was great. It felt like my boyfriend and I could explore this place with a really good amount of privacy, which is such a rarity in this city. I didn't even mind paying the $7 since I don't have a local ID.
author: k h.

description: The gardens are really big and free for San Francisco residents.  Definitely well furnished, but chose your season of visit wisely!
author: Caroline D.

description:
My visit here was in late winter, and as carlos says [http://www.yelp.com/biz/san-francisco-botanical-garden-san-francisco-2#hrid:qW4vej33vZGUr6WkMDO1bg], your experience will vary depending on the season in which you come.  For me, it was a little disappointing not to see more color.  If that's what you're into, the Conservatory of Flowers [http://www.yelp.com/biz/conservatory-of-flowers-san-francisco] would be the way to go.  Then again, you can't beat FREE!

What is there to see exactly?  Mostly plants suited for the Mediterranean climate, so those from the west coasts of Chile, Australia, and South Africa, in addition to those that grow natively here.  Check out the full list here [http://www.sfbotanicalgarden.org/Gardens/page3.html].

I took the 1:30 PM tour, which lasted 1.5-2 hours.  If you love learning about the plants, this is a great option.  The guides are very knowledgeable.  I just wish I would have learned a bit more in advance so I would be able to suck that information up.

Magnolias were in bloom everywhere, which made for some nice backdrops.  The squirrels are very friendly, coming up to you even, although they won't sit still.  My guide said that it's because they are trying to get food from you.  Do not feed them!

My final stop was the library, which I would not recommend for browsing.  It's really only good if you are looking for something specific.  One cool thing was that they seem to have newsletters for almost any gardening topic you can imagine.  I saw three or four different ones dedicated just to orchids.

I'll be back in the spring/summer.
author: M C.

description:
This 55-acre garden located in Golden Gate Park is amazing. You can spend a day here. It's a great place to look at the various plants and flowers and enjoy nature. My favorite part of the garden is the redwood grove. It's so peaceful and relaxing. I could sit there forever. 

It's open 365 days a year and best of all, free!
Weekdays: 8:00 am to 4:30 pm
Weekends & Holidays: 10 am to 5 pm
Guided walks are given daily at 1:30 pm

There are tons of squirrels running around here, and they aren't afraid of you. So cute! Not for the sciurophobic.
author: Jen P.

description:
Gunnera Manicata - my favorite plant, available for viewing in the Prehistoric section of the gardens.  Each LEAF can have a diameter of up to 10 feet.  Just don't try to view them in January; the park cuts them down to a nubbin in Winter to allow a period of dormancy.

If Anne Geddes could see these leaves she would definitely dress up a baby and perch it on one.
author: Saskia v.

description:
Very nice place and very big. Diverse wildlife there too: ducks, geese, hummingbirds, gophers, squirrels, coyote (staff alerted), CA quail w/ chicks, rat (it's a big city).

It would be nice to be better maintained: some of the trails are not marked well and have plants overgrowing on them, and I saw more weeds and thistles than I would have liked.

Great exhibits as they show why they have what they have and why it can work in SF (like the cloud forest plants). Their native section was very helpful for me to seek out for my yard now.
author: Tony T.

description:
Like most reviewers...I think this place is great.

Been living here for years and never knew this existed. The garden is peaceful with a huge variety of plants and species. We came here early to beat the crowd and to find street parking. This place is free, and accepts donations (well deserved). Would definitely come again.
author: Mike L.

description:
I love the Arboretum cause it's free and there are great picnic spaces where I can lay around and read.  It's educational and fun!

If you go across the street, Park Gyros is pretty good.
author: Betty L.

description:
My favorite place in GG Park.  It is huge and populated by so many exotic breeds of plants and flowers.  My parents delight in horticulture so I took them here and they were in rapture...and I liked it alot too!

The variety between the different collections is just amazing.  The garden is subdivided into gardens dedicated to different lands and climates.  There's nothing quite like it!  Before long, you will feel like you are on a safari or maybe in a jungle, surely not in a city!
author: Femita J.

description:
Rockin'.  Free.  Close. 

The place to visit when you need a shot of green to repair, reenergize and reboot your Chi.  I have seen Blue Herons, our favorite turtles, California Quail (and Quib in tow) and even a Red Fox frolicking in this little slice of Wonderland.

The Docent tours are under-rated as a means to learn about the diversity of this place.  

The natural inclination is for people to flock to the Tea Garden... but that's sort of like paying a high cover to get into that over-hyped club  when the rollickin one is just round the corner for those in the know.
author: Jim W.

description: So much potential here. I know SF is broke despite the record amounts of wealth, but I was still disappointed with the general upkeep of the place. Lots of nearly dead or dying plants, lots of plants placed in spots still in their black plastic containers, lots of plants with their nursery plastic tags still on them. Not so much mystique when you see the plant was purchased from a valley grower.. Lots of plant placards just sitting there with no plant, or sitting in the middle of what was a pile of weeds/dandelions. The California exhibit looked deserted and there was a GIGANTIC area by the kids garden with literally nothing there. With some money, love, and care this place would be five stars. Why not showcase more color! It never freezes here, and there are few heat loving plants which plain won't grow here !
author: Joe H.

description:
i enjoyed my container gardening class here today, and have always loved wandering through the grounds and secret paths of the botanical garden and strybing arboretum.  i still can't believe it's free.  

it can be cold so dress in layers.  but when it IS sunny, it is truly glorious.
author: Aimee B.

description: The word that popped into my mind when thinking about this place was "serene." The garden is lush and calming, and I like how you walk through different "continents" of plants. We were here on a Saturday afternoon, and it was not crowded at all. It's amazing to find something like this in the middle of the city.
author: Sonia M.

description: The City has ruined the aboretum. The park had always been free, meaning you could spend five minutes or five hours in the space. Now bringing a family of four to the arboretum costs $24. I'm not sure a family can justify a quick jaunt to the arboretum after the De Young or Academy of Sciences anymore. Let's remember that the arboretum is a park, not a museum. It should be open; there should not be a line. Moreover, this fee has raised very little money!
author: Michael L.

description:
I'll spend hours here walking around and enjoying a nice day.  This is a great place to sit outside and read a book, listen to Iron & Wine on your iPod, and just feel good about life.  Amazingly, despite the proximity to Lincoln Street and 9th Avenue, you can often forget you are in the middle of a city.  

My favorite areas are next to the pond (where I like to spend a minute or two watching the turtles), the Moon Garden (did I get that right), walking through the New Zealand section (a favorite for the park's squirrels too), and the open field area that the New Zealand section feeds into.  

Living only two and a half blocks from here makes me happy to live in the Inner Sunset despite the fog (which doesn't really bother me all that much anyways).
author: Matthew H.

description:
It's amazing how I can get away from it all while in the middle of it all. In Central Park, you can pretty much see high-rise buildings no matter where you go, reminding you that you ARE in the city. 

But here in San Francisco, we are blessed to have the arboretum. What a delightful place. Wonderful collection of palms, thought I wish there were more.  That would make this place place 5 star in my book.  

I love this place, including scurrying quails and bossy squirrels.
author: Erika K.

description:
I used to feed ducks and various fowl the non-Crunchberry bits from my Cap'n Crunch. They loved the stuff... suckers.

I love this place because it teaches you about plants and it's free. The last time I came here, there was an orchestra playing that filled the whole place with this nostalgic vibe. It was awesome.

Enter the park and go left to see some freaky big plants.
author: Keane L.

description:
Dinosaurs! Unicorns! Ridiculously cute squirrels! Its all here! (maybe moreso in my imagination, but a man can dream)

This place is the bestest on a sunny day! It feels like you're walking through some kick ass open space preserve in marin somewhere, yet its right smack dab in the middle of the city- sweet! 

And the snoozability rating is like 6 stars. I know it may seem a bit over the top, but seriously. Remember those wonderful, lazy days of  playing hookie from that lame (insert annoying college class here) class and instead of getting your learn on, you took the time honored tradition of sleeping instead? Well, the golden days are back- and they are all over the wonderfully kept green fields of Strybing Arboretum. cost of admission? Just a dream.....
author: Tim V.

description:
Um, it's free, need I say more?

Okay I will, but being free is just one aspect to the greatness that is the the SF Botanical Garden. It's massive and there are a lot of places to just kind of lounge around and read, like most people were doing. And if you actually wanted to, just go look around at all the diverse flora they have there. Some of it was kind of muddy but other than that, this place is awesome on a good day (like today) to just take a peaceful stroll to stop and smell...everything
author: Dustin H.

description:
One of the most peaceful places in San Francisco.  Plus its free.  

This is my fortress of solitude.  I come here when i want to get away from the world, and just be around peaceful flowers and trees.  I'm surprised that there usually aren't too many people here, and i pretty much have free range over the whole place.  

There are benches all over, but my favorite is the hidden benches with the redwood trees.  No too many people come through there so you are not distracted if you just want to read a book, or write some thoughts in complete serenity.

There are a plethora of squirrels that roam free throughout the garden, and if you bring some nuts they will all gather around while you feed them.

All the plants and trees and flowers are all pretty well labeled with many numerous paths that allow walking through without getting lost.  I've been here many times with sunny weather, as well as a few while it was pouring rain.  Anytime i come here i am completely brought to peace.

It is also a great place to go on a date.  I think it would impress a girl if you bring her here, and have a little knowledge about a few plants, and stroll through the park.  I mean, I have done it before.
author: Terence P.

description:
My girlfriend and I go here to take photos and feed squirrels (we know we're not supposed to, dammit).  Often times we get cute photos of squirrels munching on peanuts, but you have be quick on the shutter since these little buggers are fast.

When you are in the confines of the gardens you truly feel as-if you are no longer in the middle of a major city.  Instead you are surrounded by an assortment of plans and flowers from different parts of the world, grouped together by continent of origin.  A nice treat amidst a hectic San Franciscan lifestyle.

Be warned though, it's easy to get lost track of the time when you are inside.  So be sure to dedicated a whole day if you want to spend it walking around.  On top of that, the front enterance of the park is directly across from the Japanese Tea Garden and the de Young Museum (and soon to re-open in 2008 the new Academy of Sciences), which means that there is even more to see.

Parking gets hectic on warm weekends, but drive up and down the street a few times and you'll find an open spot quickly.

Come visit, you'll won't regret it.
author: Serge S.

description:
The tours led by the volunteer docents are very informative and might show you some things you haven't noticed before, but you can also go it alone and just read the labels with the plants' names. You don't even have to wait for a sunny day-- the rain brings out some wonderful fragrances from the plants. Along the paths, there are park benches that people have dedicated in memory of their friends and family. One of them says, "She loved this place." I love that.

Be sure to also visit the Conservatory of Flowers, which is a greenhouse that's a short/medium walk from the Arboretum.
author: Rosie R.

description:
Love, love, love this place!!

Perfect start to a lovely day in the park. Go when it's warm, so you can actually enjoy the gardens without freezing. Follow every path, so you can find hidden treasure around every corner. Squirrels are everywhere, so remember not to feed them. Now is the time to go because Spring is here and all the flowers are blooming.Free parking and admission into the gardens. Check it out!
author: Kelli H.

description:
This is one of my favorites of the park.  I am regularly here, pondering the troubles and frustrations of life while looking at the beauty in the park.  It almost feels like I get a tour of the world, through its fauna and flora.  

My tip:  Take the little hidden paths to find some of the most spectacular areas of the park.  Close your eyes and breath deep, opening them slowly and look at the world with fresh eyes.
author: Meredith N.

description: Beautiful, spacious and relaxing. Great experience but avoid busy holidays and weekends.
author: Mike P.

description:
I love the arboretum. Beautiful gardens, the succulents and cacti are worth the visit. Great for nature photos all over the gardens and you can always find a nice bench to sit and enjoy the view.

The arboretum is free, but they do have a donation container by the entrance where the little bookstore/gift shop is.  I always try to throw in a couple of bucks. :)
author: Sabrina L.

description:
I've made it a habit in my travels to sample all local arboreta I come across, as I grew up making regular pilgrimages out to Chaska MN to see the U of MN's landscape arboretum, one of the larger ones in the country, and the home of the research that gave us winter hardy azaleas and Honeycrisp apples (along with a dozen or more other cold-zone varieties).  Yes, I'll be cocky and say I like to see how other places stack up with their botanical gardens.
Well, San Francisco, I stand before you and tell you this:  I am impressed.  I was skeptical when I saw the small footprint this garden has in the park, but man can you pack a lot of different habitats into a mere 55 acres!  I counted six continents represented (seven if you count Gondwana in the Primitive Plants garden).  There was a lot of construction going on when I was there, but most of the grounds were open.  The garden of fragrance was a hidden treat, as were all the different regional gardens (New Zealand, SE Asia, Meso-American Cloud Forest, Etc.).  I must say however, after living for a year on the Humboldt County coast, I find the Redwood Trail to be adorable.  I just kept thinking, 'you guys are what six, maybe seven decades old?  spring chickens!'  In a couple centuries though those trees will be quite impressive.
Overall, I wish there was more room to expand each climate zone.  I'd love to see a Mediterranean garden that encompasses more than a single acre of park, for example, so as measured against size and research capability I give you four stars, but as a measure of biodiversity, you are head and shoulders above anything I've seen so far in my humble travels.  Cheers to you, San Francisco, for putting more species in a tiny space than I think I've ever seen before!
author: Kevin M.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to head for when I:
a.  have nothing better to do
b.  want to feel like I've explored the world when I've barely left my own backyard
c.  am asked to suggest picnic spots
d. want to get lost and found really quickly.

Warning:  I ran into a bunch of rats in the New Zealand section one time.  I would assume they roam.
author: michelle g.

description:
i've been here twice and absolutely loved it both times. how could i not?  it smells amazing and it's FREE! you walk around and get lost in a park-full of beautiful flowers, trees, and plants. and i mean it when i say you can get "lost". it literally took us half an hour to find our way to an exit, but no complaints here. 

my favorite "plants" were the cacti. they had a whole area of various cacti that all looked awesome. ps, i just love saying "cacti". i love going to the pond and watching all the little turtles climb on top of each other on a giant rock. i love watching the blue jays hopping around and the squirrels eating nuts. it's just a great place to enjoy, whether it be with that special someone, or by yourself. check it out if you havent gone.
author: Andrew T.

description: Beautiful place... I actually got engaged here. Underneath a beautiful tree... Make time to visit. Its worth it.
author: Angela Q.

description:
My company did a volunteer project at this site and it was my first time seeing this area. Quite amazing if you ask me and anytime GGP is sunny def made up for the sunburn a lot of the group *unfortunately* got. Normally you have foggy but it was windy. 

Great place to chill if we weren't volunteering!
author: S L.

description: The Botanical Gardens is like a little slice of heaven in the city! I have a hard time remembering I live in an urban area when I'm there. And since it's still free for SF residents, it's surprising how many nooks you can find in the gardens where there's not another person in sight.
author: Melissa A.

description: This place is amazing! Lots of nooks and crannies to get lost in! Jsut watch out for the not so shy, vicious squirrels!
author: Chris B.

description: Love this place - I wish they would stop charging for out of towners. Or at least don't charge if you have an 'in-outowner' with you. This is the best place to take your non-college or only fun with alcohol friends. A walk with your visiting parent, uncle, grandparent, cousin, grand-kids, recovering alcoholic etc. is perfect here. Its not usually that crowded and you can get lost in there pretty easily. The Australian area and the redwood area are my favorite. Perfect place to bring a book and enjoy little "Micro Environments" without out normal GG park vagrants and dog pushers.. SFers love their micro climates, unfortunately you're stuck with the inner sunset climate, but you at least get a little taste of the outside world and forget you are in a big city for a few minutes or hours while you visit. Top shelf ancestors, this place is amazing.
author: Nate S.

description: Such a huge disappointment  :(  We usually travel to San Francisco a few times a year. The Arboretum is a favorite stop when we visit Golden Gate Park. But this years visit was horrible. They started charging $7.00 a person for something that had once been free.  And the grounds that were once beautiful, were full of weeds, grass, and over grown plants. It looks like it hadn't been cared for in months. Both my husband and I were severely disappointed.  Save your money, the arboretum is not was it was at one time.
author: Tracy G.

description: When I read the snarky kid hater comments, I knew this would be a great place to bring my niece and nephew.  It was way more than I expected, especially given that it was free.  The kids (1.5 and 3) really enjoyed themselves.  I'd definitely recommend it.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description: This gem takes up 15% of Golden Gate Park, and is amazing. It is beautiful, and a treasured oasis for my young daughter. I came here with my grandfather and shared many picnics with my family.
author: Miguel L.

description:
The Garden is one of the best maintained and most impressive features of Golden Gate Park. No matter when you go, some colorful plants are sure to be in bloom. Spring, of course, is a wonderful time to experience the Garden, as the cherry, apple and magnolia trees are in bloom and colorful annuals line the paths.  But the diversity of plants in the garden ensures that no matter what time of year you visit, you will be overwhelmed by the many colors, textures, and types of plants. 
 The main pond and lawn are popular areas; there are almost always people picnicking, feeding birds and squirrels, and walking in these areas. These are certainly places to enjoy; in the pond you can see large fish swimming their way through the murky waters, and there are always many turtles sunning themselves on rocks or drifting lazily through the water. 
 Given all these people in the main areas, it is astonishing how few people you will see in the peripheral gardens where some of the most impressive parts of the Garden lie. The size of the Botanical Garden is impressive; each time I come here I discover some new bed or a tiny, carefully landscaped pond. I've also noticed, in my repeated visits, how often a bed has been added or improved. The vastness and variability of this garden make me think it must be nearly impossible to maintain, but it is clear the garden has a dedicated staff because the grounds are always in beautiful shape.
author: Kathleen B.

description: Gorgeous garden. I really enjoyed it when I visited. We went last June so it was little cold.
author: Charmaine P.

description:
The flowers are now in ecstatic bloom.  Magnolia scented walkways combined with flower dotted grass are making for some beautiful summer afternoons.  

Dear Boyfriend's Mother commented, when taken there last weekend, "This is paradise."  We also saw some beautiful partridges and blue birds in the Mediterranean gardens. 

Take your blanket, it's indeed quiet and so serene, unlike other parts of GG Park.  Even on Saturday we had no trouble parking less than a block away.
author: Mel B.

description: Thank you to the guy who works there who was kind enough to see me do the urgent pee pee dance and pointed me in the direction of the restroom...oh and the garden here is nice and its free! Free is always good..and the bathroom was clean. LOL
author: Lynn C.

description: I walked into this place for a leisurely walk after breakfast on a sunny day, all men should share this experience with someone, sometime while they are still living on this planet.
author: George M.

description:
this is a gem in this city.  i love going here to walk around and get lost in the park.  it's a little paradise to get away from the city and be surrounded be flora and fauna.  the lush grass is welcoming so you can have a little picnic with friends and enjoy the golden gate park band that plays every sunday at 1 PM (they are quite good).  the bathroom is newly renovated and it is so clean! there's even toilet covers, tiolet paper (no urine on the floor), soap, and paper towels.  a better restroom than many of the restaurant bathrooms!

i think it's the best public bathroom out there.
author: Amy Z.

description: It is very easy to get lost in the Australian region like Jane K. Today I finally made it out of there and visited the beautiful flowering native California plants, redwood grove, and Mediterranean garden. My absolute favorite part is the succulent garden, filled with amazingly weird plants. There was also a  band playing on the main park.  The arboretum is fantastic - so pretty, very peaceful, smells great!
author: Amy E.

description: Good quality trees, the atmosphere is relaxed and very fresh smelling bathroom. I got a little lost in the Australian region of tree life so that's really all I can speak for.  ps - The bathroom part is only for those who like to pee on trees
author: Jane K.

description: The place is awesome. I love the variation of foliage that this place and the Golden Gate Park as a whole has to offer. The place is great for those that appreciate wildlife. The place is truly family-friendly and a great place to relax at.
author: DJ Guan Yu M.

description: I think most people give this garden 5 stars because it is free for SF residence.  If they had to pay for it they may had to be a bit more critical.  It's a lovely place and pretty but its upkeep is not let say..."European style".  The weeds are everywhere, the pound water is murky and the California native area is not as extensive as it could and should be.  Still, it is peaceful and lovely.  Hard to beat on a beautiful day. The nursery is also a good source of plants to purchase.
author: Freda P.

description: Stunningly beautiful, and utterly inspiring - even on a cold and foggy summer's day.  A walk through the gardens provides nourishment for the spirit, and fortifies a love for all that is beautiful in this world!
author: Loretta G.

description: I've been going to the Strybing Arboretum/Botanical Gardens since I was a teenager. It was definitely my place to escape to and just breathe. Whenever I'm home for a visit, I always try to pass through and stroll around even if its only for 10 minutes. Your mind and body are put immediately at ease, and the variety of flora and fauna represented from all over the world is beyond impressive. Plenty of little nooks and crannies to hide out in and just be.  AAhhh, I think its time for another trip!
author: Rozz N.

description: The place is stunning.  I'm a detail person, one interesting plant can keep me in the same spot for 15 minutes - before drugs!  Fantastic shapes from around the world live and thrive here.  Tons of privacy benches on myriad winding paths - not the paved ones...
author: .Hazel T.

description: Did you know that San Francisco has the oldest Botanical Garden Arboretum in the country?  How cool.  And cool is this place in addition to being beautiful, serene, and soothing.  I love being around that many beautiful flowers and healthy plants from all over the world, I mean... There is a lot of positive energy in this place.  Throughout the nursery, there are so many orchids, which blow my mind every time that I see one.  In fact, somehow they are housed in every room.  They were housing a carnivorous plant room as their feature the last time I went and it was amazing.  I actually learn a lot from the gardens and the staff is extremely knowledgeable too.  The next time I go, I want to explore the outside gardens more.
author: Michelle N.

description: I love this one garden, I believe it is called the smelling garden? I do not know, but in the garden it has a lot of wonderful smelling things. I was trying to find the pineapple sage which smells like PINEAPPLES! But I didn't find it. I remembered I found it there several years ago.
author: Janet Z.

description: This is possibly one of my favorite things in the City. It saves me day after day. Walking in nature actually resets something in your body and nervous system so you work more efficiently. I read that recently...so I walk in the park and I am actually happier and more calm!
author: Deva G.

description: I've been here many times, and it's one of the more manicured places in Golden Gate Park. I love the fact that it's a free space in which you could spend a whole afternoon looking at. You won't get super excited like seeing the goats at the San Francisco Petting Zoo, but it is a very nice place to take a relaxing stroll. They're constantly building new additions, planting new plants, and maintain upkeep so that everything looks nice and beautiful. Great place to relax, meet old friends, or even take someone to for a date.
author: Clinton L.

description: I love this place, so peaceful.  Tons of squirrels which makes me think that the entire population of squirrels in SF resides here.  Huge area...beautiful plants and flowers.  Nice to walk and talk.
author: Nathalie C.

description: The perfect place on a sunny San Francisco afternoon.  It's so beautiful here with all of the flowers blooming and the little squirrels scampering about.  There's tons of little nooks and crannies to sit and read a book or to have a little picnic.  Of course you can always watch the ducks at the little pond or hang out on the field.  It's just so picturesque though and so peaceful that I love coming here.
author: Ke-Bear Z.

description: This is a great place in the park to hang out, have a picnic or take a nap (as I saw many people doing).  It's a pretty decent sized botanical garden, with plenty of different types of flowers and plants, but the upkeep was a bit lacking when I was there.  I'm sure it is very difficult to keep such a place pristine, but I really thought some of the areas needed a heavy gardening hand.  Maybe I just came during the seasonal transitional phase, but some of the plants were in need of some serious help.  But many were quite beautiful and there was certainly a good number of flowers from all over the world represented.
author: Jen K.

description: The sweetest hidden gem right off of 9th ave.  When you need a break from the med-student-wannabe-artiste world of the Canvas, put that laptop away and head over a block to the pond in the gardens.  The ducks are sweet, and do say hi, but my favorite creatures there are the turtles.  On sunny days the turtles hop on top of the rocks and all have their heads up, stretching out their little necks and legs on the rocks to soak up every ray of sun.  On colder days the pond is full of little micro U-boat like spies.  Just pairs of nostrils popping up above the water as they swim on by.  Minus one star for no trees in the big empty oval space, but that's my lament about GG Park in general, not enough trees shading the walkways.
author: San B.

description: I really love this place!!!!!!!!!!!!! They have awesome squirrels I means those guy have no fear and will come up to you if you have a morsel of food.  Pssst but your not allowed to feed the squirrels. Nice place to have little date with your boo ;) especially if he is on a budget ITS FREE :DI love this place. it's the perfect place for a cheap.... Free date!!!!!!! And not a bad date like yeah lets hang out in my friends garage cheap date, but its romantic and fun and will be memorable. The pond are is my fave. If I knew how to paint I would prop myself there and waste hours on end painting the flowers and water and ducks and oh yes the AGGRESSIVE ASS squirrels! They are savages never am I going to feed them, they bite but are soo cute. I know that's what I get for breaking the rule of feeding the squirrels, I'm week what can I say.
author: Kristina S.

description: This is a most beautiful arboretum. So many secret trails!!! When I was two, a squirrel ran up me here and I screamed, but that experience did not stop me from visiting arboretum. I like to eat sushi from Kiki's here, or roast on the lawn next to the geese.  So many trails, so much adventure! I love nature! FUN FACT: On the way to the Redwood Grove, you will see a garden that looks like the prarie. It reminds me of Laura Ingalls Wilder, who shares my bithday. For the ultimate prarie experience, check out the buffalo near the Polo Fields.
author: O K.

description:
love this park for hanging out and reading on a sunny weekend!

not too busy and really mellow ;-)
author: Jippers C.

description: A delicious escape from the city. An incredible variety of vegetation. Thoughtful landscaping makes for a lovely selection of scenes and passages. The aromatherapy garden is a treat for the nose. Make sure to scope the turtle pond!
author: Beatrix K.

description: super fun, really pretty, great ducks.... watch out one pecked at my toe :) also if you are a student you get in for free which is nice.
author: Mariana G.

description: Without a doubt, this is my favorite place in San Francisco. It's gorgeous! I could never get sick of coming here.
author: Janae L.

description: I read The Secret Garden while chasing squirrels in this serene oasis.
author: Janelle H.

description: Feed the ducks, explore the various habitats,visit the library and gift shop.  There are plenty of lovely little areas to explore and learn about, all with benches.  I especially like the shaded areas and the themed areas like the rose, Shakespeare and Biblical gardens.  So far it's still free and a very lovely place to spend time with kids or by yourself.
author: Merry P.

description: The gardens here are ok. I used to work in an arboretum/botanical garden back East and it was pretty impressive. I expected more from California for some reason. I've been here over  a decade now so there's no comparison anymore, only distant memories. A good place to relax and take in some nature when you're on a bike ride.
author: Colleen B.

description: One of my favorite places to get lost in nature....the Arboretum instantly helps me to relax. This was one of the first places I went to when I first moved to the city and it has remained a favorite, always a refreshing retreat from urban living. Now that it's across the street from me, I'm there even more often. Walking in the woods has always been something I love to do, and the Arboretum is about the closest I'll get to that within San Francisco.
author: Barbs J.

description: I came here this past weekend and the weather was beautiful and it was just a perfect place to be.  It wasn't very busy and the squirrels were out and about and pretty tame.  It's a great place to have lunch and just relax and it transports you outside of the hustle and bustle of the city.
author: Denny R.

description: I love walking around this park and looking at all the different types of plants and trees.  As the "owner" (there's some debate about if I own it or it owns me) of the largest cactus (night-blooming cereus peruvianus) in Sunnyvale, the succulent plants are my favorite.
author: J T.

description: AHHH I just love it! It's just so serene and beautiful here. Lovely pathways and amazing flowers! Once when I came here, I saw a mama quail and BABY QUAIL CHICKS following her! It was SO FREAKING CUTE! They were chirping and so tiny, I could've held one in my hand! Ahhh there are so many things to observe here, from the squirrels (who are crazy) to the flowers to the turtles and quails and other natural things. Come! And bring your camera :)
author: M J.

description: Calling all flower fanatics and grandmas, come here to check out nature! just kidding, its open to all. On a good morning, its nice to walk around here with a friend of hubby and relax. Squirrels, various species of birds and ob course various types of botanicals. Shades of Orange, reds and yellows. One of the touristy areas of SF but still nice EARLY in the morning. Lets say around 8-9am. =]
author: Jason C. J.

description: The best free place in the city. Love everything about it; except the ducks in the pond, they seem to have a lot of attitude.
author: Dustin H.

description: Single most beautiful place in GGP, if you never went to this place might get lost, but you don't care because the beautiful flowers and trees make up for that. This is for : Bringing your loved one out for a special time, Hanging out with friends ( great place to blaze one ), and the best place for meditation or whatever, anyone can make this their comfort utopia.
author: Maurice T.

description: Wow just an amazing garden. This is the kind of place that William Wordsworth would stroll around before writing his poetry. There are so many place to see---nooks and crannies. You could not really see it all in one visit. Amazing.
author: Jason W.

description: You know, I never knew this existed and I've lived in SF for a long time. Went today and was pleasantly surprised that it is free! It's huge garden with paths, bridges and different exhibits for trees, flowers and plants from the different continents and countries. Japan was really cool and same with Chile.  I also liked the magnolia trees and silver tip tree (it's furry!!) Will have to go back when it gets a little warmer and more flowers are blooming. Such a nice place to go for some peace and serenity in the city.
author: Natalie S.

description: It's kind of a small place, but it's quite lovely to visit nonetheless.  They had an excellent orchid exhibit here in 2005-06.
author: Asteridae A.

description: There are so many trails here, you get lost.  Each section of the garden is modeled after a different geographical area.  And it's free!
author: Merredith L.

description: I love the Arboretum... It's sooo gorgeous... I used to go here on Easter Sunday with my parents when I was much younger... Now, I like to wander the trails with friends or a special someone and get totally lost (which I always do somehow)... Of course it's nice in the spring, but it's also really nice in the Fall and Winter... And it's free! Can't beat that!
author: Lindsey S.

description:
it's springtime!  this place must be so gorgeous right now!

trees/plants/flowers from all over the world.  i love the fact that they have the information about each species right next to it.  how else would i know what it's name is and where it's from?

great to go alone, or even better on a date.  it's romantic.  pack a lunch and make a picnic of it.

parking can be tough.  take bus out there if you can, or dare to hunt down a spot to park your ride.
author: Sheri N.

description: I love this place! Brings back so many memories....Its a small lil garden full of beautiful flowers. Its a great place to go for a mini-date. Its just a short walk from 9th and Irving, and after strolling around with your one and only, you could head over to Inner Sunset to grab a bite to eat and maybe a Jamba Juice!
author: Jessica h.

description: A nice place to go on a sunny day with someone you love or care deeply about. Alot of walking because there's alot to see. I've visited here twice in my life time. FIrst time I saw a person ask his girl to marry him...which was very swt. Another time I saw a crazy bum try fight a invisible person and nearly hurting some viewers. In all a nice place  to go, but I wish there wasmore security or availible staff around.
author: David M.

description: The Botanical Garden is beautifully relaxing. I could spend all day here finding new trails that lead to different plants and flowers. All of the squirrels are so cute too. It's easy to get lost because it's so enormous here so I don't recommend going alone for the first time. If you want to have a picnic on the grass, play frisbee, throw around a baseball, or just lay back and soak up the sun you can do that too. This is one of many perfect ways to spend a day.
author: Jen Y.

description: i went running there on Saturday and you can run back and forth between dirt trails through the plants and pavement trails through the garden.  It smells so nice there, I just really enjoyed it.
author: Lindsay T.

description: Take the guided tour! Wow, you'll learn a lot!
author: Shira L.

description:
I know we're not supposed to feed the squirrels, but I couldn't help it... safeway was having a two for one special on 5 lb bags of unsalted peanuts. And they seem so friendly, walking up to you begging for a peanut.

This is one of the prettiest parts of the park with all the different themed sections to roam around and explore. When the weather's right, definitely pack a picnic (and the peanuts) and visit the Botanical Garden. It's also located just a few steps away from the De Young Museum, Japanese Tea Gardens and soon to be Academy of Science Museum.
author: Samantha F.

description: Leisurely strolling around plants from the four corners of the world, for free, is tough to beat.  It is ridiculous to think how this makes up only one sliver of Golden Gate Part, yet it's quite large itself.  Wonderful gardens are split up by theme/geographic region.  I particularly liked the "primitive" section which had plants that are closely related to plants of yesteryear ... you know, when Leave it to Beaver was hip.
author: Paul K.

description: The gardens are beautiful and family friendly.  I take the kids there to run around and enjoy the open space.  I'm taking a star off because of the cranky older people who sometimes frequent the park.  For example, I had one woman try and turn my preschooler in for running after the geese.  NOTE- He was overcome with excitement and couldn't help himself.  I warned him not to chase after the birds in the future.  Another time, I had a man holler at my kids for feeding the fish and ducks.  (Look, there is a rule not to feed the squirrels BUT according to the Docent at the gardens, there is no rule against feeding any other animals bread).
author: c v.

description: Best California native plant sale about once a month. Great library with amazing books to enjoy, not for check outs. Great collection of various plants from around the world and guess what? it's FREEEEEE for the viewing. Just pay for the plants that you decide upon to support this wonderful Society.
author: miriam b.

description: Huntington LIbrary look-alike, but condensed. Nice for walking in the afternoon in a good weather.
author: Anya B.

description:
my most favorite place in golden gate park.  i especially love the succulent garden because it has the strangest plants.  they have free tours every day at 1:30. one time we had a guide that was obsessed with how budget cuts caused the weeds to get out of hand.  he continually muttered about examining plants throughout the tour and once looked at what was a very large bush or a small tree and asked himself "is this a weed?". he wasn't joking.  it was funny.
always the same place, but always something new to learn from each tour  person.
author: locustgirl ..

description: So I have never gone to the Botanical Gardens, until yesterday when I was sitting at home and wanted to do something, so I figured I have to have an adventure and that I wanted to find this place in the park that I kept on seeing from lincoln everyday I drive by, where the park is lower than the road, and thats how I stumbled onto the botanical gardens. It was awesome, I am not that big on flowers but they had a cloud garden which is so cool and a redwood grove, which I miss since I cant go to marin as much as I would like to. So awesome. Highly suggest it.
author: Ryan O.

description:
This place is a wonderland!
It is free.
Many things to see, you can spend a whole afternoon here.
There is no admission cost.
Many scenic areas, decent for pictures.
It is FREE.
Hidden away nooks and crannies to get lost with that special someone. ^_~
F-R-E-E!!!
author: M. W.

description: I've been here a few times. I don't know much about plants but this area is really beautiful. You can tell that they put a lot of work into it - It is really well kept up.
author: Stu M.

description: I never new about this place but we pass by after the tea garden and thought why not. Its free and a good place to walk off lunch. Overall there is something in bloom here year around and you can see everyone enjoys the gardens since they are well maintain and plus the lawns they have are perfect just to relax and sun yourself. Its a little escape from the busy of the city. One thing for sure I never seen so many squirrels in my life all in one place. Its a clan and everywhere you turn you would find one. They are not afraid of people either, coming real up close to you. Probably thinking you had food for them and they are more than willing to pose for pictures. You can tell they are well feed since all of them are all plump and have bushy tails. I must say if I was a squirrel I would want to live here too, its heaven. I would like to come back in the spring when everything is in bloom and check out all the flowers. Great place for a walk.
author: Donna Y.

description: One of our civic and cultural gems, and all natural.  Great work by everyone who works and volunteers to keep it green, relavent and beautiful.  Plant sale first sunday of the month is one of the best kept secrets in the Bay Area.  Succulents are especially plentiful and affordable.
author: Ken H.

description: Came with a friend to check out the lunar floral display.  Beautiful!  Many different types of plants, not just flowers.  The building was EXTREMELY humid, would highly recommend a tank top for the sweating factor in here, but it was well worth it.  Make sure you get all the way to the eastern end.  There is a beautiful pond with gorgeous lillys.
author: andrea c.

description: i originally came here for a school project on botany but left knowing a great spot to just walk through exotic plants and soak up a day of great weather. you cant beat the free admission, and the place is always manicured very nicely. sure there are more exiting places to go but sometimes its nice to not see a car for a 1/2 hour. yah know?
author: Andrew D.

description: My kids love hanging out there.  There's a particular bird, well it's a seagull (any ol seagull) they call CHOCCO.
author: Steve W.

description: I come here frequently - I am a plant nut- I love seeing the plants as they change through the seasons and it's a great place for walking.  They have wonderful plant sales most every month, too, full of temptations to add to my garden.  The California native gardens are wonderful in the spring!  Look in all the nooks and crannies - there's lots of treasures everywhere.
author: Charlotte M.

description: This is the most amazing piece of nature in the middle of a busy city.  Provides the best relaxation and it is free.  I am concerned with the proposed usage fee and would like to ask everybody who will read this to call the board of supervisors and let hem know what do you think about this misguided initiative
author: Eugene K.

description: there isnt much i can say that hasnt already been said about this place. just wonderful. plain and simple.. a true delight. sf is lucky to have place like this. if you live in sf and havent been here, what the hell is your problem? id say come late april - oct, you cant go wrong with a visit here, whether you take a friend, a date, kids, parents, everyone will enjoy it.
author: Euge L.

description: I think that the Botanical Gardens is a great place to learn about lots of interesting plants. It is clean nice and teaches you lotsof things. I liked it when I saw butterflies and that I learned that you can't touch butterflies or else it'll die or can't taste any more!
author: Christina L.

description: the day we went was a really nice day. the sun was out and it was getting pretty warm so we decided to take a seat on a bench under a tree. as we were sitting down admiring nature we noticed little squirrels around us. the next thing we know they were getting really close. i have to admit, they were so adorable. my boyfriend picked up an empty peanut shell and told me to take a picture of him feeding a squirrel. yeah.... the squirrel ending up scratching him and made his finger start bleeding. the squirrels were no longer all that cute and began to literally surround us after that. we got freaked and ended up leaving after just 10 minutes. other than that, it looks like a good place to actually stroll around and not just sit on a bench.
author: Aber M.

description: Ahh, the botanical gardens. The times I had as a teenager running amuck here. I wish I was so easily amused now, but then again, I think I may be. These gardens never lose their charm for me. Growing up in San Francisco made me very horticulturally deprived. No front yard, only a communal backyard that was really just a slab of cement in a 10x12 space. No wonder I am so obsessed with botanical gardens and flowers in general. It doesn't matter where I go in the world, I always have to see the city's Garden. The Grand Dame of them all, of course, being in London. Kew Gardens is amazing and grandiose on a big scale but come on, that's London. I must admit, it's the most impressive I've ever seen but our Botanical Garden does a mighty good job of standing it's own here in SF. I love the Conservatory, not only for it's displays but it's history and I was so excited when it finally reopened. The outside gardens are just gorgeous and I can still lose myself in them just as I did over a decade ago when I would look for little elves hiding amongst the flowers. Suffice to say, all I found were bums and Haight street punks drinking Robitussin, but we all have to grow up sometime. I still hold a shred of my rosy colored youth in spite of it. ;-) They also offer lots of neat classes and bird walking tours, among others. I can watch the birds and squirrels there for hours, so see, I guess I still am easily amused!
author: Brittany A.

description: This place is amazing!  We walked around for a couple of hours, and were constantly saying "Wow.", "Look at that.", "This is so beautiful."  Lots of special trees, plants and flowers, beautifully landscaped gardens, lots of information, and it's all free.  Special mention of the redwood forest, so peaceful and calm.  I will definitely be back with a good book on a sunny day.
author: Marijke D.

description: the best place to be. im going to move in here. in the new zealand area. one time i left my eyeglasses on the grass. i came back the next day and they were still there. wooo.
author: Alissa S.

description: Green, violent violet, red.  The colors just flow all around.  It's the one place in the park that actually smells good.  That and they have the highest concentration of squirrels.  I love squirrels and everything that has to do with them, especially feeding them.  They're such rascals, jumping all over me, clawing their way to claim that nut, one that they will bury for the winter that is many months away.  Squirrels do not understand the notion of immediate satisfaction.  The only downside is the duck pond.  Maybe it's just me, but I do not think it would be that difficult to put city money to use in finding a better way of keeping that waterhole clean.  Thankfully, that pond is only a minute fraction of what the park offers.  There an innumerable number of trails one could take, allowing a person to get lost in their own fanciful pursuits.  On sunny days, the park outshines itself, taking on an almost distant feel from the rest of the city.  I've enjoyed walking through there since I was really young, and it has unparalleled beauty.  It exudes a calm that washes over me, permitting a release from all else that exists beyond its non-pearly gates.  And of course there are the squirrels.  Can't forget the squirrels.  They're my friends.
author: Alexander S.
